webTitle: Nasty Nick puts heat on Pope in Today poll

fields.headline: Nasty Nick puts heat on Pope in Today poll
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: With a TV presenter and a game show contestant racking up votes, the heroes and villains poll seems to exhibit precisely the sort of dumbing down criticised by Radio 4 presenter John Humphreys.
fields.body:
With a TV presenter and a game show contestant racking up votes, the heroes and villains poll seems to exhibit precisely the sort of dumbing down criticised by Radio 4 presenter John Humphreys. Unfortunately, the survey is the work of his own Today programme, giving him little opportunity to decry the shortlists issued yesterday.

The show is attempting to revive its personality of the year award, axed in 1997 after Labour and Conservative supporters tried to fix the results. The programme's editor, Rod Liddle, decreed that no politicians would be eligible, in an attempt to stop such cheating.

This year Anne Robinson, quizmistress on the Weakest Link, is the only woman to appear on either list - as a villain. Nasty Nick (Bateman) from the TV show Big Brother makes it on to the shortlist of heroes, despite his reputation. It seems a far cry from the days when the Pope, Mrs Thatcher and Mikhail Gorbachev won the contest.

But a BBC spokesman stressed: "It's a lighthearted look at the people who caught the public's attention over the year."

Chris Woodhead enjoys the distinction of being nominated in both categories, although the former chief inspector of schools had yesterday received only 12.8% of the vote in the heroes category, half that garnered as a villain.

Steve Redgrave, winner of five Olympic gold medals for rowing, had notched up more than 45% of votes for heroes. Team Philips yachtsman Pete Goss also appears on the list - despite the loss of his £4m catamaran in which he was preparing to sail round the world. He may have won votes for his bravery in the face of defeat, much like PY Gerbeau, chief executive of the ill-fated Millennium Dome.

Bob Ayling, former chief executive of British Airways and the dome, however, is placed firmly in the villains' camp alongside Brian Souter, chairman of Stagecoach and a leading campaigner against the repeal of clause 28.

Richard Branson is also included, as is Alan Nash, former managing director of Equitable Life, presumably for his part in bringing the country's oldest mutual insurance company to its knees.

Listeners have until midnight to vote. The winner will be announced on Saturday.

webTitle: BBC3 to cram news into one minute

fields.headline: BBC3 to cram news into one minute
fields.trailText: The BBC is spending £1m on a one-minute news bulletin for its new youth channel, BBC3.
fields.body:
The BBC is spending £1m on a one-minute news bulletin for its new youth channel, BBC3. In a move that will bring despair to traditionalists, the fast-moving hourly news service is designed for the "disposable society", with emphasis on showbusiness and sport.

A producer from Newsbeat, the fast-paced news service on Radio 1, and another from the BBC's entertainment programme Liquid News are developing the new proposition.

BBC3 is part of the corporation's new "family" of digital channels, which will be launched next year subject to the approval of the culture secretary, Chris Smith. It will be a youth and entertainment network, developed from BBC Choice, and available free to the millions of viewers who have digital television.

Its controller-designate, Stuart Murphy, has been given an increased budget to make quality programmes. He wants the news service to reflect the channel's target audience, and has the support of Greg Dyke, the BBC director general, who wants it to "break many of the conventions of traditional news services".

Colin Hancock, from Radio 1, and Chris Wilson, from BBC Choice's Liquid News, have put together the proposal for an hourly one-minute news bulletin aimed at a youth audience. It will be fronted by a young presenter, probably a woman, and will feature a "busy" split screen with a torrent of information thrown at viewers.

The programme will be supported by a website, which would provide more detailed reports, in video and audio format. The cost of a flashy title sequence, modern set and a pool of journalists will come to more than £1m a year.

"Stuart is determined to give the disposable society what it wants," said one BBC News executive, who was supportive of the plans. "But if he got his way completely, he would cram in 20 stories in 11 seconds." In the past year, Liquid News, which is produced by BBC News and has its own dedicated team of reporters, has been a notable success. The show will continue when BBC Choice becomes BBC3 in the autumn, alongside the new headline news service.

Pitching news at a youth audience is notoriously difficult. ITN's programmes for Channel 5 were the first concerted attempts to change the way news is reported. But Channel 5 News has gone through a number of presenters.

A BBC Choice spokeswoman stressed that no details about the programming strategy for BBC3 had been finalised.

From Newsround to the News Bunny

John Craven's Newsround First commissioned by the BBC in 1972 for an initial six week run of 10-minute bulletins, it concentrated on stories of particular interest to children and each item had to be self-contained and self-explanatory. Parliamentary issues were not prominent unless legislation affected the audience. It has often had major news stories before the main bulletins, such as the 1986 Challenger disaster and John Major's resignation as leader of the Conservative party. In 1989, after 3,000 editions, John Craven left and the programme was renamed Newsround.

The Big Breakfast Launched in September 1992 as an alternative to the pastel-sofas-in-TV-studio morning programmes. Set in a small house in the east end of London it was to have frequent news spots, but never wanted to be seen as primarily a news service. With an emphasis on pop and showbiz, the idea was to appeal to adults and children alike. It was seen as a radical departure from Channel 4's hard hitting news format and proved a massive success, attracting 2m viewers after only a year.

Live TV To set the cable channel's news bulletins apart from the "dull and regimented" format of mainstream programmes it created News Bunny, a man in a rabbit suit who interpreted the news with gestures of pleasure or sadness. A two-minute 'people news' came every hour, celebrity-led with plenty of gossip. But the channel failed to gain public support and closed in October 1999.

Sally James Gregory

webTitle: Paraglider arrested at Buckingham Palace

fields.headline: Paraglider arrested at Buckingham Palace
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: A man was arrested today after he flew his paraglider on to the forecourt of Buckingham Palace.
fields.body:
A man was arrested today after he flew his paraglider on to the forecourt of Buckingham Palace.

Armed police were waiting to swoop on Brett De La Mare, who was pursued by a police helicopter as he flew low over central London.

Mr De La Mare, 36, is an Australian author seeking publicity in an attempt to land a publishing deal. He was taken to a central London police station and faces possible criminal charges for breaching air safety laws.

He circled the palace before landing in the forecourt where the changing of the guard ceremony takes place. Mr De La Mare's flatmate Monica Kelly, a 22-year-old Australian public relations executive, said he had been flying the motorised paraglider in an effort to get publicity for his unpublished book Canine Dawn.

He has been involved in similar stunts in the past and claims on his website, brettdelamare.com, to have recently flown around New York's World Trade Centre and Empire State building.

Police sources said today's incident was apparently a publicity stunt.

A palace spokesman said no members of the royal family were in the building at the time. Senior royals are currently at Sandringham, the Queen's Norfolk estate, where they are spending the Christmas and new year period.

Today's incident is the second time a flying intruder has breached royal security. In 1994 naked American paraglider Jim Miller landed on the roof of the palace. A Scotland Yard spokesman confirmed a 36-year-old man was arrested at 1.10pm today in the forecourt of Buckingham Palace today.

A police helicopter had spotted the paraglider before it landed and had alerted officers on the ground. The helicopter had tailed the paraglider from Hampstead Heath, over Regent's Park, down Whitehall and the Mall before it landed.

Bemused tourists watched as a police helicopter tried to warn the paraglider away. Eric Schmidt, 57, from Berlin, said: "I suddenly heard the helicopter and looked up and saw the man in a parachute. The helicopter was going towards him and he was being given a warning on a loudspeaker, but the man did not seem to take any notice. He landed running on his feet behind the gate and he was quickly whisked away by police."

webTitle: MPs urge delaying reading and writing

fields.headline: Delay formal teaching of reading and writing until children reach six, MPs urge
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: MPs will next month press for the formal teaching of reading, writing and maths to be postponed well beyond the nursery stage, to the point where the "foundations" of a child's early education are established.
fields.body:
MPs will next month press for the formal teaching of reading, writing and maths to be postponed well beyond the nursery stage, to the point where the "foundations" of a child's early education are established.

The recommendation, to be included in a long-awaited report on early years education written by the influential all-party education select committee and due to be published in the next two weeks, will undermine the government's determination to establish "basics", such as reading and writing, early on.

Ministers have already come under fire for putting learning before play in the crucial early years. The government published a guide to what a child should be able to do - such as simple counting and name recognition - on arrival at primary school. And its guidelines allowing smacking with parental consent were seen as controversial, receiving strong criticism from the select committee's MPs, who have been taking evidence for months from childcare and early years experts. The MPs have advised that childminders should not be allowed to smack, or smoke in front of their charges

A member of the committee said MPs had also been extremely concerned about government moves to encourage more formal learning on entry to nursery or primary school reception at the age of three or four.

"The move towards more formal learning at an early age was something that seemed to gain momentum under the former chief inspector for schools, Chris Woodhead," the MP said. "The evidence from abroad shows there are long-term benefits to starting formal learning later - at, say, age six."

The MPs were also worried by the inspection role planned for early years schooling by the Office for Standards in Education. The watchdog Ofsted is on the verge of naming the person to lead its early years inspectorate which next year will start inspecting all 33,000 nurseries, playgroups and childminders in England.

Meanwhile, the government is to create more than 200,000 new childcare jobs over the next three years, as part of a drive to expand nursery provision and get lone parents and low-income families back to work. The jobs, covering childminders at home, pre-school groups and nurseries, will mean the UK's workforce of childcarers doubles between 1998 and 2004. The positions- aimed at men, ethnic minorities and those over 40, as well as young women - will help provide a million new childcare places by 2004.

webTitle: Woodhead: once a Tory, always a Tory

fields.headline: Woodhead: once a Tory, always a Tory
fields.standfirst:
It will come as no surprise if the next Conservative assault on Labour's education policy is led by the former Ofsted chief, writes Derek Brown

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText:
It will come as no surprise if the next Conservative assault on Labour's education policy is led by the former Ofsted chief, writes Derek Brown.
Education Unlimited
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead, the former chief inspector of schools and scourge of the teaching profession, could soon be back in the thick of the education fray.

The Conservatives have been keen to recruit Woodhead ever since his abrupt resignation from Ofsted on November 3. Now William Hague is said to be close to appointing him as chief shadow spokesman on education, with a seat in the House of Lords.

He would supersede Theresa May, who may retain her shadow education role in the House of Commons.

With the new year's honours list due to be published on Saturday, there is intense speculation that Woodhead's return to public life is imminent.

He is bound by Whitehall convention to remain silent about his time at Ofsted until February 28 - three clear calendar months after his resignation. But that would leave him plenty of scope to lambast Labour's education record in the run-up to a May general election.

There is little doubt that the irascible, unpredictable Woodhead would relish that task. He regularly traded verbal blows with the education secretary, David Blunkett, who did not trouble to conceal his relief when the Ofsted boss resigned.

Indeed, it is an open secret in Westminster that Blunkett wanted to ditch Woodhead when Labour returned to power in May 1997. He was overruled by Tony Blair, who is an admirer of Woodhead's "modernising" ways and his obsession with tests and league tables.

More recently, Woodhead had high-decibel spats with Blunkett and his officials over alleged financial waste in the school system, and over Labour grassroots resistance to the abolition of local education authorities.

He has also been scathing about education action zones and other inititiatives he dismisses as gimmicks.

There is little doubt that during his controversial Ofsted stint, Woodhead amassed a good deal of potentially damaging insights into Labour internal feuds, as well as a mass of information about the inner workings of the education system.

But ministers appear to be relaxed about the possible elevation of Milord Woodhead to the opposition front bench. They believe that with his track record of abrasiveness, he might well self-destruct in the glare of publicity.

There is also the problem, from the Conservative point of view, of his oft-repeated protest: "I am not a Tory". However, his choice of post-Ofsted jobs - leader writing at the Daily Telegraph and a part-time consultancy with Margaret Thatcher's favourite lobbying outfit - suggests that his views are a great deal closer to Hague's than Blair's.

webTitle: Bin Laden link to Frankfurt terror suspects

fields.headline: Bin Laden link to Frankfurt terror suspects
fields.trailText: German authorities were today questioning four suspected terrorists with ties to Osama bin Laden.
fields.body:
German authorities were today questioning four suspected terrorists with ties to Osama bin Laden.

Weapons and explosives were seized during a search of two Frankfurt apartments, federal prosecutors announced today. The four suspects were arrested on Tuesday suspected of belonging to a criminal organisation, arms and explosives violations and falsifying documents.

During a subsequent search of two apartments yesterday, authorities seized 20kg of potassium permanganate, which prosecutors said can be used to manufacture explosives, as well as homemade detonators, a hand grenade, sub-machineguns, dismantled rifles, revolvers and ammunition.

All four suspects were living under assumed names, and prosecutors said their true identities were not yet known. Their documents identified them as Ayoubi B of Algeria, Hisham E and Lamin M of Iraq and Fouad S of France.

Prosecutors said they were part of an international network trained by Bin Laden's followers in Afghanistan, and that they set up logistics in Germany to support attacks on the "enemies of Islam".

No evidence linking them to any actual or planned attack was found, prosecutors said.

A Saudi exile accused of running a global terrorist network from bases in Afghanistan, Bin Laden is wanted in the United States on charges of directing the 1998 bombings of US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania.

webTitle: Britain gets extended white Christmas

fields.headline: Britain gets extended white Christmas
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Arctic conditions today blanketed much of Britain in snow, bringing travel chaos to road, rail and air services.
fields.body:
Arctic conditions today blanketed much of Britain in snow, bringing travel chaos to road, rail and air services.

As temperatures plunged below zero, police advised drivers not to venture on to the roads unless absolutely necessary and motoring organisations said speeds should be kept to an absolute minimum.

Overnight six inches of snow fell in parts of Wales as the big freeze moved east across the country, leaving the Midlands, west country and Gloucestershire under deep snow.

There were also heavy falls overnight in Northern Ireland and parts of Scotland, which has suffered its coldest winter for five years with lows of -14C (7F) yesterday.

London's first snowfall for four years turned the city white and led to the closure of the London Eye, or Millennium Wheel.

Up to eight inches of snow fell in Glasgow, leaving about 1,000 passengers stranded at the city's airport. The last flight left at 10pm yesterday and a snow clearing operation was under way on the runway.

The airport was officially closed at 5.30am today and it was expected to be late morning before planes started taking off again, an airport spokesman said.

Parts of Ayrshire and Argyll were also badly hit and police across the west of Scotland urged motorists to allow extra time for their journeys.

Liverpool Airport was also closed by snow and racing at Haydock Park near Wigan was cancelled.

The runway at Gatwick Airport in West Sussex was closed until around 7.30am and some flights had to be diverted to other airports.

At Stansted in Essex, some early-morning flights were cancelled or diverted and passengers were enduring delays of up to 90 minutes.

In Devon, a couple and their 12-month-old child had to be airlifted off Dartmoor last night after their car became stuck in snow. A police four-wheel-drive vehicle was unable to reach them because of black ice and snow and they were taken to safety by police helicopter.

All London Underground lines were experiencing delays, including some caused by points failures.

Kent Police said the M25, M26, M20 and M2 were "hazardous" because of very heavy snow. Ten vehicles were involved in a crash on the M25 between Epping and Brentwood. Part of the A27 in Brighton, a steep hill between the A23 and Brighton University, was closed after lorries started sliding backwards in the icy conditions. Police also closed the northbound M40 near High Wycombe in Buckinghamshire after several stranded lorries blocked the carriageway. About three inches of snow fell in the area overnight.

In north Wales, a lorry driver had to be rescued from his cab after the vehicle careered off the A55 at St Asaph, near Rhyl, in heavy snow and was left overhanging a busy road below. He escaped unhurt.

Several inches of snow fell across north-west England, with police warning drivers to stay at home.

In Lancashire a police helicopter was scrambled to airlift a 76-year-old man from an isolated farm after he suffered a heart attack.

Many motorways in the West Midlands were reduced to a single lane, with a 30mph speed restriction in place, and in Warwickshire police urged motorists to stay at home.

webTitle: TV ads prompt rush to join police

fields.headline: TV ads prompt rush to join police
fields.standfirst:
15,000 replies to 'Could You?' campaign

Policing crime
fields.trailText: 15,000 replies to 'Could You?' campaign
fields.body:
A £7m advertising campaign which focused on the most distressing aspects of police work has generated nearly 15,000 responses from applicants interested in joining the service, according to Home Office figures released yesterday.

A quarter of the responses to the adverts, which have the theme "Could You?" and have featured actress Patsy Palmer and former England footballer John Barnes, came from women, while 4% were from people of ethnic minority backgrounds.

The campaign continued last night with a 60-second slot on ITV featuring the broadcaster Joan Bakewell, who is asked whether she could remain emotionally detached while interviewing a suspected rapist. Like the other celebrities who have featured, she concedes that she is not up to the task.

As well as boosting applications, a Home Office survey in dicates that the advertisements have painted a more complex picture of police work in the minds of the public.

The police service has been battered by bad publicity in recent years and is suffering from poor morale.

Figures released when the recruitment campaign was launched in August showed the number of police officers in England and Wales had dropped from 127,158 in 1997 to 124,418 by March this year.

Metropolitan police commissioner Sir John Stevens warned this week that pressure on resources was leading to police on the beat being transferred to answer emergency calls and carry out administrative tasks.

He said 200 officers had been transferred off the streets and that by February, the Met would be short of 1,000 civilians and 2,500 uniformed officers on six years ago.

However, yesterday's figures showed that Sir John's force, hardest hit by the recruitment crisis, has enjoyed the most interest with 1,127 applicants.

New government figures released separately showed that the number of new police trainees entering colleges had risen by 41% from April to November this year.

Home Office minister Mike O'Brien said the government was keen not only to raise numbers but to show the public the difficult and challenging circumstances in which police officers worked.

But critics have pointed out that the crucial problem is not in generating interest but in recruiting and retaining officers.

In March the home secretary, Jack Straw, announced that recruits to the Metropolitan police would be offered a bonus of up to £3,000 to ease the cost of living in the capital.

The extra cash was to make up for a London housing allowance that was scrapped five years ago and took a new constable's pay package to £23,500 a year.

webTitle: Three sought for racist attack on Turk

fields.headline: Three sought for racist attack on Turk
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Police are looking for three white men ejected from a pub in Southwark, south London, on Christmas Eve and suspected of an attack on a Turkish man that left him with serious injuries and surviving on an artificial ventilator.
fields.body:
Police are looking for three white men ejected from a pub in Southwark, south London, on Christmas Eve and suspected of an attack on a Turkish man that left him with serious injuries and surviving on an artificial ventilator.

Cumali Bagirtkan, 41, an asylum seeker, suffered a "severe and unprovoked" assault, which, police believe, was carried out by the men. Detective Inspector Jonathan Tottman said officers were treating the attack as racially motivated.

"We believe he was walking back from a friend's house and came into the side street. At around the same time three men were ejected from the Blue Anchor pub [because of] unruly behaviour."

Mr Bagirtkan, a father of two, from a village near Aksaray in central Turkey, was found by police at 11.30pm on Sunday lying in the street. He had been in Britain for over a year. Yesterday his wife was flying in from Ankara to join his brother at his bedside.

Mr Tottman added: "I have just come from the hospital...we are not sure if he is going to survive. He is in a stable but very critical condition. He has very serious head injuries caused by either a blunt instrument or feet and fists."

webTitle: Explosions rock Israel after summit cancelled

fields.headline: Explosions rock Israel after summit cancelled
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Hours after the abrupt cancellation of a planned Middle East summit today, a bus bomb went off on one of Tel Aviv's busiest roads, reportedly injuring 14 people, sparking panic and sending black smoke billowing through the air.
fields.body:
Hours after the abrupt cancellation of a planned Middle East summit today, a bus bomb went off on one of Tel Aviv's busiest roads, reportedly injuring 14 people, sparking panic and sending black smoke billowing through the air.

The blast came as efforts to implement the US peace plan lurched from hope to uncertainty. Egypt called off plans to host the summit at the prompting of Israel, which said it was frustrated by the intransigence of the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat.

Later today an Israeli was killed and three were injured in an explosion along Israel's border with Gaza Strip, military sources said. The roadside explosion occurred near the Sufa crossing point in the southern Gaza Strip, the sources said.

Police sources said the explosion happened when the Israelis were attempting to dismantle the device.

Though many Arabs denounced President Clinton's peace proposals - which called for deep and painful concessions from both Israelis and Palestinians - it won support from Egypt and Saudi Arabia.

Both sides had expressed reservations about the US proposals. But the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, accepted the plan as a basis for further talks, while Palestinians sharply contested it.

Egyptian foreign minister Amr Moussa praised Mr Clinton's efforts, adding: "In order to activate President Clinton's initiative, it seems it needs some time."

Mr Arafat, returning from talks in Egypt with President Hosni Mubarak, said the opinion of the Muslim world would carry great weight in Palestinians' continuing deliberations on the American proposals. "These issues should be discussed with our Arab brothers," Mr Arafat said.

Late yesterday the Palestinians sent the Clinton administration a letter detailing misgivings on 24 separate points in the proposal. A senior Palestinian official said the objections were serious enough to amount to a rejection of the plan, but the US state department said it was still awaiting a formal Palestinian response.

There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the Tel Aviv explosion. Mr Barak vowed to track down the perpetrators, and vowed that such attacks would not deter his government from peace efforts.

During the past three months of violence, Palestinian militants have claimed responsibility for two bombings inside Israel, one in a Jerusalem market and the other in the northern town of Hadera. Since late September, fighting by Israeli troops and Palestinians in the West Bank, Gaza Strip and east Jerusalem has killed nearly 350 people, most of them Palestinians.

Mr Barak and Mr Arafat had been due to meet with Mr Mubarak in the Red sea resort of Sharm el-Sheik tonight. But early today, Egypt announced that the meeting was cancelled.

Barak told his Cabinet he would not sign any agreement transferring sovereignty over the Temple Mount to the Palestinians - even though his foreign minister, Shlomo Ben-Ami, had said after last week's Washington talks that Israel was prepared to take such a step.

The prime minister, who faces an election challenge in less than six weeks from the veteran rightwinger Ariel Sharon, had come in for a storm of criticism over the planned concession, from across the political spectrum. The Palestinians, meanwhile, appeared most opposed to requirements they scale back demands for the return of millions of refugees to their homes in Israel. Both sides requested a number of clarifications of the US plan.

webTitle: Early-bird bargain hunters brave the freeze

fields.headline: Early-bird bargain hunters brave the freeze
fields.trailText: Freezing weather and Christmas hangovers failed to prevent thousands of bargain hunters descending on shops before dawn yesterday as the sales season began in earnest.
fields.body:
Freezing weather and Christmas hangovers failed to prevent thousands of bargain hunters descending on shops before dawn yesterday as the sales season began in earnest.

Shoppers began queueing outside Selfridges in Oxford Street, London, shortly after 4am, undaunted by an overnight temperature of -3C and the prospect of waiting until the store opened at 10am, by which time some 1,000 people were outside. Peter Williams, Selfridges finance director, said the sale had got off to a strong start. "The most popular brand was Burberry and everything we had put in the sale had sold within an hour and a half."

Elsewhere in the capital shops reported a sluggish start, with Liberty, Hamleys and Harrods all seeing smaller than expected crowds.

Outside London early starts were also the order of the day. The clothing chain Next opened at shopping centres across the country from 5am.

Queues formed outside Cribbs Causeway, Bristol, at 1.10am and around 250 shoppers were queuing by the time Next opened. The centre's operations manager, John McColl, said: "We decided to open our doors at 4am to allow people to come in from the cold.

In Swansea's Oxford Street shoppers started queuing at 3.30am outside Next, and in Cardiff queues started at around 4.15am.

Around 1,000 people queued in Liverpool's Church Street before 4am, while more than 400 people queued for the 5am start at the Braehead shopping centre near Glasgow. General manager Bob Baldry said the centre was "exceptionally busy".

webTitle: Tel Aviv blast hits slender peace hopes

fields.headline: Tel Aviv blast hits slender peace hopes
fields.standfirst:
Derek Brown sees a glimmer of hope for Middle East peace despite today's explosion in the Israeli capital

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Derek Brown sees a glimmer of hope for Middle East peace despite today's explosion in the Israeli capital.
fields.body:
An explosion ripped through a Tel Aviv bus yesterday, wounding at least 11 people and sending new tremors of alarm through the region.

The blast was relatively small, but it inevitably revived dreadful memories of the wave of suicide bomb attacks on Israeli buses in the spring of 1996.

There has as yet been no claim of responsibility, but suspicion clearly centres on Islamist militant groups which have vowed to sabotage the crumbling peace process.

Even before today's Tel Aviv blast, tension was running high in Israel and the Palestinian territories as leaders backed away from a key US-brokered summit meeting in Egypt.

The summit was abruptly cancelled after Israel apparently decided that it was not worth attending. The Palestinians had earlier signalled their strong objections to US draft proposals for a final settlement - proposals which the Israelis had accepted in principle, but with serious reservations of their own.

On the face of it, President Bill Clinton's last desperate attempt to secure a peace deal before he leaves the White House on January 20 has comprehensively foundered.

Yet in the byzantine world of Middle East diplomacy, nothing is ever that certain.

The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, has flown to Cairo for talks with the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, who longs to host a successful peace summit.

The political survival of the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, depends on a deal, and he has not ruled out a meeting with Mr Arafat.

And President Clinton, still seeking the holy grail of a final settlement, says he believes the two sides are "closer than they have ever been before".

Both the Israeli and Palestinian leaders know that the US proposals are the best - maybe the last - chance they have of rounding off the peace process which began in 1993.

But both also know that a deal on Washington's terms would be wildly unpopular with their own peoples.

For Israel, it would mean the creation of a full-fledged Palestinian state on their doorstep, the forced evacuation of thousands of Jewish settlers from the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, and, most dramatically, a Palestinian presence in Jerusalem.

The proposal which has most inflamed militant Zionists and Jewish zealots is that Israel should hand over sovereignty to the Palestinians over most of al-Haram as-Sharif, the mosque complex which is Islam's third most sacred place, but which is also the most holy site in Judaism.

Jews call it the Temple Mount, and although they would retain the part which is most important to them, the Western or Wailing Wall, the loss of the rest of the site is simply unthinkable to many Israelis.

Equally unthinkable to Palestinians is the American proposal that they drop their demand for up to 4m refugees to be allowed back to their homes in Israel and the occupied territories.

The refugees' right of return is embedded in modern Palestinian lore. Most of the refugee families, scattered in mostly squalid camps throughout the region, still possess title deeds and even keys to homes long since occupied or demolished by Israelis. Their continued exile, more than 50 years after the creation of Israel, is the most potent symbol of Palestinian humiliation.

These issues are central to the peace process. Only by constantly putting off discussion of them, has that process managed to limp along for seven frustrating and often bloody years.

Now there are fears that Clinton's imminent departure from office will remove the last element of momentum from the interminable negotiations.

Another body-blow could be struck if, as widely predicted, Mr Barak loses the prime ministerial direct election on February 6 to his rabidly rightwing rival Ariel Sharon.

With nerves scraped raw by political uncertainty, the only ray of light in recent days has been a sharp diminution of the Palestinian "intifada", or uprising, which has claimed more than 350 lives in three months.

But even as the daily confrontations subside in scale and ferocity, the Tel Aviv bus bombing is a reminder of the dark forces which are hellbent on a final, violent, solution.

webTitle: Alarm as drug company chief joins watchdog

fields.headline: Alarm as drug company chief joins watchdog
fields.trailText: A top executive at one of the world's leading pharmaceutical companies is to become director of drugs licensing at the medicines control agency.
fields.body:
A top executive at one of the world's leading pharmaceutical companies is to become director of drugs licensing at the medicines control agency, raising questions about the independence of the MCA from the industry that it is supposed to police.

Ian Hudson will take up his new job in February. He has worked in the drugs industry for the past 11 years and until recently was director and vice- president of Worldwide Clinical Safety, at SmithKline Beecham, and was to have led the worldwide drug safety group after the merger of SKB with Glaxo Wellcome, which came into effect yesterday.

The MCA rebuts any suggestion that the appointment of Dr Hudson to head the drugs licensing division will reinforce the already close links between the MCA and the drugs industry.

"These very senior positions within the agency do not come along very often and it would be regarded as an exceptional opportunity to play a leading national and international role in public health through medicines regulation," said a spokeswoman. She added that the MCA had "previously attracted high-calibre candidates from industry", including its chief executive, Keith Jones. Dr Jones was formerly a director of Merck, Sharpe and Dohme Rahway in the United States.

Although the MCA claims to be moving towards greater openness, few details have been divulged about evidence given that has meant approval or otherwise for drug licences.

The agency argues that the data it sees from clinical trials are commercially sensitive and must be kept secret to assure protection from competitors to the companies developing the drugs.

The MCA makes its decisions following advice from the committee on safety of medicines, a group comprising doctors and scientists, the majority of whom have links to the drugs industry in the form of research grants, consultancies or other financial support.

All members of the CSM are asked to declare both personal interests in drug companies, such as shares or fees, and non-personal interests, such as funding for clinical trials. Any member with a personal financial interest is expected to leave the room when the CSM starts to discuss drugs connected with the company involved.

Critics say, however, that the problem runs deeper than personal interests because most of the scientists are steeped in a culture which does not tend to question the drugs industry.

Paul Flynn, MP for Newport West, considers this culture "defensive, pro-industry and anti-consumer". He says that those responsible for advising and granting licences for medicines should be wholly independent of the industry and rejects the argument that the scientists who are employed and backed by drugs companies are the best in their field.

"They tell you these people are the only ones who can do it, which is not true. There are plenty of independent people who could do it," he said.

Also his appointment sent out a message about "the priorities for the MCA".

The drugs regulatory system is facing a review within Europe which may lead to the end of separate licensing bodies for countries. Ms Mackay said she was aware that it would be a challenge to get the public/patient perspective taken on board.

webTitle: Billions lost in contracts failure

fields.headline: Billions lost in contracts failure
fields.trailText: Taxpayers miss out on windfalls after Treasury omits clawback clauses in private firms' loan deals. Patrick Wintour reports
fields.body:
The government stands to lose billions of pounds as a result of negotiating soft contracts with the private sector to build Britain's schools, hospitals and transport infrastructure.

Inquiries by the national audit office and the public accounts committee have revealed that the Treasury has failed to negotiate clawback clauses in which the taxpayer could share the extra profit if the private sector refinances loan deals.

In some cases, refinancing deals mean private sector firms, such as Group Four, are projecting to double their planned rate of return and move into profit within three years of a 25-year contract.

The oversight has led one Labour MP, Alan Williams, to describe the right to tender for private finance initiative (PFI) deals as the equivalent of Christmas.

The Treasury has now admitted to the national audit office and the public accounts committee that it had failed to negotiate clawback clauses in most of the current £17bn worth of PFI deals. Clawback clauses have not been negotiated in 69% of PFI deals, measured by their monetary value.

The Treasury financial secretary, Stephen Timms, has ruled that all future PFI deals must include a clause ensuring the private and public sector share equally in any windfall profit due to refinancing deals. He has also negotiated a clawback deal for the £100m refurbishment of the Treasury.

Private sector firms find it easy to refinance loans at cheaper interest rates and longer repayment times once the initial construction is completed to budget and the project is shown to be running smoothly. At that point the risk of the project falls sharply, making the markets more willing to lend at cheaper rates.

There is also evidence that the markets are becoming more confident about the political stability of PFI deals, so making more lenders willing to offer refinancing deals.

The national audit office has already highlighted the massively higher than expected profits which will be reaped by Group 4 and Carrilion for the first prison built and run by the private sector at Fazakerley, Liverpool.

The companies have refinanced the deal after two years, lifting their expected returns over 25 years from £17.5m to £31.6m - an 81% increase. Only £1m of the extra profit is to be paid back to the prison service.

As a result, the projected rate of return for the initial shareholders on a publicly funded project has tripled from 12.8 % to 39%.

The contractors have admitted they will be getting a 100% pay-off in two and a half years.

The public accounts committee has been told that of 105 signed PFI contracts, only 29% of them measured by value are covered by clawback arrangements. Not one of the 15 Home Office PFI contracts has clawback clauses.

Mr Williams, a senior member of the public accounts committee, said he did not object to companies making profits from PFI deals but he did object to taxpayers not getting their fair share of any unforseen windfall profits.

The Treasury says all new PFI contracts will insist on 50% clawback of excess profits.

It also claims government departments may have powers to withhold consent from refinancing, even if no clawback clause exists, if it can be shown the refinancing will alter the costs to the Treasury of early termination of the contract.

webTitle: Mutiny threat over health councils

fields.headline: Mutiny threat over health councils
fields.trailText: The government was warned last night of an impending Labour backbench mutiny against key clauses in the flagship bill to reform the NHS as it proceeds through parliament in the run-up to the general election.
fields.body:
The government was warned last night of an impending Labour backbench mutiny against key clauses in the flagship bill to reform the NHS as it proceeds through parliament in the run-up to the general election.

David Hinchliffe, Labour chairman of the Commons health select committee, said ministers risked a revolt if they did not think again about proposals to abolish community health councils.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, wants to set up a new Patient Advocacy and Liaison Service to handle complaints against hospitals and GP practices.

When he announced the plan in July it was criticised by the British Medical Association, law society and consumer groups on the grounds that the advocates would be employed by NHS trusts and might be reluctant to expose their mistakes.

He tried to answer the point in the health bill, published earlier this month, by giving the advocacy service statutory recognition and stronger financial muscle.

But in a letter to Mr Milburn last night, Mr Hinchliffe said: "What is currently being proposed will not address the genuine worries of patients and their representatives over the current complaints system or the long standing anxieties of many, like myself, over the democratic deficit in the NHS."

He added: "When the health committee looked at the handling of complaints, we suggested that independent patient advocates should be based within CHCs, significantly strengthening their role as the patients' voice ... While there are many positives in the NHS plan, I believe the alternative proposed to the current CHC system does not offer a coherent response to current anxieties over patient representation and complaints."

Mr Hinchliffe told the Guardian: "I hope the government will listen. There's a long way to go yet, but people do feel strongly and may choose to vote against the government on it."

Donna Covey, director of the Association of Community Health Councils, said the government was "riding rough-shod over the concerns of patients, professional bodies and backbenchers on this issue". She added that NHS reform in Scotland and Wales was maintaining CHCs as champions of patients' rights.

The CHCs were set up 25 years ago as independent bodies able to take up complaints on behalf of patients. They played a key role in bringing the case of the disgraced gynaecologist Rodney Ledward to light.

However, they have been a thorn in the side of successive governments, running an annual casualty watch, and highlighting long waiting times in accident and emergency departments. About 700 people work fulltime for CHCs and 5,000 act as unpaid volunteers.

webTitle: Tube cashes in on movie magic

fields.headline: Tube cashes in on movie magic
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: While London commuters may begrudge paying £3.90 for a day's travel on the underground, Hollywood directors are queuing to pay £200 an hour to turn the Tube into a film set.
fields.body:
While London commuters may begrudge paying £3.90 for a day's travel on the underground, Hollywood directors are queuing to pay £200 an hour to turn the Tube into a film set.

Last year, London Underground received over 200 filming requests and provided the backdrop for scenes from this year's hit, Billy Elliot. Previously it has been used as a location for films ranging from action blockbuster Mission Impossible to Sliding Doors, a romantic comedy starring Gwyneth Paltrow, and The Wings of the Dove, set at the beginning of last century, with Helena Bonham Carter and Linus Roache.

Now, the Tube's directors plan to further boost its movie appeal and have launched a marketing drive to entice the film industry's big names to the delights of London's subway.

London Underground has launched a glossy brochure, ranging from the grandeur of 1930s art deco stations to the futuristic Jubilee Line extension. London Underground's commercial filming facilities manager, Kate Blow, said: "We hope this new brochure will help promote London Underground as a premier film location.

"We don't make a vast amount of money from filming but at £200 an hour it is certainly a useful money spinner."

Most film-making takes place at night or at stations normally closed at weekends.

Canary Wharf station was the most popular film set last year because of its futuristic appeal.

However, the Waterloo and City line has also proved attractive because it is closed on Sundays, making it ideal for uninterrupted filming.

While London Underground has been able to accommodate most film-makers' requests such as the need to redecorate platforms, some were turned down on safety grounds or in the interests of taste. One company wanted to feature a stuntman performing somersaults over the track, but was diplomatically told that the 640 volt current made this impossible on health and safety grounds.

webTitle: Europe's centre cannot hold

fields.headline: Europe's centre cannot hold
fields.standfirst: Germany would like to think of Berlin as the new capital of Europe. John Hooper finds it severely lacking
fields.trailText: Germany would like to think of Berlin as the new capital of Europe. John Hooper finds it severely lacking.
fields.body:
Viewed from Britain, the deliberations at the European Union's latest summit in Nice must have seemed pretty arcane: a lot of haggling over how many votes each country should wield when decisions - mostly, the less important decisions - are taken by qualified majority voting.

Viewed from Germany, and particularly from Berlin, it was probably the most important meeting since the creation of the old EEC more than 40 years ago.

The outcome acknowledged, however subtly and obliquely, that reunified Germany's greater population entitles it to a "first among equals" status with respect to the other big European nations. It also cleared the way for an enlargement of the community eastwards.

As numerous commentators here have noted, in a Europe of up to 27 nations, Berlin will no longer be on the periphery. It will be at the centre. The cities on the edge of Europe will be London and Paris.

These are the factors that Germans have in mind when they talk euphorically of Berlin becoming the "new capital of Europe". They are not the only ones to believe that a sea change is gathering.

On the day after the summit ended, I had a call from CNN to ask me to take part in a programme to discuss the results. I presumed they wanted the view from Germany. No, said the producer. What they wanted was an overall view from Europe. And they felt that the place to go for it was Berlin.

There are several reasons for thinking that all this could be a bit premature. Because of its grisly recent past, Germany cannot elbow its way to the front of the pack without stirring a mixture of apprehension and sheer terror among other EU nations.

In any case, centrality does not by itself qualify a city to be the capital. What the commentators referred to earlier seem to have overlooked is that neither London nor Paris is exactly at the centre of the country of which they are capitals.

At a purely practical level, moreover, it will be decades before Berlin is ready to assume the role of a national - let alone continental - centre.

It may have an exciting night life and a vibrant cultural scene; millions of tons of steel and concrete may be being poured into giving Berlin a spectacular new business and administrative quarter along the line of the old Wall; but, take away the surface glamour, and Berlin is revealed as a city with problems. Big problems.

It has an ailing economy and serious unemployment. It has few of the infrastructure characteristics you would normally associate with a city of its size and importance. And above all, it is broke.

In a study published last month*, researchers from Deutsche Bank Research and Deutsche Grundbesitz Management estimated that, although the German economy was booming, and would grow by 3.3% this year, the capital's economy would manage less than half that figure - around 1.5% after adjustment for inflation. Underperformance, though, is the norm for Berlin.

"For many years Berlin came bottom of the economic growth league among all German states", say the authors of the report. "The last marked jump in its real GDP was in 1995. Two years of steep downturn were followed by stagnation in 1998 and another slight price-adjusted drop of 0.3% last year."

Some 166,000 jobs were lost in the city in the five years to 1999. Unemployment is currently running at almost 16%. In one district, Kreuzberg, it is 25%.

As the report notes drily, "There is not yet any real industry focus in Berlin". Frankfurt has its banking; Dusseldorf its telecommunications; Hanover its fairs. But Berlin? There are a lot of new internet start-ups and a growing number of other hi-tech enterprises. But they do not yet constitute a genuine specialisation.

On all sorts of indicators, Berlin lags. Despite the direct and indirect effects of being made the capital, office space per head of the population in Berlin, at 4.7sq m, is way below that in other big German cities. In Frankfurt, it is 14.3sq m.

Though it straddles east and west, Berlin is in no sense a transport hub. Only three per cent of passengers at the city's three airports change planes, compared with 49% in Frankfurt.

With a hotel occupancy rate of 9.5m room nights, Berlin is only fractionally more visited than Madrid. The corresponding figures for London and Paris are 65m and 28m.

The roots of the city's problems lie in its cold war division. As an island within communist East Germany, West Berlin received generous subsidies to achieve a standard of living comparable with that of the rest of the country to which it then belonged.

After reunification, those subsidies were cut drastically - at just the moment the city hall most needed money to fund infrastructure development in the newly absorbed east. The council's debts soared. It now owes 33.5bn euros.

The authors of the report conclude that "There is little political scope [for reducing the debt] in the years ahead". But they do see one glimmer of hope. Among the many distortions introduced by Berlin's cold war division was the separation of the city from its hinterland, the region of Brandenburg, into which Berliners have been migrating in search of a better, "greener" life, ever since the division ended.

If the two entities were to merge, it would do away with a huge amount of duplication. The report points to scope for "common municipal and regional planning, economic promotion, joint tourism marketing and infrastructure projects".

A failed attempt to fuse the city with the region was made in 1996 and there is growing pressure for another try. There is just one snag, which the authors of the report do not mention. As so often in Germany, it is one that arises from the past.

The proposed merger would recreate the core of old Prussia - an entity whose rampant militarism evokes almost as many unpleasant memories in the rest of Europe as does Hitler's third reich.

Reuniting Berlin with Brandenburg is not just a question of local administrative expediency, but an infinitely sensitive political and diplomatic issue - and never more so than in the wake of a summit at which German primacy in Europe was acknowledged for the first time since 1945.

webTitle: Obituary: Stephen Mitchell

fields.headline: Obituary: Stephen Mitchell
fields.standfirst: His journal enabled analysts to start a new dialogue
fields.trailText: The unexpected death of the North American psychoanalyst Stephen Mitchell at the age of 54 has stunned colleagues and friends all over the psychoanalytic world. His contribution over the last two decades has been absolutely crucial in reformulating the psychoanalytic project to meet the intellectual and emotional demands upon it a century after its birth.
fields.body:
The unexpected death of the North American psychoanalyst Stephen Mitchell at the age of 54 has stunned colleagues and friends all over the psychoanalytic world. His contribution over the last two decades has been absolutely crucial in reformulating the psychoanalytic project to meet the intellectual and emotional demands upon it a century after its birth.

In 1983, Mitchell published the first of many books which bore the hallmark of his intellectual approach. With Jay Greenberg, he wrote Object Relations in Psychoanalytic Theory, in which they brought both a generosity and a rigour to the work of other theorists whose various attempts to understand the structures of the inner world had resulted in a profusion of concepts that looked similar, even sounded similar, but often meant very different things in theory and in practice.

Mitchell and Greenberg looked for the links, the strengths, the arguments that the psychoanalysts themselves were trying to make about their theories, often setting them out better than they had themselves, in order to draw a historical and philosophical picture of the mental world individuals create within themselves to handle distress and conflict. They argued that there were two dominant tendencies within the field, a drive model in which the mind is prestructured to use relationships with parents and others as a source of drive gratification, and the relational model in which it is the actual interaction with others that creates the structures of the mind.

In Relational Concepts in Psychoanalysis (1988), Mitchell proposed a paradigm shift within psychoanalysis, elegantly and persuasively arguing for the insistence on relationship as the determining feature in human psychological life. Without sacrificing Freud's great contributions to our notions of the unconscious, of the role of conflict, of sexuality, and of infancy, Mitchell determinedly and persuasively insisted that the complexity and subtlety of human relations are best understood within the individual's inevitable struggle both to connect with others and yet be autonomous. He understood that individuality and uniqueness comes out of and is expressed in relationship; that the concept of individuals coming together to form a society is a nonsense, for the individual emerges out of human relatedeness and is always embedded within it.

Drawing on the work of the Scottish analyst, WRD Fairbairn, he addressed the problem of human agency, the individual not simply as a tabula rasa, but as a figure whose idiosyncratic and deeply personal responses and reactions within the relational matrix are an expression of her or his unique will.

He saw the complexity of defence structures both as they were expressed in the patients he saw and supervised, and through the relational demands that were thrown up within the analytical relationship. He helped a whole generation of analysts recognise that one of the critical dilemmas of treatment, those moments when the analyst privately experiences her- or himself as embroiled with the patient's inner world, were the inevitable consequence of addressing relational theory in the consulting room. For Mitchell and the group working around him, the analyst moved from being an external, evaluating, neutral observer of the patient's distress to being a co-participant in the dramas and struggles of the patient to develop.

The patient needed not just to be witnessed, heard and interpreted by the analyst as a transference figure, but also needed recognition and a palpable emotional relationship in which the analyst was unafraid to become entangled by the very issues that perplexed the patient.

More books followed, including Freud and Beyond with his wife Margaret Black (1995), and a new book, The Degradation of Romance (to be published in 2001), addressed to a more popular audience.

Born in New York, Mitchell graduated from Yale with philosophy as his main subject, and took a doctoral degree in clinical psychology from New York University (NYU) in 1972. In 1977, he completed his psychoanalytic training at the William Alanson White Institute. At NYU he became an adjunct professor and clinical supervisor of postdoctoral studies in psychotherapy and psychoanalysis, and at the White Institute he was a training analyst.

While his lucidly written books had a wide readership, most psychoanalysts know Mitchell through the innovative scholarly journal Psychoanalytic Dialogues (PD), which he founded in 1991. Each new issue was the most avidly awaited journal of the field: the articles were well written, with thoughtfulness and originality encouraged; they often addressed the leading edge of clinical practice, so that the preoccupations of practising analysts - their subjectivity, their erotic countertransference, issues of dependency - could be rigorously questioned from fresh perspectives; part of each issue was organised as a dialogue in which leading thinkers would engage with one another over critical issues in theory and practice; and there was the sense that PD represented a community of analysts hard at work, in dialogue to create new understandings and to push their field forward. The excitement that came off the pages was palpable.

The element of dialogue was particularly apt: although avowedly relational, Mitchell invited analysts of other persuasions who had things to say to think through their arguments on the pages of PD, and allow themselves to influence and be influenced by the positions of colleagues from another idiom. This allowed psychoanalysts, so good at listening to others and so often inadequate at listening to one another, to really take on and hear the strengths in each other's positions and the historical and philosophical basis of those positions. The work of theory-making, in relation both to theory about practice and theories of development and change, thus reflected Mitchell's intellectual commitment, purpose and passion for dialogue, listening and learning.

The energy generated by the journal encouraged Mitchell and others to start an even more participatory organisation, the International Association for Relational Psychoanalysis, of which he was to be the first president. For those of us 3,000 miles away from the New York scene, this was a welcome way in which to participate in developments in relational practice.

Stephen's loss is incalculable. Those who spoke to the thousand and more people at his funeral said that his loss will be as large as the space that he occupied. All of us who have been touched by his intellectual acuity and generosity echo that sentiment.

Stephen Mitchell is survived by his wife, and their daughters Caitlin and Samantha.

webTitle: Peckham strives to discover a new image

fields.headline: Peckham strives to discover a new image
fields.standfirst: One month after the stabbing of Damilola Taylor, local youngsters are being encouraged to build up self esteem peacefully
fields.trailText: One month after the stabbing of Damilola Taylor, local youngsters are being encouraged to build up self esteem peacefully
fields.body:
The boys are breathing deeply, learning to control their anger. After this half hour of meditation they will move on to martial arts or maybe a bit of sparring, or they might talk a little about positive role models or perhaps racism.

It is Saturday morning in Peckham Pulse, the recently-built "healthy living" centre for this south London community, and these boys are members of From Boyhood to Manhood, a project that aims to help young black boys work out their identity.

While their friends are mucking around writing their tags (nicknames) on walls, these boys have dropped their monikers - tags like Smarter, Spark and Chaos - and embraced a project that tries to help them build self esteem.

The scene is a neat parallel for Peckham, a troubled urban area that is also trying to reclaim its identity.

Before the death of Damilola Taylor one month ago, this area of south-east London - the name Peckham is derived from the Anglo-Saxon for "village among the hills" - was trying to get a grip on itself. It had begun to tackle housing, education, and employment in a radical way. The regeneration was having some success.

Now, though, the national image is of Peckham as a desolate estate and the focus has been on troublesome gangs. When Nissan used the slogan "Built to tackle the most inhospitable places on earth. Including Peckham," to advertise its cars, it was bad enough. But now the area is the focus of the nation's sympathy as well as the butt of its jokes.

As one 15-year-old boy explained: "They portray Peckham to be a really, really bad place. I have lived in Peckham all my life and I don't think it's a bad place. Young boys don't die every day here and that's the image they try to portray. Gangs exist everywhere but they are making out these Peckham gangs are a brand new revelation."

Damilola's death is hanging over Peckham. The aftermath is everywhere - in the books of remembrance in the library and in other public places, in the piles of faded flowers lying at the 10-year-old's school, and in the stairway where he collapsed after he had been stabbed.

There are now more police on the High Street and in Rye Lane than ever before, and there are notices appealing for witnesses to the murder. On the piazza by the library where the CCTV camera caught Damilola's last moments as he went tripping and jumping along, an older girl is teasing a younger boy, warning him "You know what happened to Damilola." People are fighting to beat exclusion and fragmentation here - factors so clearly manifest in a place where 25% of the people have an income of less than £100 a week and where 52% of those in employment earn less than £150.

Uanu Seshmi runs the From Boyhood to Manhood project, taking in children excluded from school or on the verge of it, young offenders and "good" boys, too. He says: "The majority of boys who come to us have anger management problems. They have frustration, loss of self esteem. They are alienated, they don't under stand where they belong in terms of society. Some of them are in gangs but lots of boys don't want to get involved and want a way out of gangs.

"The majority of young black boys will be very lucky to come from a background where their parents help to clarify issues about who they are as a black person. They are confused. They are in a real muddle in terms of their father, who is either not there, or confused or contradictory. We clarify issues about their responsibilities as a man."

Mr Seshmi is a volunteer and, because of lack of space and resources, his project can take only a small number of boys. He says he will have to give up if he does not get proper funding.

Decima Francis, who runs SASS, a project for the youth of Peckham, springs to defend the area. She returned from the US to live here because she missed it, and also feels there is not enough going for the local community.

She said: "It's a new area now, more or less because we have got new buildings and we have got new people in the area. It's a community of transition. Our work is to help people settle in and get used to the area. But what isn't here is a theatre, a performing arts base. There isn't a civic centre, there's nowhere for people to congregate or get married or have church events."

Her concerns are reflected in the niggles felt across the five housing estates that are part of the Peckham Partnership's £260m, seven-year single regeneration scheme, which is the biggest in the country and involves the largest shift and resettlement of people in Europe. Its aim is to "make Peckham a place where people choose to live, work and visit".

Hordle Promenade, the flats where Damilola died and other blocks, such as St Briavel's Court where he lived, are being pulled down.

But many people find their new, smarter accommodation is not without its problems: they say the walls are so thin they get no privacy, and the rooms are smaller, so much so that you can't always get the furniture through the doors. "It's still on the cheap, unfortunately," said one local resident. Recently, a tenants' group passed a vote of no-confidence in the Peckham Partnership management.

Mike Rahman, development manager for Peckham Partnership's tenants' and residents forum, said: "People still haven't got jobs and health has not improved."

However, the partnership has achieved some success. There's Peckham Arch and Peckham Pulse, and also the award-winning library designed by Alsop & Stormer and the attempt to create a town square around it. Crime has been reduced; three years ago Southwark had the highest crime rate in London but now it is in joint ninth place. The partnership has spent £2m on community safety, spending £300,000 on CCTV.

Krystina Stimakovits, the coordinator of Peckham voluntary sector forum, has just submitted an application for lottery funding on behalf of 25 groups. "It's been a very mixed picture in Peckham," she said. "There have been a lot of successes, but there's a lot of frustration because a lot of things that could have happened, didn't. Halls are disappearing, and there had been a lot of support for a multi-purpose community centre - African communities have a lot of social events. But the church halls get booked up over weekends."

Regeneration was meant to be holistic, but very little has been reflecting the community's needs, she said. There had been many lost opportunities. "Space is always the key problem. There's a lot of positive energy about and will to do things, but I think it's a struggle to get resources. The people who are good at communicating with youngsters are not necessarily the ones who write good funding applications or reports. It all boils down to listening to what the community is saying."

After the terrible events of a month ago, it is just possible that Southwark council, Peckham Partnership and others will now be listening more carefully to the community's voice. Somehow, if slowly, Peckham might just get to be "a place where people choose to live, work and visit".

webTitle: Poster's lesbian embrace breaks advertising taboo

fields.headline: Poster's lesbian embrace breaks advertising taboo
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Another of the big taboos in the advertising world is broken today with the launch of the first overt lesbian poster campaign in a move that many in the gay community hope will finally bring gay imagery into the mainstream.
fields.body:
Another of the big taboos in the advertising world is broken today with the launch of the first overt lesbian poster campaign in a move that many in the gay community hope will finally bring gay imagery into the mainstream.

The poster, advertising the gay internet business Queercompany and featuring two scantily clad women locked in an embrace next to the legend "Thank God for Women," went on display early today on one of the UK's largest billboards at Centrepoint in Charing Cross Road, central London.

The poster is due to stay up until the end of January, and will also be seen on other sites around London and in Underground stations, together with another showing two men posing provocatively next to the words "Thank God For Men." Although advertisers have alluded to gay relationships in the past, the Queercompany poster is believed to be the first to picture a gay couple in an embrace.

Wanda Goldwag, managing director of Queercompany, said yesterday that they were not trying to shock. "We are trying to attract upmarket lesbians and gays," she said. "They are striking ads that will appeal to that community without offending others. We have certainly not done it to cause some sort of stir."

However the Advertising Standards Authority, which recently ordered the removal of a poster of model Sophie Dahl wearing only jewellery and high heeled shoes, said they would be "monitoring" the situation. Any decision that the advert caused offence would take into account the target audience "and who is seeing the ad", a spokeswoman said.

Earlier this month the authority rejected a complaint against Queercompany advertisements that appeared in the national press showing two men hugging under the headline "I'm Queer. And by the way this is not an apology" and two women holding hands, next to the words "No White Wedding. Sorry Mum."

Peter Tatchell of OutRage!, the gay rights group, said: "It is a breakthrough to have gay images in such high profile sites, but the real breakthrough would be for a mainstream company to use similar images to promote their products to consumers in general."

Queercompany, which aims to become the leading website for gays and lesbians with editorial content and services from travel to finance, was founded earlier this year by Ms Morrison and Dominic Richards, an adviser to the Prince of Wales on architectural matters and a trustee of the Prince's Trust. He is also chair of the Lesbian and Gay Christian Movement.

The posters were created by Anti-Corp, the maverick Hackney based ad agency who won the £1m account after the gay web portal decided its previous ad agency was not coming up with provocative enough material.

webTitle: Bush adviser talks tough on Colombia

fields.headline: Bush adviser talks tough on Colombia
fields.standfirst: Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: George W Bush's incoming administration is preparing for a more aggressive onslaught on guerrillas and drug traffickers in Colombia, a confidential speech by a senior adviser reveals.
fields.body:
George W Bush's incoming administration is preparing for a more aggressive onslaught on guerrillas and drug traffickers in Colombia, a confidential speech by a senior adviser reveals.

Robert Zoellick, who is to be appointed to an international policy post in the Republican administration - possibly chief trade representative - said: "If the Colombian people are willing to fight for their own country, then the US should offer serious, sustained and timely financial, material and intelligence support."

His speech, which was delivered to the Council on Foreign Relations a week before the November 7 presidential election, suggests a big shift in Washington's policy on Colombia, just as President Andres Pastrana appears to be on the verge of making peace with the country's second-biggest leftwing rebel force, the National Liberation Army (ELN).

The Clinton administration's tried to stay out of the 36-year civil war while giving multimillion-dollar aid packages intended for action against drugs.

Rightwing critics such as Mr Zoellick say that policy is soft on leftwing guerrilla movements such as the ELN and the larger Farc.

"We cannot continue to make a false distinction between counter-insurgency and counter-narcotics efforts," Mr Zoellick said. "The narco-traffickers and guerrillas compose one dangerous network."

Leftwing critics, on the other hand, say the Clinton policy gives the Colombian armed forces too much leeway to divert US aid to rightwing death squads waging a largely unchecked war against the guerrillas.

Death squads have carried out three-quarters of the 4,000 annual political killings.

One critic, Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota, said this week that the Clinton administration's refusal to attach human rights guarantees and conditions to Washington's latest $1.3bn (£870m) aid package to Colombia "sent a terrible signal".

When the issue comes up for review next month, Mr Wellstone says, no aid should be given until all human rights terms are met.

But Mr Zoellick's tough speech suggests such that an effort is doomed.

It ignored human rights conditions, and called on the "forces of democracy" to combat "new threats to security" in Colombia.

Such a policy appears to align the new administration with the Colombian military and the death squads against Mr Pastrana and the left.

The prospect of a change in US policy could hardly come at a more delicate time in Colombia's long-running crisis, which has claimed more than 35,000 lives in the past 10 years and creates 300,000 refugees each year.

Thousands of Colombians have also been kidnapped, by both sides.

Last weekend the ELN freed 42 police officers and soldiers, a Christmas gesture which appeared to crown Cuban-brokered talks between Bogota and the ELN aimed at establishing a demilitarised enclave run by the ELN in Bolivar region in the north.

If it is finally agreed, the land-for-peace deal with the 5,000-strong ELN will be similar to a pact two years ago between Mr Pastrana and the Farc.

That deal was criticised because of the continuing claim of human rights abuses by Farc and because the armed forces have never accepted the deal's legitimacy.

That has led Bogota to press for tougher terms in any agreement with the ELN. Residents of Bolivar are demanding such conditions, because they fear a demilitarised zone could lead to increased violence.

The land-for-peace deals with the guerrillas are intended to be a prelude to full-scale peace talks. The deal with Farc laid down two years of peace talks which have not so far led to any hoped-for agreement.

The Farc has until January 31 to return to talks or see the military allowed back into the demilitarised zone.

fields.bodyText: George W Bush's incoming administration is preparing for a more aggressive onslaught on guerrillas and drug traffickers in Colombia, a confidential speech by a senior adviser reveals. Robert Zoellick, who is to be appointed to an international policy post in the Republican administration - possibly chief trade representative - said: "If the Colombian people are willing to fight for their own country, then the US should offer serious, sustained and timely financial, material and intelligence support." His speech, which was delivered to the Council on Foreign Relations a week before the November 7 presidential election, suggests a big shift in Washington's policy on Colombia, just as President Andres Pastrana appears to be on the verge of making peace with the country's second-biggest leftwing rebel force, the National Liberation Army (ELN). The Clinton administration's tried to stay out of the 36-year civil war while giving multimillion-dollar aid packages intended for action against drugs. Rightwing critics such as Mr Zoellick say that policy is soft on leftwing guerrilla movements such as the ELN and the larger Farc. "We cannot continue to make a false distinction between counter-insurgency and counter-narcotics efforts," Mr Zoellick said. "The narco-traffickers and guerrillas compose one dangerous network." Leftwing critics, on the other hand, say the Clinton policy gives the Colombian armed forces too much leeway to divert US aid to rightwing death squads waging a largely unchecked war against the guerrillas. Death squads have carried out three-quarters of the 4,000 annual political killings. One critic, Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota, said this week that the Clinton administration's refusal to attach human rights guarantees and conditions to Washington's latest $1.3bn (£870m) aid package to Colombia "sent a terrible signal". When the issue comes up for review next month, Mr Wellstone says, no aid should be given until all human rights terms are met. But Mr Zoellick's tough speech suggests such that an effort is doomed. It ignored human rights conditions, and called on the "forces of democracy" to combat "new threats to security" in Colombia. Such a policy appears to align the new administration with the Colombian military and the death squads against Mr Pastrana and the left. Thousands of Colombians have also been kidnapped, by both sides. Last weekend the ELN freed 42 police officers and soldiers, a Christmas gesture which appeared to crown Cuban-brokered talks between Bogota and the ELN aimed at establishing a demilitarised enclave run by the ELN in Bolivar region in the north. webTitle: Shell cuts price of unleaded by 4p a litre

fields.headline: Shell cuts price of unleaded by 4p a litre
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Shell last night started cutting the price of unleaded fuel at its motorway service and trunk road petrol stations from 83.9p to 79.9p per litre.
fields.body:
Shell last night started cutting the price of unleaded fuel at its motorway service and trunk road petrol stations from 83.9p to 79.9p per litre.

Shell said the cut reflected the lower price of crude oil, which has been falling since November as supplies from the Middle East have picked up.

Super unleaded will be reduced from 89.9p to 86.9p, lead replacement petrol will be cut from 89.9p to 85.9p and diesel from 86.9p to 84.9p.

Shell said it was restricting its cuts to 250 of its 1,100 service stations because at other sites local competition meant unleaded petrol was already around the 79.9p mark.

BP Amoco indicated it could follow Shell's lead, although it had no plans yet to cut its prices. A spokesman said the group intended to remain competitive. "If the market is moving downwards, then no doubt we will too," he said.

This month, Shell became the first big oil company to join the leading supermarkets in a price-slashing exercise as falls in the price of crude oil began to filter through to the pumps.

In September lorry drivers held a nationwide protest at high diesel prices. A second protest in November, however, failed to capture the public imagination.
