webTitle: Top judge attacks prison 'cancer'

fields.headline: Top judge attacks prison 'cancer'
fields.standfirst:
Lord Chief Justice sparks row over merits of fighting crime by jailing more offenders

Policing crime
Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: Lord Chief Justice sparks row over merits of fighting crime by jailing more offenders.
fields.body:
The Lord Chief Justice yesterday said that fewer convicted criminals should be sent to jail and that politicians should stop promising to lock more people up as a way of battling crime.

The intervention in the heated law and order debate by Lord Woolf, the top criminal judge in England and Wales, set him on a collision course with William Hague.

The Tory leader reacted by saying that under his party, more people may be jailed as a way of cutting crime.

Home office minister Mike O'Brien said Lord Woolf had "slightly missed the point" and that the effectiveness of anti-crime policy should not be judged by the numbers of people in jail.

In an interview, Lord Woolf said prison numbers, which are forecast to hit record numbers, were swollen by people who did not need to be behind bars. He called for more use of community sentences and described prison overcrowding as a "cancer" which hampered the rehabilitation of serious offenders.

Large rise

Lord Woolf said: "If a person has committed a serious crime, I am strongly in favour of the person receiving serious punishment. What I am equally in favour of is when he goes to prison to receive that serious punishment, the system works as well as is possible, having regard to all the constraints of resources, to ensure that when he comes out of prison he is less likely to offend again and not more likely to offend."

The "prison works" doctrine espoused by the former Tory home secretary, Michael Howard, saw a large rise in the numbers behind bars. The Home Office predicts that the prison population will hit an all-time high of 68,300 by March 2002, from its current level of 62,229.

Lord Woolf continued: "Overcrowding of prisons is a cancer which undermines the work of the prisons and the problem is we have people there because of the system who should not be there, who contribute to overcrowding.

"What we have to do is to achieve a situation where our punishments in the community are ones which the public find more acceptable than they do at the present, because many things can be done so far as offenders are concerned without sending them to prison which actually provide better safeguards for the public."

Lord Woolf likened tough talk from politicians on jailing more people to the "race card" and told the BBC: "On the whole the politicians are very good about race, they don't approve of playing what is called the race card. I wish that they also took the same view with regard to the prison card. I'm afraid they don't.

"They do see prison as something which the public feels is an important safeguard and so they will be in favour of the rhetoric that they use of more and more prison, but that actually is not necessarily in the interests of the public."

Tory leader William Hague has identified voters' concern about crime as a way of eating into Labour's opinion poll lead. Mr Hague said: "I think that it may be necessary to have more people in prison, in order to deal with the law and order situation in this country."

Shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe told the Guardian that Tory plans would see no more than "a couple of thousand" added to prison numbers. She said the private finance initiative could be used to fund extra prison places so that any rise did not exacerbate overcrowding.

The prison population's peak (66,500) was reached under Labour in June 1998. In 1993 it was 44,246. Privately, the government is not worried by criticism from liberals over rising prisoner numbers, which are already some of the highest in the developed world.

Mr O'Brien attacked Mr Hague's policy and appeared to criticise Lord Woolf's intervention: "In a sense he has slightly missed the point."

Mr O'Brien continued: "He's got it back to front. It's not about the numbers, increasing or decreasing the numbers, its about locking up those who deserve to be there and having the capacity to do so."

Both main parties believe that concern over crime, which has fallen by 10% since Labour took office, requires them to pay greater heed to talking tough rather than taking note of concerns from reformers.

Mr O'Brien told the Guardian: "I've never had a constituent ask me to put less people in prison, unless it's one of their relatives."

Flawed

Those expressing concerns over the effectiveness of incarceration were supported by Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman Simon Hughes, who said: "Given that half of all people released from prison reoffend within two years, the argument that prison is an effective deterrent is flawed."

Norman Brennan, director of the Victims of Crime Trust, accused Lord Woolf of "joining the liberal brigade".

He said weak sentences passed by judges were partly to blame for high crime rates. "The reason there are many criminals in prison is that judges give out weak sentences that do not act as a deterrent. Many persistent offenders know that, if caught, they will receive a short sentence and see it as no more than a respite, an occupational hazard."

The Prison Reform Trust said the public should be more confident in community penalties and prison must be kept as a last resort. Its director, Juliet Lyon, said: "A crowded prison cannot be effective, just or humane."

Lord Woolf is no stranger to controversy. In October, he ruled that the continued detention of the killers of the toddler James Bulger would not serve any constructive purpose and that their release would be determined by a three-member panel comprising a judge, psychiatrist and lay member.

webTitle: Middle East talks founder

fields.headline: Middle East talks founder
fields.standfirst:
Arafat to meet Egyptian president without Barak
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Hopes of a Middle East settlement received a grave setback early today when a planned summit between the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, and the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, was suddenly cancelled.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill  and  Virginia Quirke in Jerusalem
fields.body:
Hopes of a Middle East settlement received a grave setback early today when a planned summit between the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, and the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, was suddenly cancelled.

It would have been the first face-to-face meeting between the two men since October in the early days of the Palestinian uprising that has cost more than 350 lives.

The Israelis pulled out of the summit after the Palestinians expressed deep reservations about US proposals that would have formed the basis for a settlement. Although, the Israeli cabinet secretary, Isaac Herzog, said a final decision would be made later today.

Israel said it conditionally accepted US President Bill Clinton's plan after the security cabinet wrapped up a three-hour meeting early this morning. "Israel sees these ideas as a basis for discussion provided that they remain unchanged as a basis for discussion also by the Palestinian side," Mr Barak's office said.

"Israel will request several clarifications from the United States on issues that are related to Israel's vital interests," it said. Ten cabinet ministers voted in favour of the plan, two against , while two abstained.

The cancellation is a serious blow to the hopes of Mr Clinton - who had expressed optimism that the two sides "are closer than they have ever been before" - of achieving a major diplomatic success before leaving office on January 20. The other deadline is February 6 when Mr Barak faces an election. His main opponent has threatened to reject the plan.

The summit was to have been hosted by the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, at the Egyptian resort of Sharm el-Sheikh. But the Egyptian information ministry an nounced early this morning that Mr Barak would not arrive , but that Mr Arafat would fly to Cairo to meet with Mr Mubarak.

Mr Barak's reluctance to attend the summit came hours after the Palestinians had issued statements expressing their unhappiness at Mr Clinton's proposals.

Yasser Abed Rabbo, one of the Palestinian negotiators, said: "The offer we have is not an opportunity but a trap. It is very far from the principles of the peace process and the principles of negotiation."

After attending prayers to mark the start of the three-day Muslim holiday of Eid al-Fitr yesterday, Mr Arafat said the Palestinians were still discussing Mr Clinton's proposals.

"God willing, it will represent a strong start in which a Palestinian boy or girl will raise the flag of Palestine over the walls, minarets and churches of Jerusalem."

But Mr Arafat is under huge pressure at home and from other Arab states not to concede on the key issues, primarily the fate of an estimated 3.5m Palestinian refugees. Israel fears the consequences if these refugees were to return from camps in Lebanon, Jordan, Egypt, Syria, Gaza and the West Bank.

Saeb Erekat, the chief Palestinian negotiator, ruled out any concessions on the right of return. He said the Palestinians stood by UN resolutions supporting the right of the refugees to return to the homes they left, or were forced to leave from, in 1948.

After a meeting yesterday of Palestinian legislators, a letter was sent to Washington in which "the Palestinian leadership said it cannot accept these American ideas as a basis for a settlement of the Palestinian-Israeli conflict".

Although definitive versions of the proposals have still to be made public, it is understood that Israel has agreed that Palestinians can have control over Arab east Jerusalem and more of the West Bank.

The Israelis have offered a compromise on the contentious holy site, known to Jews as the Temple Mount and Muslims as Haram al-Sharif: the Palestinians to have sovereignty over the top of the site and the Israelis to control the area underneath, including the Wailing Wall. In an opinion poll in yesterday's Jerusalem Post, 52% opposed a peace plan compared with 38% in favour.

webTitle: Dissenters

fields.headline: Dissenters
fields.trailText: Tolerance in British society actually owes far more to the dissenting tradition than it does to the C of E.
fields.body:
It is all very well for Michael Scott-Joynt (A defender of the only faith, December 27) to claim that "tolerance... owes a great deal to the Church of England", but I belong to a tradition (Baptist) that was persecuted by the state (hand-in-glove with Church of England) until the end of the 17th century and was looked down on with disapproval by the same Church of England for long after that. Tolerance in British society actually owes far more to the dissenting tradition than it does to the C of E.

Philip Clements-Jewery, Basildon, Essex

Tom Lewis (Letters, December 27) is mistaken to claim that Henry VIII "went after the Catholics" and to describe Catholics as a "minority". Henry VIII may have ruthlessly annexed church property and authority in England, but he regarded himself as a Catholic until he died and vigorously persecuted protestant "heresy". And Catholics were certainly still in the majority at the end of his reign and quite possibly into that of his Anglican daughter Elizabeth, never mind that of his Catholic daughter Mary. He would have been with Lewis on the killing of animals for sport, though. He just wouldn't have described it as "culture".

Stephen Brasher, London

Supporters of field sports are not the largest minority to have their culture abused in the last 400 years; that would be the racists and the homophobes. Like the pro-hunting lobby, they are in the wrong.

Colin Beveridge, St Andrews, Fife

webTitle: Equality in US universities

fields.headline: Degrees of separation
fields.standfirst:
Why do women outnumber men in US universities? Sharon Krum reports.

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Why do women outnumber men in US universities?  Sharon Krum reports
fields.body:
If it were possible to take the blood pressure of every American high schooler today, they would record numbers guaranteed to keep every ambulance in the country in overdrive. Think Richter scale. Think heart failure on a grand scale. Today is the day SAT (Scholastic Aptitude Tests) results are mailed out to thousands of desperate Harvard, Yale, Anytown USA University hopefuls. The SATs determine which university will come courting (race, sports prowess and parent alumni can also help) and any teen will tell you that the right university on your cv can set you up for life.

What the hopeful high schoolers may not know, but the universities do, is that this year, again, most of those SAT scores will be sent out to women. More women will apply for bachelors degree places, then graduate, tipping over the applecart that for decades has been pushed by males. According to the National Association for College Admission Counselling, universities now enrol more women (55%) than men (45%, down from 81% in 1900). The US Department of Education says that by 2007, there will be 9m women and 6.9m men in college in the US.

Feminists, naturally, are thrilled. They see the statistics as a victory for the women's movement and affirmative action, and laugh at the view held by some that the gender shift signals a crisis. "Nobody was worried when there were too many men in universities and women had to bang down the door to get in," says Pamela Haag, director of research at the Association of American University Women. "Now it's a problem?"

Thomas Mortensen, of the Center for the Study of Opportunity in Higher Education, has been analysing the trend for 10 years. He sees the gender disparity as a major concern - and one for which feminists must take some blame. "They have raised a generation of daughters to value education, not to assume men will support them, and that's good. But there is a militant strain, fermenting since the 70s, that has an effect."

But while Mortensen believes "all this political correctness, these sexual harassment suits" have scared men away, he adds that today's flush economy is also a factor. "When a high school diploma will get you a good job in the computer industry, why pursue university?"

Of course, for women, a high school diploma still gets them pretty much nowhere. That is why, he says, they are more motivated to study and improve their prospects. But he sees something else going on, too: a disengagement from family life. "Women are self-supporting. Divorce is prevalent. Many men do not feel responsible for families any more, so they are not motivated to get a better education to provide for them."

Then there is the issue of role models. For 30 years, mothers have encouraged girls to have their own careers, earn their own money. On the other hand, the number of boys raised in single parent homes has rocketed: "And if they don't see men who have benefited from higher education, they may not pursue it."

Not everyone accepts Mortensen's views. The American Council on Education denies a general crisis, saying it affects only men who are African-American, Hispanic and from low-income families. Haag points out that while women dominate in obtaining bachelors degrees, "they still lag behind in degrees that lead to higher-paying jobs in engineering and IT".

To address the issue, Mortensen says disapprovingly, universities are considering affirmative action - for men. "You are treating the symptoms, not the cause. If you have a double standard to let in a dumb guy over a better-qualified woman, it's a slap in the face for women's achievements."

The answer, he says, is for society to engage in a searching discussion about the way we raise boys - and for men to take a leaf out of the feminist handbook. "We need a movement to push boys, in the way feminism has pushed girls for all these years." And personally, he adds, he would like women to take a "chill pill" on campus to create a less threatening environment. "Feminists need to soften the rhetoric and encourage men to join them."

"When a high school diploma will get you a good job in the computer industry, why pursue university?" Of course, for women, a high school diploma still gets them pretty much nowhere. That is why, he says, they are more motivated to study and improve their prospects. But he sees something else going on, too: a disengagement from family life. "Women are self-supporting. Divorce is prevalent. Many men do not feel responsible for families any more, so they are not motivated to get a better education to provide for them." Then there is the issue of role models. For 30 years, mothers have encouraged girls to have their own careers, earn their own money. On the other hand, the number of boys raised in single parent homes has rocketed: "And if they don't see men who have benefited from higher education, they may not pursue it." Not everyone accepts Mortensen's views. The American Council on Education denies a general crisis, saying it affects only men who are African-American, Hispanic and from low-income families. Haag points out that while women dominate in obtaining bachelors degrees, "they still lag behind in degrees that lead to higher-paying jobs in engineering and IT". To address the issue, Mortensen says disapprovingly, universities are considering affirmative action - for men. "You are treating the symptoms, not the cause. If you have a double standard to let in a dumb guy over a better-qualified woman, it's a slap in the face for women's achievements." The answer, he says, is for society to engage in a searching discussion about the way we raise boys - and for men to take a leaf out of the feminist handbook. "We need a movement to push boys, in the way feminism has pushed girls for all these years." And personally, he adds, he would like women to take a "chill pill" on campus to create a less threatening environment. "Feminists need to soften the rhetoric and encourage men to join them."

webTitle: Having too much fun gives students debt problems

fields.headline: Having too much fun gives students debt problems
fields.trailText: It is quite untrue to suggest that the vast majority of those on degree courses are in serious financial difficulties (Comment, December 20).
fields.body:
It is quite untrue to suggest that the vast majority of those on degree courses are in serious financial difficulties (Comment, December 20).

Over 70% of students take up the offer of a loan - hardly surprising as they have a 0% real rate of interest. They don't have to pay it back until they are earning and even then as a reasonable proportion of their income. Compared to any commercial loan, likely to be at least 15.9% APR, this is both fair and affordable.

The loan is to help cover basic living costs. It is for students themselves to think carefully about how much extra they borrow from banks and credit card companies to cover other costs. Our survey shows that entertainment spending has risen sharply - that is the student's choice.

If you go to university, you will have greater earning power in the future - a fact that 86% of students accept. Far from turning people off university, drop-out rates are static and more people are applying than ever before. Where there is hardship we do provide extra help and from next year there will be childcare grants and opportunity bursaries of £2,000 for poorer students. In total we spend nearly twice as much on students than on those who leave school at 16. Our system of student support is fair to the taxpayer, the student and parent.

Malcolm Wicks MP, Department for Education

I graduated this year. By the time I left I owed over £8,000 to banks, credit cards and student loans. I had worked continuously through my degree, to a point in my second year where I was working longer hours than studying. The continual hand-to-mouth existence placed great strain on me and my counterparts.

We are now in the job market. We should feel proud that we survived and obtained our degrees and are at the threshold of a new life. Unfortunately our main concern is paying off those debts we accumulated whilst attempting to gain an education. Many graduates even consider not working and claiming benefits in an effort to postpone repayment of loans. Our wages are swallowed up by education and so often you hear the cry: "Was it worth it?"

R Holland, Brighton gea@geaeventi.it

Poor Gemma Cantelo - quoted as an example of student poverty (Report, December 21). She leaves university on a salary of £16,000 a year - and has not a penny over to pay off her debts. On that kind of salary she must take home £900 or £1,000 a month. She'll have to pay her rent - but if she shares a house in Cardiff she'll get change out of £300 - and the bills won't be more than £100 at most. As a senior professional I earn £28,000 a year - but it has to support two adults and two children. I suspect that if there was £600 a month over for each adult after paying the bills we could afford to make inroads into the overdrafts and credit bills.

Andrew Skinner, Cardiff askinner45@hotmail.com

webTitle: Building on nature

fields.headline: Building on nature
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee is as trenchant as ever on global warming (Stormy weather ..., December 27). Perhaps we will have to wait until the Thames barrage is breached before a parliament knee deep in water will take decisive action to curb carbon dioxide emissions. But she is less sure-footed when it comes to buildings.
fields.body:
Polly Toynbee is as trenchant as ever on global warming (Stormy weather ..., December 27). Perhaps we will have to wait until the Thames barrage is breached before a parliament knee deep in water will take decisive action to curb carbon dioxide emissions. But she is less sure-footed when it comes to buildings.

At present the cost of a photovoltaic facade to a building is substantially higher than even ultra-low-energy glazing. This was demonstrated by the only speculative solar office at Doxford international business park near Sunderland. Things are set to change with the next generation of titanium-based solar cells.

The most cost-effective way to cut building-related C02 emissions is to reduce demand. Persuading clients to make the most of natural light, heat and ventilation has been the mission of many architects since the late 80s. This produced highly energy-efficient buildings like the Addison Wesley Longman HQ (1992-93), or Bennetts Associates 1992 Powergen building in Coventry. The latest example of this firm's environmental crusade is the operations centre for Wessex Water near Bath. Its energy consumption is 70% less than the norm for offices and it has been universally acclaimed by its inhabitants.

Architects would like to do much more to persuade clients to adopt this kind of architecture. At a recent symposium, I asked the representative of the British Property Federation why there was such resistance such buildings. The answer was: "Our clients demand fully air conditioned glass boxes." Against this antediluvian attitude even architects are powerless.

Prof Peter Smith, Vice-president, sustainable development, Royal Institute of British Architects

webTitle: Sick not sub-human

fields.headline: Sick not sub-human
fields.trailText: Among the many laudable intentions of white paper on mental health is the aim "to reduce, wherever possible, the number of individuals who are subject to the use of powers for compulsory care and treatment"
fields.body:
Among the many laudable intentions of white paper on mental health - raising service quality, expanding the number of services and improving access to them - is the aim "to reduce, wherever possible, the number of individuals who are subject to the use of powers for compulsory care and treatment" ('Campus care' for psychopaths, December 21).

Unfortunately, this commitment disappeared in the media feeding frenzy created by linking a white paper on mental health to plans to deal with people who have severe personality disorder and are considered dangerous. Yet they comprise fewer than 2,000 of the 630,000 people using mental health services at any one time.

One in three people with a severe mental illness has been turned away from a service at some point. Often, the pleas of desperate people go unanswered until a crisis is reached and compulsion is used to force a hospital admission. Making quality services open and accessible could break this vicious cycle and reduce the use of compulsory powers. The white paper reforms will stand or fall by whether it helps people receive the quality care they need and which they are so often denied.

Cliff Prior, National Schizophrenia Fellowship

It has long been recognised that black and ethnic minority groups get a raw deal from the mental health system. Black people are more likely to be detained in locked wards, more likely to be given high doses of medication, and less likely to be offered appropriate services.

A welcome measure in the white paper is the recognition that people subject to compulsory treatment should have a right to an independent advocate. If black people had access to an advocate who has an understanding of their culture during the assessment period, this could help reduce the sort of misunderstandings and racist assumptions that are now all too common. However, the proposals appear to promise an advocate only after assessment has been completed. Unless these issues are addressed when the bill is published, the proposals to allow compulsory treatment in the community are likely to impact more severely on black and ethnic minority patients. No doubt I shall not be the only Labour MP making representations.

Helen Brinton MP

The government's plans for the mentally ill and those deemed to have a personality disorder are shameful. It seems that the mentally ill are not as human as "us" and their rights can be truncated accordingly. The mentally ill are sick, not sub-human, and many Guardian readers will suffer from one mental illness or another at some point in their lives. Suicide rates among this group of patients are already unacceptably high, but how many more will be driven over the edge by this government- decreed stigma. There are already many attacks by the "normal" on the ill, now some legitimisation has been offered to these acts.

Hilary Eddy, Penzance, Cornwall

Psychiatric disagnosis is not exact: you cannot diagnose a disorder as you can a broken leg. Yet people are now to be locked up on the basis of what are no more than educated guesses. Meanwhile, those patients who remain free are to be deprived of the right to decide for themselves whether their medication - which can be harmful - is suitable or necessary. It is no use talking of "safeguards". Anyone who, like me, has been through the psychiatric system, knows how difficult it is to get professional people, like doctors, to accept that their colleagues are capable of error. And the stigmatising of mental patients implicit in these proposals makes it that much more unlikely that the patient's views will be listened to.

Justin Horton, Loughborough, Leics

webTitle: Life as a widow

fields.headline: Love life after death
fields.standfirst: Elaine Kingett on what you don't hear about being a widow.
fields.trailText: Elaine Kingett on what you don't hear about being a widow
fields.body:
I am a widow. Now, be honest. What does that conjure up? Grey hair? Bus pass? Evenings in front of the telly with a cup of cocoa? Certainly not sex. You don't get a booklet on that, you see. There's one on claiming your pension, another on bereavement counselling, but where's the one on suddenly being single after 30 years with the same bloke who you fancied to the end?

My husband died at the end of July. He had been ill with leukaemia for three years. I love him. I miss him. So do my three children. But he had been ill for so long that his death came as a release for both of us. Now I need to move on. And part of moving on - inevitably, terrifyingly - is thinking about relationships with other men.

While he was ill, I didn't have time to look in the mirror. Then suddenly he wasn't there and when I looked at my reflection, I saw someone I didn't recognise. The trouble is, grief is great for the figure. Want to lose weight? Ask me how! I've lost pounds. Someone dies, there's loads to do. You race around. You don't eat. Drink like a fish. Drink like a widow.

And what about this grieving business? How do you do it properly? For how long? When are you allowed to giggle again? To think about other men? You're not divorced. You're not single. You're a widow and you're meant to be a saint, a goddess, an object of grief and pity. But after the sheer hard work of dragging my family through years of chemotherapy, bone marrow transplants and late-night hospital dashes, death was a blessed relief. You've done your job. You did it well and everyone says so, constantly reminding you of the weeping martyr role you are expected to fulfil while you have this disgraceful itch to get your hands on a healthy male body.

It's hard on the kids if you're ricocheting round the house like a pinball, gleefully clearing out binbags full of syringes, drugs and dressings. For them, there is no relief, just a huge gap and a mother who has overnight turned back into a woman.

Oh, you think you've got it sussed, this grieving and dealing, and then you find a note he's written saying goodbye and to not hurt for too long and it's Crumble City. You throw away the spicy pickles only he ate because they are past their use-by date. You don't buy white wine any more. The fridge never empties, it rots, and still post arrives addressed to him, offering accidental death insurance. You take photos of the kids on their first day at senior school and catch yourself thinking: "I must take them to the hospital to show him." Wrong.

Plus there is this terrifying sense of vulnerability. A long-term partner provides boundaries, however flexible, and without them I flail around, my anchor up, crazily searching for something, someone, to hold me down, keep me in check, under control.

I have joined a new gang and I don't know the rules. I've been booted out of Happy Families, smack bang into Blind Date. Suddenly you look at your women friends and wonder which one would be the least likely to put off the blokes and the most likely to want to talk about sex all night. You go Christmas shopping for the kids and come back with a catsuit for yourself. Last year, parties were avoided to spare other guests' embarrassment. Cancer's not fun, it makes people uneasy, and baldness is only attractive when you still have your eyebrows and your face isn't blown out with steroids. Now every invitation is accepted with brazen enquiries about probable single men quotas.

It's not that I want to move a bloke in, you understand. I don't want "a new Daddy for my children". While I, from the very first gut- wrenching, hand-clenching moment of his diagnosis, knew his leukaemia was terminal, incurable and unlikely to respond to treatment (they had a booklet on that one), my children saw every subsequent day as confirmation of success and a possible return to normality. For me, the person I fell in love with gradually faded away as I watched our roles metamorphose from ones of equality and delight into fragile, terrified patient and supposedly strong, optimistic carer.

But for my children his death was a total surprise, a deceit, a denial, a promise unfulfilled. I have had three years to try to get my head around this; they've only just begun. They are raw and ragged, trusting nothing and no one. Watching my every move. Urging me to eat properly but worrying when it's liver and broccoli in case I've got something wrong with my blood. They want life back as it was, while I couldn't bear that.

But as I venture back into the world of dating, I find myself confused. I'm not used to playing emotional games. When you've been with someone for a long time, it's straightforward. You do something together, you enjoy it, you do it again, whether it's tree pruning or anal sex - but with a new bloke? You're back to being 15 and hanging round by the phone in the hall. Will he? Won't he?

It's all very well 30-year-olds moaning on about wanting to meet the right man, settle down and have kids. At least that's socially acceptable. Try talking about rediscovering your desire when you are 50 and your husband's just died.

So what do you do? Macramé? Embroidery? No. You go and buy a load of new underwear, just in case, and if you want to learn a new skill, buy a vibrator. Happy New Year!

webTitle: The mysterious world of New Labour peers

fields.headline: Take your places, please
fields.standfirst:
On this year's winners in the mysterious - and mystifying - world of New Labour peers

Special report: Lords reform
fields.trailText: On this year's winners in the mysterious - and mystifying - world of New Labour peers
fields.body:
There are already, some say, too many annual awards. Awards for books and for beauties, for wine and for poets, for businesswomen and for dogs; even, incredibly, awards for journalists. What we need is fewer awards, not more.

On the other hand, does not this very profusion argue for the creation of additional prizes, to honour all those categories that have mysteriously been overlooked? If, say, bottoms have their own celebrated annual award - then why not life peers? If slimmers, who have powerful health reasons to shed their bulk, are eligible for prizes, then why not baronesses who accept their most solemn duties out of a simple desire to serve? If the lowliest "parliamentarian" stands the chance of public recognition for this futile and now thoroughly discredited activity, then why not one of our new placemen and placewomen, who are doing so much more to bring about Blair's vision of "a model 21st-century nation, based not on privilege or class or background, but on the equal worth of all"? What backbench MP, this year, has done a 10th as much as the prime minister's former cohabitee, Lord Falconer, to make this a model parliamentary democracy of which we can be proud?

One of the great difficulties, of course, in choosing a Placeperson of the Year , lies in detecting what exactly has been achieved, and by whom. With Tony Blair creating around 80 peers a year, and the creation of more than 300 task forces, staffed by more than 2,000 unelected placepersons, it is almost impossible to keep up with the quantity of good work being done.

Naturally, not having been elected, placepeople do not answer to the House of Commons, nor is membership of the House of Lords any guarantee of transparency. One thinks, for example, of his secretive lordship, Lord Levy, whose quiet diplomacy in the Middle East as the unofficial emissary of Tony Blair, was unknown to most of us until the Sunday Times decided to ask him about his tax arrangements.

And then some of their lordships are so unassuming as they go about their work as to be almost invisible. Which brings us to the first of our awards, the Mystery Prize for Entirely Inexplicable Promotion , which could easily have gone to Lord Birt, a bespectacled man formerly connected with the BBC. Tony Blair, unlike many of Lord Birt's former employees, discerned some talent in this devotee of management consultants. In July Blair appointed Birt his new "crime tsar", "tasked" (to adopt placemanspeak) with advising on the long-term causes of crime. The reason Birt does not win the prize is that we have no idea whether he is advising well or badly. To date, there has been no word of Birt's progress whatsoever. There were unconfirmed rumours of a lunch-date with the former Tory home secretary. After that, nothing. Some say he is still awaiting reports from his consultants. Others that he has gone undercover, the better to inform himself on his area of expertise. Either way, anyone who believes that the best peer is an invisible peer will surely welcome Lord Birt's outstanding contribution to 21st-century Britain.

Instead, the Mystery prize goes to Lord Matthew Evans, the publisher, who, despite having no discernible expertise or experience in the field of museums, was appointed chairman of the Museums, Libraries and Archives Commission. In his first utterance in the post, he accused his audience of museum curators of being, among many undesirable things, regressive, isolationist, and in danger of becoming "cultural versions of Marks and Spencer . . ." Well done, Lord Evans!

As Lord Evans discovered, placemanship can be a hard row to hoe, a theme which was movingly explored this year by Lord Bragg, who made a plea for enhanced pay and conditions for working peers such as himself. As "the 19th-century mills of Lancashire are to silicon valley", he pointed out to a Houseful of weeping colleagues, "so are the conditions of your Lordship's House to the way the 21st century really conducts its business". Perhaps, he ventured, if these put-upon operatives of the legislative spinning jenny were paid more, they might be better respected. "I am convinced that the quaint antiquity of our remuneration is part of the reason that, in the public eye, your Lordship's House receives less respect than its achievements merit."

And if, as he suggested, there were "more and better phones, faxes, e-mails, privacy . . . message systems", then - who knows - perhaps his young colleague, the millionaire Lord Alli, might not have to use the House as a business address in any of his future advertisements for dot.com employees?

In fairness, however, the Luvvie Award for Closer Links between Government and Showbiz must go to Lord Puttnam, who now devotes himself to helping the teaching profession, not least through the presentation of "education Oscars" for especially deserving pedagogues. But Lord Puttnam, who left school at 16, does not forget the runners-up, exhorting them to "develop a more enlightened attitude to the manner in which you are perceived by the public", suggesting that they take advice on performance from actors, and, most memorably, declaring that "you can't bully people into doing good work. You can love them into doing it."

Unless those people happen to be MPs, about whom Lord Puttnam recently had some uncharacteristically harsh things to say. "I have to say, the percentage of those who are fine people is depressingly slender," he said this year. "I often wonder whether the problem of Britain isn't in the failure of imagination in their elected representatives. A lot of them suffer from poverty of imagination."

Had Lord Puttnam not amply earned himself the above award, he would certainly have won another, for Best Placeperson's Coat of Arms , having favoured a badge flanked by two birds. "There was no device to represent my career in film so I persuaded them to put celluloid collars on the stork and the curlew," he said, imaginatively. Instead the award goes to Baroness Rendell of Babergh, who chose to feature polar bears.

After he was appointed vice chairman of the BBC, the government stressed that the economist had not been involved in any important political activity in the past five years. His wife works for Gordon Brown, at whose wedding Davies' daughter Rosie and son Ben served as bridesmaid and pageboy. The difficulty lay in choosing her most egregiously ill-chosen comments. Should it be her claim to having attended a "fairly standard" grammar? Her advice to the less fascinatingly employed on the joys of the wonderful world of work? In the end, it had to be that "little cottage" which has afforded her so many insights, of a weekend, into the rural way of life.

The only possible competition had come, inevitably, from Lord Falconer, who regretted having caused such inconvenience, last year, to "VIPs and ordinary people". But since Lord Falconer's greatest achievement is his staying power, despite a year's plebeian clamour for his resignation, the only suitable award must be the Elastoplast for Steadfast Defiance of the World's Non-Placemen .

webTitle: Palestinian grief brings Ramadan to a sad close

fields.headline: Palestinian grief brings Ramadan to a sad close
fields.standfirst:
The Muslim holiday is closing on a muted note after a year that saw hundreds die and, in Baghdad, tyranny and hardship still holding sway

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Violence in the Palestinian territories injected some sadness, and some anger, into Muslim celebrations ending the holy month of Ramadan yesterday, with religious leaders calling on the faithful to liberate Jerusalem from the Jews.
fields.body:
Violence in the Palestinian territories injected some sadness, and some anger, into Muslim celebrations ending the holy month of Ramadan yesterday, with religious leaders calling on the faithful to liberate Jerusalem from the Jews.

As Muslims worldwide celebrated Eid al-Fitr, which marks the end of Islam's holiest month, clerics also urged Muslims to send zakat (alms) to the Palestinians.

In Mecca, the imam of Masjid al-Haram, Islam's most holy site, declared that "the tragic events" in the Palestinian territories - where 350 people, mainly Arabs, have been killed in the past three months - were a "source of sorrow to every Arab, Muslim and fair minded person in the world".

"The Jewish invaders have violated the forbidden, desecrated the sacred and usurped our land in Palestine while the whole world has stood idle," Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdullah al-Sabeel said in a sermon after the Eid prayers.

In Cairo, the imams who led millions of worshippers in mosques and city squares asked that the traditional Eid alms be given to Palestinians who lost relatives in the uprising in Israel and the Palestinian territories.

After prayers, Egyptians exchanged good wishes while some activists sold pictures of Muslim holy sites in Jerusalem to raise funds for the Palestinians.

Iran's spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, told tens of thousands of worshippers gathered in and around a north Tehran mosque: "It is a human, religious, wise and historical duty for all the Muslim nations to support the oppressed Palestinian nation as much as possible."

Some hardliners responded with calls of "Death to Israel! Death to America!"

The leader of the Sunni Muslims in Lebanon, Sheikh Mohammed Rashid Kabbani, denounced Israel in his sermon, saying the intifada must continue "until Palestine and Jerusalem are liberated from the foreigner Jewish enemy".

In a number of Middle Eastern countries, the festivities marking the end of Ramadan were subdued this year, while all over the West Bank and Gaza Palestinian families were mourning their dead.

The leader of the Palestinians, Yasser Arafat, who performed early morning prayers in a Gaza mosque, told reporters that "This holiday is decisive. With God's help, it [the current negotiations for a peace settlement] will lead to a Palestinian boy or a Palestinian girl raising the flag of Palestine over the walls of Jerusalem."

Elsewhere, other pressing secular concerns intruded on the sacred.

In Afghanistan, the leader of the ruling Taliban, Mullah Omar, told his countrymen that the United States and Russia had a plan to isolate Muslims worldwide, beginning with Afghanistan. Washington and Moscow are the co-sponsors of a UN resolution imposing new sanctions on the Taliban, including restrictions on foreign travel for its leaders.

The US, he said, was also trying to thwart the Taliban in particular, using as a pretext the sanctuary which Afghanistan has given to the man who at the top of Washington's most-wanted list of terrorists, Osama bin Laden.

Meanwhile, Malaysian Muslims, including the prime minister, ended the fasting month with house parties yesterday. In his holiday message, the prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad called on the Malay ethnic group - which forms the power base of his government and is mainly Muslim - to heal political divisions. AP

webTitle: Sanctions give Iraq little to celebrate

fields.headline: Sanctions give Iraq little to celebrate
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Iraqis, hit hard by more than 10 years of UN economic sanctions, found little joy yesterday as the Muslim world celebrated the Eid al-Fitr feast which marks the end of the holy month of Ramadan.
fields.body:
Iraqis, hit hard by more than 10 years of UN economic sanctions, found little joy yesterday as the Muslim world celebrated the Eid al-Fitr feast which marks the end of the holy month of Ramadan.

"How can we celebrate and feel happy if we cannot afford it?" asked Munna Khalaf, who lost one of her six children to a serious illness four years ago. The traditional good cheer of the occasion was dampened by the widespread hardship suffered since sanctions were imposed in August 1990 after Iraq's invasion and occupation of Kuwait.

The three-day feast brought mixed feelings to Iraqis: nostalgia for the good old days tempered by hope that sanctions will soon be lifted.

"For the poor there is little joy, but the rich celebrate ... Before 1990 you'd see people singing and dancing in the streets when the Eid came," a shopkeeper, Abu Saad, 52, said. "

We are sick of these embargoes. We just wait and wait for them to end ... I am fed up and I don't follow the news any more."

The sanctions have not only caused personal suffering, they have also shattered Iraq's economy: the basic salary of a civil servant can be as little as 5,000 dinars (£1.70) a month.

There is no immediate end in sight to the sanctions and the US secretary of state-designate, Colin Powell, has stated his intention to "re-energise" them.

But Iraqis have found grounds for optimism in the decision of some countries to resume flights to Iraq in the latter part of the year.

US and British war planes struck targets in the south of Iraq yesterday but no casualties were reported, according to Iraqi sources.

An Iraqi military spokesman, quoted by the official Iraqi News Agency INA, said "enemy formations" flew over the provinces of Basra, Dhiqar, Muthanna, Qadissiya, Najaf, Kerbala and Wassit yesterday morning, attacking civilian and service installations. Reuters

webTitle: Haggling on Middle East peace deal begins

fields.headline: Haggling on Middle East peace deal begins
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Palestinian sources revealed the substance of their response to the peace plan devised by the US yesterday as the official reply was being couriered to Washington in a letter.
fields.body:
Palestinian sources revealed the substance of their response to the peace plan devised by the US yesterday as the official reply was being couriered to Washington in a letter.

The plan gives the Palestinians 95% of the West Bank, but officials speaking say privately that they want a map with details of the planned transfer.

The sources said that the Palestinians also want more details of the US proposal that Israel should rent 3% of a Palestinian West Bank, in the centre of of Hebron and 1% of the northern Gaza Strip. The rental would run for 20 years.

In exchange for the 5% of the West Bank that Israel would keep, Tel Aviv would give the Palestinians land just outside the south-east of the Gaza Strip. The Palestinians want to know its specific location and size, the sources said.

The initiative says Israel should keep the main Jewish settlements around Jerusalem, but give up 60 to 70 settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

The plan also calls for the West Bank to be bisected by an Israeli-controlled six- to 10-mile wide corridor from Jerusalem to the Dead Sea - a plan which the Palestinians strongly reject.

The Palestinians would gain sovereignty over the al-Aqsa mosque compound, known as the Noble Sanctuary and the third-holiest shrine in Islam, but Israel would have control of the archaeological sites that lie beneath the surface, according to the plan.

The Palestinians want sovereignty of the underground sites as well, the sources said.

Tel Aviv publicly signaled its willingness to give up sovereignty of the site, known to Jews as the Temple Mount.

Israeli sovereignty over the Western Wall, the holiest site in Judaism, is not contested.

The Palestinians would gain control of traditionally Arab districts of Jerusalem under the plan. Palestinians welcome that, but they want more information about the fate of Jewish neighbourhoods in mainly Arab districts, the sources said.

Under the plan, Israeli forces would stay in the Jordan valley for three to six years, controlling the borders, and after that an international force would patrol the area.

Again, the Palestinians want details.

The biggest sticking point is the 4m Palestinian refugees and their right to return to what is now Israel. Palestinians have made no public expression of willingness to go along with the reported terms of the US plans for refugees.

Israeli reports claim that the US plan calls for the Palestinians to largely relinquish the right of return. Some of the refugees scattered in the West Bank, Gaza Strip, Lebanon, Syria and Jordan would be settled in the new Palestinian state, but a tiny number would be allowed into Israel to reunite families. Significant aid would help with resettlement and compensation.

webTitle: New testament: Lost will explodes Gaudi myth

fields.headline: New testament
fields.standfirst: Lost will explodes Gaudi myth
fields.trailText: It has always been thought that the revered Catalan architect Antoni Gaudi died a pauper after being struck by a tram in Barcelona in 1926.
fields.body:
It has always been thought that the revered Catalan architect Antoni Gaudi died a pauper after being struck by a tram in Barcelona in 1926.

Now a newspaper has claimed that copy of his will has surfaced, showing that he left 3,000 pesetas, about £50,000 in today's money.

La Vanguardia said that documents which Gaudi drew up in his last few years had been found in a government archive in Reus, near Barcelona, and at the office of the Archbishop of Tarragona, also in Catalonia.

The notary's office which processed Gaudi's will and was thought to hold the only copy was burned down in 1936.

Gaudi, 73 when he died, was at the forefront of the Art Nouveau movement in Spain. He is best known for the whimsical, free-flowing shapes and voluptuous colours seen in some of Barcelona's most notable landmarks, including the Parc Guell and the Sagrada Familia cathedral. Hitherto Spaniards have thought that the devout and unmarried Gaudi left what little he had to the still unfinished Sagrada Familia, his life's work.

webTitle: Crucial seats Hague must win

fields.headline: Crucial seats Hague must win
fields.standfirst: Special report: elections 2000
fields.trailText: Next year Tony Blair faces the loneliest choice a British prime minister ever makes. He has to decide whether to go ahead with the expected general election this spring and, if so, exactly when.
fields.body:
Next year Tony Blair faces the loneliest choice a British prime minister ever makes. He has to decide whether to go ahead with the expected general election this spring and, if so, exactly when. Or should he opt for caution and postpone it until early June, October or even as late as June 2002?

By modern standards he still enjoys an astonishing dominance in the opinion polls, 10% ahead in this month's Guardian/ICM poll, a 13.1% lead according to Gallup in the Daily Telegraph, the latter figure almost exactly the percentage lead which delivered Labour's extraordinary 179-seat landslide on May 1 1997.

The government's protracted honeymoon ended in 1999 amid familiar problems over jobs, crime, ministerial squabbles, the NHS, road and rail chaos, the dome. Not even baby Leo's arrival prevented the healthy onset of political mortality. Mr Blair is no longer as trusted as he was.

Yet William Hague, fighting his first leader's election (as is Charles Kennedy), seems unable to profit more than briefly from Labour's discomfort. His populist forays on asylum, on Europe and even the murder of Damilola Taylor strike an uneasy note, even among many Tories.

To survive as Tory leader with a chance of victory in 2005-6, Mr Hague knows he must cut Labour's lead to below 100. He must also quash Liberal Democrat pretensions to be Labour's near-permanent, shot-calling progressive partner.

Labour ought to be brimming with confidence. Yet there is unease. Every minister knows that the three centre-left landslides of the 20th century - 1906, 1945, 1966 - collapsed entirely or were hamstrung at the next election. Has Labour done enough to prevent mass abstentions or defections next time round?

With probably just a few months to go, the Guardian has tested the water in two key marginals which Mr Hague must win to survive, let alone be prime minister. He still has a long way to go.

Yet William Hague, fighting his first leader's election (as is Charles Kennedy), seems unable to profit more than briefly from Labour's discomfort. His populist forays on asylum, on Europe and even the murder of Damilola Taylor strike an uneasy note, even among many Tories. To survive as Tory leader with a chance of victory in 2005-6, Mr Hague knows he must cut Labour's lead to below 100. He must also quash Liberal Democrat pretensions to be Labour's near-permanent, shot-calling progressive partner. Labour ought to be brimming with confidence. Yet there is unease. Every minister knows that the three centre-left landslides of the 20th century - 1906, 1945, 1966 - collapsed entirely or were hamstrung at the next election. Has Labour done enough to prevent mass abstentions or defections next time round? With probably just a few months to go, the Guardian has tested the water in two key marginals which Mr Hague must win to survive, let alone be prime minister. He still has a long way to go.

webTitle: Enfield byelection

fields.headline: A status symbol ripe for the picking
fields.standfirst:
Enfield

Special report: elections 2000
fields.trailText: Enfield
fields.body:
On a miserable afternoon, when most people are wrapped up in the warmth of their homes, a woman rushes out on to the street with no time to put on a coat.

"Oh Stephen, I saw you walking by and was so hoping you'd drop in," the woman says as she rushes up to her young MP. Stephen Twigg beams at the woman, asks after the residents in her nursing home - he knows them all - and is on his way.

If the general election were purely a personality contest, Mr Twigg would romp home once again in Enfield Southgate, the north London seat he snatched from Michael Portillo in 1997. Hardly a soul has a harsh word for the Oxford-educated local boy whose daily pounding of Enfield's streets has paid dividends.

The battle in Enfield Southgate will, however, be tough as both parties seek to win the seat which came to symbolise the Tory meltdown of 1997. Were you up for Portillo? was the title of the best-known book of the general election, which pictured Mr Twigg rolling his eyes in disbelief moments after unseating one of the country's most unpopular Tories. Mr Portillo announced that the Tories had suffered a "truly terrible night" after his 15,545 majority was transformed into a Labour majority of 1,433 on a 17.4% swing.

Labour would love to hold Enfield to show that Tony Blair can still capture the imagination of comfortable suburban voters who kept the Conservatives in power for nearly a generation. But John Flack, the Tory candidate who needs a swing of 1.55%, knows that he must win back Enfield if his party is to be seen as a credible force.

The constituency, which is at the top of London's Piccadilly line, is sharply divided. Labour will write off the northern tip, around the smart Trent Park, where owners in million-pound properties have shown little appetite for New Labour. The Tories will write off the most southerly part, just below the north circular road, where voters in small flats traditionally support Labour. The contest will take place between the two extremes where there is a sizeable Liberal Democrat vote up for grabs and thousands of floating voters. The signs for both sides are mixed.

Labour has been defeated in the two main elections in the constituency since the last general election - the 1999 European elections and last summer's London assembly elections. Although a loyal Blairite, Mr Twigg, 34, has paid heed and is conciliatory towards Ken Livingstone. Calling for a deal between the mayor and government over tube funding, Mr Twigg says: "I have been impressed by Ken's record and see no reason why he should not be returned to the Labour party."

If Mr Twigg succeeds in neutralising the "Ken factor" he could find himself punished for the sins of the Labour-controlled Enfield council which has angered voters by increasing council tax while reducing services. If the council's performance damages Mr Twigg, his Tory opponent could be hurt by concerns about the Tory performance at a national level. Freda Burnett, a nursing home resident who voted Conservative in 1997, said: "I might turn against the Tories next time because there seems to be a lot of petty bickering."

Voters in the constituency, which has a high proportion of Cypriots and Asians, do not seem too bothered by William Hague's interventions on crime and race. But traditional Tory voters harbour serious doubts about his competence.

One Asian man, who abandoned the Tories for the first time in 1997, said he was unlikely to switch back. The man, who asked not to be named, said: "Hague is not up to the level one expects of a prime minister. He is not in John Major's league and has a very short time to change his ways."

In the face of these signals, the Tory candidate insists he is on course for victory. A businessman and admirer of Norman Tebbit, John Flack, 43, said: "The Labour party made a huge effort to get Portillo out in 1997. I cannot see anyone being so motivated to stop John Flack getting in. I look forward to seeing Stephen Twigg in the Commons - when he comes back at a byelection in another seat."

As a Eurosceptic and fervent supporter of Mr Hague's Keep the Pound campaign, Mr Flack will hope to scoop the 1,342 votes which went to Jimmy Goldsmith's Referendum party in 1997.

Any gains on that front could, however, be cancelled by Lib Dem spoiling tactics. The party has yet to select a candidate, suggesting that Enfield may have been pencilled in for an informal Lib-Lab electoral deal.

1997 results

Twigg, S (Lab) 20,570; Portillo, M (Con) 19,137; Browne, J (LD) 4,966; Luard, N (Ref) 1,342; Others: 518

Lab maj 1,433

webTitle: The rise of the Maharaja Mac

fields.headline: Give me a Big Mac - but hold the beef
fields.standfirst:
In India, where the cow is venerated, most people do not eat beef, but McDonald's still has plans to conquer the subcontinent. Luke Harding on the rise of the Maharaja Mac

Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: In India, where the cow is venerated, most people do not eat beef, but McDonald's still has plans to conquer the subcontinent.  Luke Harding  on the rise of the Maharaja Mac
fields.body:
It is lunchtime at Ansal Plaza, Delhi's newest shopping centre. Inside the groundfloor branch of McDonald's, Ashish and Jasmeet are busy behind the counter doling out seven rupee (10p) ice-cream cones to a group of Indian schoolboys. The restaurant is half-empty or half-full, depending, of course, on your view of global capitalism. At first glance the branch resembles any of the McDonald's restaurants across the world. We could be in French Guyana, the most recent addition to McDonald's prolific empire, or Kuwait, or Russia. It is only when you spot a small sign on the wall that you realise this is India. It reads: "No beef or beef products sold at this restaurant."

Four years after arriving in Delhi and Bombay, McDonald's is poised to launch a massive expansion programme in India, its last great frontier. There are plans to expand the existing 24 restaurants to 80.

That McDonald's has come here at all seems curious. The subcontinent, after all, has revered the cow for thousands of years. The creatures are everywhere in India - on traffic humps, grazing in rubbish dumps, in temples - everywhere, that is, except on your plate. To give an idea of how highly the animal is revered, nobody thought it odd when, earlier this month, 634 cows, en route to a slaughterhouse in Muslim Bangladesh, were rescued from a train by animal rights activists. The sight of naked Hindu saints holding pro-cow rallies is not unusual.

McDonald's, by contrast, is the world's largest user of beef. Hundreds of thousands of animals have died since Ray Kroc, McDonald's founder, first opened a modest burger parlour in Des Plaines, Illinois, back in 1955. From humble beginnings in the US, Kroc set out on an epic voyage of expansion that was to take McDonald's into 119 countries, sweeping aside barriers of ideology, language and taste. But in recent years there has been resistance to his global vision from, for example, the two London Greenpeace activists who took on McDonald's in Britain's longest ever libel trial; high-street conscious Hampstead residents; and concerned environmentalists around the world.

As the stand-off between anti-globalists and multinationals continues, India has become the last great battleground. If McDonald's can succeed here, without beef, it can succeed anywhere, so the reasoning goes. To woo customers, McDonald's has devised a unique marketing strategy. India is the only country in the world where McDonald's does not offer beef. With 140m Indian Muslims, pork is off the menu, too. This leaves chicken and mutton - the ingredient of McDonald's flagship "Maharaja Mac". There are other additions to the menu specifically designed to lure India's middle-class - such as the tantalising McAloo Tikki burger. All foods are strictly segregated into vegetarian and non-vegetarian lines. Even the mayonnaise has no egg in it, so as not to offend India's vegan sensibilities.

Sitting in a first-floor office, incongruously decorated with Hindu friezes and posters of the ever-grinning Ronald McDonald, Vikram Bakshi - McDonald's managing director in India - admits that beef had been a "complete no-no" from the start. "We have to be sensitive to the culture here. No beef and no pork. We are absolutely politically correct. The point is to be commercially viable. Using beef would take us away from 80% of our customers."

McDonald's had been drawn to India because of its huge potential market of 1,000 million people, he says. Bakshi points with pride to the new McDonald's on the road between Delhi and Agra, which allows customers to munch Maharaja Macs en route to the Taj Mahal. More branches in north India will follow, he says.

But Indian critics complain that McDonald's food is "bad", "expensive" and, well, "unIndian". They also allege that McDonald's - together with other fast-food outlets that arrived in the mid-90s, is losing money. "India has a very ancient food culture. We are not going to change to American patterns of consumption. McDonald's will never become part of mass culture in India because most people can't afford to eat there," says Dr Vandana Shiva, director of the Research Foundation for Science, Technology and Ecology. People in India are gradually "waking up" to the threat posed by foreign multinationals, including Monsanto, to traditional methods of farming and ecology, she adds.

India's fledgling fast-food industry has been keeping a low profile because of such opposition. Five years ago, Kentucky Fried Chicken found its new restaurant in the eminently westernised city of Bangalore under siege from farmers and anti-globalisation protesters. Customers had been staying away too - put off by what they regarded as high prices and inedible food. The mob ended up vandalising the restaurant. A hundred people were arrested. KFC eventually abandoned India altogether. "India is no Thailand, where we could create the Kentucky magic within two years of operations," its former MD in India, Sandeep Kohli, conceded. "We closed because the economics didn't work out."

Many of the multinationals that came to India following liberalisation in the early 90s made the same mistake as KFC. They overestimated the size of India's middle class. It is around 100 million - though the figure of 200 million is often bandied about. And it is discerning. Domino's Pizza, McDonald's, TGI Fridays and others discovered to their horror that their new restaurants were rarely full. They embarked on a desperate round of price cuts. A Big Mac lamb wonder today sells for the lowly sum of 19 rupees (30p), while the cost of a Domino's pizza with cheese toppings has plunged from 90 rupees (£1.40) to 49 rupees (75p). This has not deterred other aspirational entrants to the market: Pizza Express, the British chain, recently opened its second Delhi restaurant. It has "conservative" expansion plans.

In China, McDonald's has had a happier time of it. There are now 260 restaurants, frequented by the better off and the urban rich. Ronald McDonald has been transmogrified in China into Uncle McDonald (and Aunt McDonald), as befits a corporation which adapts to local needs. In neighbouring Japan, which was assimilated into the Kroc empire 30 years ago, there are more than 3,000 branches of McDonald's.

There are few countries in Asia where McDonald's has yet to penetrate. To avoid the chain entirely you would have to go somewhere really remote: Afghanistan, perhaps, with its landmines, civil war and Islamic fundamentalism. Or there is Bhutan, a small and esoteric Himalayan kingdom of few tourists and no beefburgers, where there exists a long-standing tradition of scepticism towards dubious western ideas.

webTitle: Leader: Milosevic on the ropes

fields.headline: Milosevic on the ropes
fields.standfirst:
He is no longer safe from Serbia's courts

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The Milosevic era is truly over and in the next few months Serbia's evil genius may well be put on trial in his own country. Less than four months ago such a scenario would have seemed absurd, but the pace of recent change has outstripped all expectations, not least those of the former strongman who precipitated his own downfall by organising Yugoslav elections in September.
fields.body:
The Milosevic era is truly over and in the next few months Serbia's evil genius may well be put on trial in his own country. Less than four months ago such a scenario would have seemed absurd, but the pace of recent change has outstripped all expectations, not least those of the former strongman who precipitated his own downfall by organising Yugoslav elections in September.

He lost the presidency and now in the latest democratic exercise he has lost control of the Serbian parliament. The reformist forces have swept the board, taking more than two-thirds of the seats and leaving them the chance of amending the flawed Milosevic constitution if necessary. Although Milosevic's party won 13% of the vote, the electorate brutally humiliated his wife, whose party won less than 0.4%. Her party was a phoney creation that had a leftwing-sounding name while in practice being little more than a club of cronies who got good jobs in businesses protected by the regime. Serbian voters have shown how much they want to break this team.

Zoran Djindjic, the experienced leader of the Democratic party who is to be Serbia's prime minister, has a formidable agenda. He must hold his coalition of 18 parties together. The economy needs reforming. The old regime's cronies must be removed. A sound legal climate has to be created for foreign investment. Negotiations with an increasingly independence-minded Montenegro loom. Milosevic's future, in limbo since last autumn, must be clarified. Mr Djindjic has indicated that he wants to move fast to see Milosevic tried for corruption, vote-rigging and embezzlement. Provided the trial is fair and speedy and the former strongman is soon evicted from state villas he still enjoys, this might prove better than any early transfer to the Hague to the international war crimes tribunal. Serbs need to feel they are in charge of their own destiny.

But it would be wrong to avoid the war crimes issue altogether, or to make Milosevic carry all the guilt. Collective responsibility cannot be dumped on all Serbs, but neither is there such a thing as one-man responsibility. Milosevic ran a killing machine in which thousands of Serbs took part, and at some stage the authorities must take steps to organise trials of a range of military and paramilitary commanders or send them to the Hague. Otherwise, the nationalist page will not be fully turned.

webTitle: Office killer kept sniper rifle at workplace

fields.headline: Office killer kept sniper rifle at workplace
fields.standfirst: Special report: Gun Violence in America
fields.trailText: The 42-year-old computer worker accused of shooting dead seven colleagues kept a gun at work and bomb-making equipment at home, it was disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
The 42-year-old computer worker accused of shooting dead seven colleagues kept a gun at work and bomb-making equipment at home, it was disclosed yesterday.

Further evidence suggested that the motive for the attack involved money set to be deducted from his wages.

Michael McDermott - nicknamed Mucko - appeared in court yesterday manacled and wearing orange prison clothes and a bullet-proof vest.

He denied shooting dead four women and three men at the offices of Edgeware Technology in Wakefield, Massachusetts, about 10 miles north of Boston. Such a plea indicates that his defence intends to argue that the balance of his mind was affected. Mr McDermott has been taking medication and receiving psychiatric treatment.

A collector of antique guns, he had responded on websites to questions about explosives. Last week he had an argument about the company's intention to dock money from his wages in response to an Internal Revenue Service request to recover a couple of thousand dollars in unpaid taxes.

"In a fairly routine procedure they asked the company to assist with garnishment of his wages, taking a percentage, but obviously not all, to pay off back taxes," said Martha Coakley, a district attorney.

Mr McDermott - who used the name Mucko on both the internet and his licence plates - singled out two people in his employer's accounts department as he made his way around the building seeking out victims for between eight and 10 minutes late Tuesday morning, the court in Malden was told.

Tom O'Reilly, an assistant district attorney, said a high-powered rifle with sniper sights was found in his locker at work, ammunition in his desk and shotgun shells in a dustbin. At home there was bomb-making literature and gallons of chemicals in boxes labelled "danger, do not move".

Mike Stanley, a manager at Edgeware, said: "Of all the people that I thought could have done this, it's him. He was variously described by others as lonely, anti-social, and surly, or average, amiable and bizarre."

In response to one internet inquiry on how to get landmines, posted by someone wanting to defend Christians in Indonesia, Mucko replied: "It would seem that some 'Christians' have forgotten the sixth commandment." The sixth commandment states: "Thou shalt not kill."

webTitle: Alarm as drug company chief joins watchdog

fields.headline: Alarm as drug company chief joins watchdog
fields.trailText: A top executive at one of the world's leading pharmaceutical companies is to become director of drugs licensing at the medicines control agency
fields.body:
A top executive at one of the world's leading pharmaceutical companies is to become director of drugs licensing at the medicines control agency, raising questions about the independence of the MCA from the industry that it is supposed to police.

Ian Hudson will take up his new job in February. He has worked in the drugs industry for the past 11 years and until recently was director and vice- president of Worldwide Clinical Safety, at SmithKline Beecham, and was to have led the worldwide drug safety group after the merger of SKB with Glaxo Wellcome, which came into effect yesterday.

The MCA rebuts any suggestion that the appointment of Dr Hudson to head the drugs licensing division will reinforce the already close links between the MCA and the drugs industry.

"These very senior positions within the agency do not come along very often and it would be regarded as an exceptional opportunity to play a leading national and international role in public health through medicines regulation," said a spokeswoman. She added that the MCA had "previously attracted high-calibre candidates from industry", including its chief executive, Keith Jones. Dr Jones was formerly a director of Merck, Sharpe and Dohme Rahway in the United States.

But there will be concerns over the appointment among consumer groups and those who are critical of the MCA's secretive ways of operating.

Although the MCA claims to be moving towards greater openness, few details have been divulged about evidence given that has meant approval or otherwise for drug licences.

The agency argues that the data it sees from clinical trials are commercially sensitive and must be kept secret to assure protection from competitors to the companies developing the drugs.

The MCA makes its decisions following advice from the committee on safety of medicines, a group comprising doctors and scientists, the majority of whom have links to the drugs industry in the form of research grants, consultancies or other financial support.

All members of the CSM are asked to declare both personal interests in drug companies, such as shares or fees, and non-personal interests, such as funding for clinical trials. Any member with a personal financial interest is expected to leave the room when the CSM starts to discuss drugs connected with the company involved.

Critics say, however, that the problem runs deeper than personal interests because most of the scientists are steeped in a culture which does not tend to question the drugs industry.

Paul Flynn, MP for Newport West, considers this culture "defensive, pro-industry and anti-consumer". He says that those responsible for advising and granting licences for medicines should be wholly independent of the industry and rejects the argument that the scientists who are employed and backed by drugs companies are the best in their field.

"They tell you these people are the only ones who can do it, which is not true. There are plenty of independent people who could do it," he said.

While it was not uncommon for top figures in other industries to move into Whitehall, such as the Department of Trade, he said, "matters of life and death" hung on decisions that affected the licensing of medicines.

Clare Mackay, principal policy adviser to the Consumers' Association, said it was probably inevitable that there would be movement between the industry and the regulatory body. She said the issues were about conflicts of interest when people "crossed over", and the need for guidelines to be in place to manage it. Also his appointment sent out a message about "the priorities for the MCA".

The drugs regulatory system is facing a review within Europe which may lead to the end of separate licensing bodies for countries. Ms Mackay said she was aware that it would be a challenge to get the public/patient perspective taken on board.

webTitle: Relief as French leave EU chair

fields.headline: Relief as French leave EU chair
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: After what even the French media have begun calling a "six-month political fiasco", France hands the European Union presidency to Sweden this weekend, to sighs of relief from its fellow members.
fields.body:
After what even the French media have begun calling a "six-month political fiasco", France hands the European Union presidency to Sweden this weekend, to sighs of relief from its fellow members.

"The treaty of Nice is a failure ... and the way France conducted the inter-governmental conference that produced it has led to an unprecedented avalanche of criticism," the daily Libération said yesterday.

Diplomats and analysts point out that the task Paris faced - bringing to a successful conclusion complex and sensitive negotiations on the institutional reforms needed to allow the EU to function as it expands to the east - would have been a tough one for any country. But they add that France did not make its job any easier: arrogant, bullying, insensitive and bereft of vision are some of the more polite epithets that have been applied to the French EU presidency since the Nice summit earlier this month.

"This has been perhaps the worst EU presidency ever. France has acted like a bull in a china shop," a diplomat from one of the smaller states said. "Small countries generally run the presidency better. They tend to lack the big power ambitions so patently on display during this French presidency."

Some important technical successes were chalked up. A new maritime safety agency was agreed, as was a military rapid reaction force. A European company law was formulated after being blocked for 30 years, rail freight was liberalised, road hauliers' working hours were restricted, and local phone calls were opened to competition.

But Brussels insiders say this was due mainly to the hard work of France's permanent representative to the union, Pierre Vimont, and his team of diplomats and technocrats. French ministers, on the other hand, were criticised for behaving "with the individualistic, loose-tongued arrogance of Paris taxi drivers in a bad mood".

Much of France's lack of European perspective is due to the rivalry between the centre-right president, Jacques Chirac, and his Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, who will almost certainly be standing against each other in the 2002 presidential elections.

That contest, another Brussels diplomat said, "has deprived France of all perspective, to the point where the situation has become of serious concern to the country's partners, particularly Germany".

But the absence of a French vision for Europe also stems from its leaders' apathy on the subject. Mr Jospin has made no major speech on Europe since he was elected in mid-1997. Mr Chirac's few attempts at the subject have been contradictory and confused.

As a result, observers and politicians argue, France went to Nice without any genuine political objective beyond retaining a semblance of parity with Germany. This meant it succeeded in offending its partners, while not even, in the end, being able to defend its immediate national interests.
