webTitle: Our year at the Dome

fields.headline: Our year at the Dome
fields.standfirst:
It started to go horribly wrong on the opening night - and it has been one long struggle ever since. As the Millennium Dome enters its final days, Joanna Moorhead asks some of the staff what it was like to work for a national disastor.

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The inside story - by the people who work there
fields.body:
Daryl Atkins, 36.
Dome host

Daryl Atkins's job, this past year, has been to welcome the public to the different zones of the dome, and explain the exhibits. She remembers the early days as chaos "In the beginning everything just fell apart: it all went wrong. The queues were terrible. They solved them eventually by giving people timed tickets, but they should have done that from the start. The trouble was that the Body was the busiest zone, and when people arrived it was the first thing they would see - a huge long queue. It was so depressing."

But the quiet days that followed the first rush of interest were the worst of all. "We had been led to believe the place would be packed out most of the time, but by February and March there were weekdays when we hardly saw a soul before noon. It was a real downer.

"We tried to just get on with things, but it made the day stretch on and on - especially as we had been so psyched up for it being busy. And it was freezing cold, too, in the early weeks. There was a problem with the heating and we had to wear our outdoor jackets inside. We were still shivering."

The signs inside the dome were a big source of trouble. "The idea was that the dome wasn't going to have signs. Instead we, the hosts, were going to talk people through the exhibits and tell them what was going on. It sounded fine, but the truth was that there was only one of you and - when it was busy at the weekends, especially - you could only talk to one or two people at a time. It was batty. As time went on they changed things and the signs were improved, but they never got it quite right."

Jan Anderson, 50.
Business strategy manager

"There have been so many days when we've just sat here and cried - I've lost count," says Jan Anderson, a senior civil servant who became the dome's head of government liaison and business strategy in October 1997. "It wasn't a question of sleepless nights - over the past 12 months, I don't think I've had a sleepful night. It's been one crisis after another - there is no way any of us could have imagined what this year would be like."

It all started to go fabulously wrong on the first night. "We put everything into getting the place ready for December 31 and, when it was, we thought we had achieved this miracle and that it would all be OK from then on."

It wasn't. "As the first night wore on we heard the rumours about people being stuck at Stratford and unable to get in, and I remember feeling a bit jittery. But it wasn't until a few days later that we realised how enormous the impact of that night, and the publicity about it, had been."

The worst moments were in June and September when the dome faced closure unless it was given more government funding.

"As the head of government liaison, I had had to prepare all the reports and go to meetings with the millennium commission, which funds us. But on the days when they were making up their mind if we would get more money, I was just sitting there on tenterhooks like everyone else. When the phone rang and we heard that we had got our money, the relief was enormous."

Robert Warner, 35.
Show director

For Robert Warner, the biggest difficulty was convincing the 162 performers in the Millennium Show that a pitifully small audience didn't mean total disaster. "Of course it's bad for morale when you've got an arena that can seat 16,000 and only 200 people are there," he says.

"As a director you've got to keep people's spirits high. I would tell them that they might have already entertained 15,000 or 20,000 that day, because it was always the third show, at 6pm or 7pm, that got the lightest audiences - and there are three shows a day. But it wasn't easy, because, of course, we wanted the place packed out all the time. And it wasn't. In some ways, I have felt like the bandleader on the Titanic, conducting even as the ship sinks beneath the waves."

Matt Costain, 30.
Acrobat

Trapeze artist Matt Costain has the lead role of Skyboy in the Millen nium Show. What hurt most about the criticism of the dome, he says, was when family and friends read the reports and believed them. "Like when your dad phones and says he's read it's all crap so he's not going to come and you say: 'Dad, for God's sake - come and see for yourself.'

"He loved it. But I've stopped telling taxi drivers what I do. I tell them I'm a tax inspector."

Cherie Williams, 32.
Chief executive's PA

Cherie Williams has spent most of the past 12 months dealing with letters from people who think they could do a better job than the dome management. "They write in to say, if you did this you would pull in an extra 10,000 a day. There are just so many experts out there: one man said that if we had mirrored cubes it would do it. Another wanted to change the show. Everyone thinks they know more than we do about how to run the dome."

Even now, Williams, personal assistant to the chief executive, Pierre-Yves Gerbeau - and to his predecessor, Jennie Page - still has a pile of letters to answer. "P-Y insists on a reply to everyone," she says.

Williams had been Page's PA for several years when her boss was made dome chief executive. "I thought it was brilliant - I was so excited to think I would be helping to make history," she says. But by the end of February, Page had been sacked and Williams had a new boss. "I was in shock when I was told that Jennie was going," says Williams. "But everything happened so fast: the new chief executive arrived, and he asked me if I would stay on. I said yes, but it was very difficult to say goodbye to Jennie because we all thought she had done a good job. I still think about her sometimes."

Amanda Nicholls, 31.
Dome Host

On the day of the attempted diamond robbery, Amanda Nicholls was working in the Mind Zone, close to where the thieves' JCB crashed through the outer wall. "I heard this shudder, which must have been the JCB coming in. Someone said we all had to evacuate the place and I was running towards the exit when I saw a figure in black running along and two men behind him shouting: 'Armed police - stop or we shoot.' My legs felt like jelly - I just couldn't believe what I was hearing."

Adam Liversage, 28.
Press officer

"The dome has been a political football, and it's a shame because we've never been able to stand on our own two feet," says Adam Liversage. "We're a visitor attraction, for God's sake, and we are treated like a government department: what other visitor attraction is monitored by the national press on a weekly basis? When we've got good news, no one wants to know - we've just welcomed our six millionth visitor, which was the target we were aiming for since Pierre-Yves Gerbeau arrived. But did anyone from the press want to know?"

As drama piled upon drama, and crisis upon crisis, the unexpected became the routine for the press office. "When the jewel thieves broke in a few weeks ago, it was almost just another day for us. I got a call to say someone had just driven a bulldozer through the gate, and then a reporter from the Sun phoned to ask had there just been a robbery? In any other press office something like that would be the story of a lifetime, but here it was just a question of, OK, I'll go and take a look."

Sholto Douglas-Home, 39.
Marketing director

"It was like launching a new restaurant and giving everyone food poisoning on the first night," says Sholto Douglas-Home. "We all realised fairly quickly that what happened at the start of January was a very serious blow, and that it would be extremely difficult to turn things around."

Difficult was an understatement. But Douglas-Home and his team never gave up. "It was like a drug," he says of the dome. "It pulled you in, you became addicted to it. If I was at home I would phone in five, six times a day just to check on attendance figures. It had us hooked."

Next year Douglas-Home, who has been on secondment from BT, goes back to his old job there as head of advertising. He defends all he has done at the dome. "I'm not saying everything about the dome worked, but I will defend the marketing strategy - One Amazing Day did work.

"From the start, I don't think any of us were under the illusion that the 12-million visitor target would be easy, but what you have to bear in mind was that everything seemed such a challenge. It was, we've got to build the thing, ha ha. We've got to organise the show, ha ha. We've got to get 12 million people through the doors, ha ha.

"The point is, it all seemed so ridiculously ambitious, and in many of the ambitions we did succeed.

"We were all in completely unchartered territory - there has never been anything like this and I don't think there ever will be again."

There have, Douglas-Home admits, been some very tough days. "But I wouldn't have missed it," he says. "Sometimes I've felt, help, I want to get off. But it's like the scariest sort of rollercoaster: once you get off, you want to get back on. I love the dome: I believe in it. I think it is a great day out. And history will be kind to it. I honestly believe that."

webTitle: Newborn baby found dead at derelict pub

fields.headline: Newborn baby found dead at derelict pub
fields.trailText: Police hope today to interview a teenage mother whose new-born baby was found dead in sub-zero temperatures at a derelict pub in Derbyshire.
fields.body:
Police hope today to interview a teenage mother whose new-born baby was found dead in sub-zero temperatures at a derelict pub in Derbyshire.

A spokeswoman said the 16-year-old girl, from Newhall, near Swadlincote, south-east Derbyshire, was taken by her parents to Queen's hospital in Burton-on-Trent, Staffordshire, in the early hours of yesterday. There, the girl told medical staff she had given birth to a baby girl, whom she had left in the pub.

The child was found in the empty Horse and Jockey pub at Newhall. A police spokesman said: "Police officers and paramedics went to search for the baby and found her dead. They tried to resuscitate her, but could not."

The teenager has been kept in hospital for treatment. Last night a Home Office pathologist carried out a post mortem to establish how the baby died.

 In Manchester, ambulance crews praised a nine-year-old who helped deliver her brother on Christmas Eve. Samantha Henchion came to the rescue when her mother, Priscilla, went into labour at their home in Chorlton-cum-Hardy. Samatha dialled 999 and followed instructions from the operator. When Andrew was born, weighing 6lbs, she covered him with a blanket and laid him in her mother's arms.

Samantha Henchion came to the rescue when her mother, Priscilla, went into labour at their home in Chorlton-cum-Hardy. Samatha dialled 999 and followed instructions from the operator. When Andrew was born, weighing 6lbs, she covered him with a blanket and laid him in her mother's arms.

webTitle: Leader: A spurned bouquet

fields.headline: A spurned bouquet
fields.standfirst:
The Princess Royal's recidivist moment

Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The Queen's audience ratings this Chrismas were down on last year - 9.8m now against 10.5m then. But that still put her clearly ahead of the Royles, on 8.3m. And deservedly so, for good though the Royle scripts are, their twists and turns are hardly a match for those that feature the real royal family.
fields.body:
The Queen's audience ratings this Chrismas were down on last year - 9.8m now against 10.5m then. But that still put her clearly ahead of the Royles, on 8.3m. And deservedly so, for good though the Royle scripts are, their twists and turns are hardly a match for those that feature the real royal family.

Every soap opera worth the name has a character whom audiences love to hate. For a time the role was played to perfection by Princess Anne. Her distinctive cry of "naff off" and unconcealed loathing for journalists made her a natural. But that changed. She worked tirelessly for good causes and reined back her former contempt. In Today programme terms, she graduated from villain to hero. Her brother Charles meanwhile, especially after the death of Princess Diana, had been moving the other way, disparaged in tabloids for green commitments and mildly eccentric ways. But that changed too. The public began to see him as a good father. Some of his views on sensitive subjects, from GM foods to the European rapid reaction force, now chime usefully with those of the Daily Mail.

So who's next? The answer arrived on Christmas Day. Among those waiting to see the family come out of church was 75-year-old Mary Halfpenny. She had spent many hours making a basket of flowers that she hoped to hand to Prince Harry to pass on to the Queen Mother. Instead, she complained, she had them snatched out of her hand by the Princess Royal, who said of her efforts: "What a ridiculous thing to do!" And when the Duke of York's daughters stopped to collect some flowers, Anne told them to get a move on.

The palace talked of a misunderstanding, while others suggested the princess might have been stressed because her daughter Zara had been in an accident. So maybe she will soon return to her former calm and cease upsetting pensioners. Though that of course will leave a hole in the script that will need to be filled pretty swiftly by somebody else.

webTitle: Unionist rage at jailbreak decision

fields.headline: Unionist rage at jailbreak decision
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: A decision effectively to pardon four IRA jailbreakers was seen by many in Northern Ireland yesterday as evidence of intense government efforts to overcome the paramilitary decommissioning deadlock threatening the political process.
fields.body:
A decision effectively to pardon four IRA jailbreakers was seen by many in Northern Ireland yesterday as evidence of intense government efforts to overcome the paramilitary decommissioning deadlock threatening the political process.

Some Unionists were furious at the symbolic move to allow Angelo Fusco, Robert Campbell, Paul Patrick Magee and Anthony Gerard Sloan to return to Northern Ireland without fear of rearrest.

Other sources speculated it was part of a choreographed sequence of moves to try to persuade the Provisionals to re-engage with General John de Chastelain's disarmament body, thus stopping Unionists pulling out of the power-sharing Stormont administration.

Sinn Fein's Gerry Kelly gave the news a qualified welcome. He said, however, it was "only the tip of the iceberg" and urged the government to act in hundreds of similar cases.

The four were part of an eight-man gang who shot their way out of north Belfast's Crumlin Road jail in June 1981. Fusco, Magee and Campbell were given life sentences in their absence for their roles in the murder of SAS captain Herbert Westmacott, shot dead in the city's Antrim Road in May 1980.

All four were later recaptured in the Irish Republic and served jail terms there but did not qualify for early release under the terms of the Good Friday agreement because they had been in prison less than two years in Northern Ireland.

Ulster Unionist deputy leader John Taylor condemned the decision as "deplorable" and said the four had been treated "far too liberally".

The Strangford MP thought they should have been brought to court in Northern Ireland and convicted, even though they would still be released in a short time.

webTitle: Mitterrand's son loses plea for immediate bail

fields.headline: Mitterrand's son loses plea for immediate bail
fields.standfirst: Lawyer calls postponed ruling 'a political move'
fields.trailText: The elder son of the late French president François Mitterrand will stay in jail for at least another five days while the police continue to investigate his alleged involvement in money laundering and illegal arms dealing.
fields.body:
The elder son of the late French president François Mitterrand will stay in jail for at least another five days while the police continue to investigate his alleged involvement in money laundering and illegal arms dealing.

A Paris appeal court accepted the public prosecutor's argument yesterday that the case against Jean-Christophe Mitterrand would be better served if he stayed in jail for the time being, and postponed its ruling on his request for bail until January 2 at the earliest.

Mr Mitterrant's lawyer, Jean-Pierre Versini-Campinchi, denounced the decision as a politically motivated attempt to discredit the Mitterrand family and said his client was "morally burned out" by the dishonour of his imprisonment, which he was at a loss to understand.

"There is nothing in the file, nothing at all," he said. "If his continued imprisonment is justified, we should be told why. There is no evidence whatsoever at this stage that would allow him to be detained."

Mr Mitterrand, who as head of the Elysée Palace's secretive "Africa cell" from 1986-1992 was his father's chief adviser on African affairs, was jailed last week on suspicion of influence peddling, complicity in arms trafficking and abuse of funds.

The potential charges relate to sales of Russian arms and military equipment to Angola in the early 1990s. The illicit deals, worth £350m, were allegedly put together by Brenco International, a company run by the French businessman Pierre Falcone, who was jailed on December 1 on suspicion of illegal arms dealing.

Investigators claim that Mr Mitterrand's privileged contacts with African leaders were crucial to these deals, and possibly several more, and say that Brenco paid £1.3m into his numbered Swiss bank account in the late 1990s.

Mr Mitterrand has denied knowledge of any arms deals, saying the money was his reward for legitimate consultancy work which helped Brenco to help President Jose Eduardo Dos Santos's government in Angola borrow money on the world market against future oil income.

Mr Versini-Campinchi said his client had "arranged introductions" for Mr Falcone in Angola which allowed him "to exchange contracts relating to inter-governmental bank loans for oil". He added: "This type of operation is worth billions of dollars and leads to certain commissions."

Angola has been devastated since its independence from Portugal in 1975 by a civil war between Mr Dos Santos's leftwing MPLA and Jonas Savimbi's Unita movement, which was backed for 15 years by the US and the South African apartheid regime.

An estimated 92% of Angola's national income comes from crude oil production. The lack of transparent accounting means there is no way of knowing exactly how much money is involved, or how it is spent, and allegations of kickbacks, corruption and theft by high-ranking officials are rife.

Some observers believe the oil-for-arms scam allegedly set up with Mr Mitterrand's help by Mr Falcone and his supposed associate Arkadi Gaidamak, a Russian businessman currently wanted under an international arrest warrant, is still in place.

Simon Taylor of Global Witness, a British NGO which has studied Angola in depth, believes at least one firm with a stake in Angolan oil may have links with Mr Falcone and Mr Gaidemak, both of whom are said to have been given Angolan citizenship.

Mr Mitterrand's arrest has come as yet another blow to his father's deteriorating reputation in France.

In an unusually hard-hitting editorial, Le Monde said last week that the secret deals hatched in the Elysée under Mr Mitterrand and others - and carried out in a complete legal vacuum - were "a disgrace for France and for Africa".

webTitle: Wansdyke byelection

fields.headline: Labour roots in a rural Tory setting
fields.standfirst:
Wansdyke

Special report: elections 2000
fields.trailText: Wansdyke
fields.body:
In the youth centre at Peasedown St John, between Bath and the Mendips, Father Christmas gave presents to pre-schoolers. Proud parents, who had a jumble sale to fund the treat, looked on with pride.

Despite its rural setting, the village has Labour roots as one of the communities which sustained the Somerset coalfield. The last pits closed in 1973, leaving a legacy which includes an active campaign - Justice for the West Miners - seeking belated compensation for mining-related illnesses. The area boasts a mining museum and old coal tips can still be spotted.

Most of the parents watching Santa voted Labour in 1997. Will they do so in the coming general election? It is far from clear. Good things are said about local hospitals and the primary school, which failed its Ofsted inspection but is picking up fast under a new-broom head, David Tilling.

The local MP, Labour's Dan Norris, is also known to people. "He's around, he holds surgeries and he listens," notes one approving father. "Tony Blair's done quite well, I think Labour will get back," adds a mum. But below the surface there are also resentments, among them the cost of petrol in rural communities which need their cars.

As for welfare-to-work, Gordon Brown's stern message has not yet reached Peasedown St John. Everyone can cite someone who is much better off on benefit than folk who work. "I go to work for my self-esteem. If I stopped working my income would double," concedes one father.

Whether or not the villagers vote in the election matters just as much as the suburban turnout in the 20,000-strong market town of Keynsham 10 miles away, or the swing votes from Tories and Lib Dems in the smart villages in between .

All helped make 40-year-old Mr Norris one of Labour's least-expected winners in the Blair landslide. He took the Wansdyke constituency on an above-average 14.4% swing after pushing the Liberal Democrats into third place at his first attempt in 1992 when the popular Tory MP, Jack Aspinall, stood for the last time.

Little wonder that William Hague, Francis Maude and Ann Widdecombe have all paid visits and promised plenty more when the election is called. Or that Nick Brown addressed irate local farmers, and that Peter Mandelson recently made two local appearances, one to speak to a dinner sponsored by successful businesses which the assiduously New Labour Norris has cultivated.

At first glance Wansdyke is a rock-solid Conservative seat which, if it was going to stray, should have gone Lib Dem, as several nearby seats have done. In villages where ancient cottages and council houses sit cheek-by-rose-bush with smart executive estates, built for Bath and Bristol commuters (all three types faced in Bath stone) there are pockets of poverty. Peasedown St John has its share.

But the Chew and Avon river valleys adjoin the hi-tech M4 corridor which stretches, via Swindon and Reading, almost to London. Unemployment has fallen fast since the mid-90s, even in the old mining areas around Midsomer Norton and Radstock which are beneficiaries of regeneration funds. Keynsham, halfway between thriving Bristol and the world heritage city of Bath, and home to Wansdyke's biggest employer - the Cadbury's factory - gives off a prosperous air.

"Norris is quite good," concedes a Tory voter emerging from the chip shop. "I've met him at a couple of the village dos, he's all right," says a well-dressed woman, an exile from Chelsea.

What seems to have happened in 1997 was a mixture of luck and judgment. Thanks to its mining past Labour's local roots never withered here. Mr Norris, a child protection social worker and ex-Avon/Bristol councillor with local ties, had been digging in since 1992, practising what he calls "pavement politics" to beat the Lib Dems at their own game. "If they put out a leaflet you have to put out one. If they put out two you have to match it."

It will be even harder for the Lib Dems in Wansdyke now that Paddy Ashdown no longer generates reflected glory from nearby Yeovil. "Charles Kennedy's a Scot," he notes drily. Mr Norris is a Quaker and wholesomely optimistic. But not that wholesome.

As the Blair bandwagon rolled in 1997 the anti-Tory tactical votes all swung his way, unlike neighbouring seats -Northavon and Somerton & Frome - which went Lib Dem. Gale Coleshill, the Lib Dem's new candidate, knows she faces an uphill struggle in an area where the party's regional energies have long been diverted elsewhere - to Yeovil or to Don Foster in Bath.

Equally aware of the daunting challenge is Chris Watt, the 32-year-old ex-army officer, now an IT specialist, who is trying to win Wansdyke back for William Hague at his first attempt to become an MP. His opponents tease Mr Watt as an accident-prone no-hoper and, worse, an outsider, though (like Mrs Coleshill) he is very-nearly-local, a Frome boy. He seems earnest, knowledgeable and committed, a self-styled "Euro-realist". But is that all enough to win next time ?

Probably not. There are issues which upset people that a Tory could exploit. The Bath and north-east Somerset council, which has a Lib Dem minority leadership, is underwriting a huge scheme to redevelop Bath's Roman Spa. Some think the whole area benefits from such investment. Others feel Wansdyke is the council's poor relation, that its schools are cash-strapped (Mr Norris shares the complaint), its cottage hospital at Paulton threatened by Alan Milburn's reforms.

Local road improvements on the A37 have been cancelled and John Prescott's house-building plans also threaten what is left of the treasured green belt between Keynsham and Bristol which may swallow it up (again). Wansdyke's local government boundaries have been redrawn more times than the Belgian frontier. In Radstock two deselected councillors, mother and son, stood as Independent Labour and won.

But is all this enough to unseat the pragmatic and hard-working Dan Norris? Voters, especially Tory voters, are casually dismissive of William Hague and his prospects. "People don't like him," explains a shopper outside the superstore in Radstock.

Mr Norris has his setbacks too. His pragmatism does not extend to hunting. "It's just not a civilised thing to do," says the Labour MP with two hunts on his patch. He campaigns fiercely against it. But not a single voter mentions the issue in the street. That won't lose him Wansdyke either.

1997 results

webTitle: A year of dance

fields.headline: Great leaps forward
fields.standfirst: This was the year that the Kirov Ballet enchanted, Merce Cunningham thrilled and Elvis lived again. By Judith Mackrell
fields.trailText: This was the year that the Kirov Ballet enchanted, Merce Cunningham thrilled and Elvis lived again. By Judith Mackrell.
fields.body:
The A-Z of dance-going changed significantly in the year 2000. The changes were most pronounced in London, where the glossy new Opera House launched into its full ballet season; the Place Theatre closed down for major refurbishment; and the ROH's Linbury Studio Theatre became the glamorous new venue for small-scale modern dance. (Not that the ROH management have quite got the hang of the appropriate style, despite their resolution to appear hip and audience-friendly for the new millennium. There's something charmingly fuddy-duddy about their insistence on announcing, even before some subversive new dance show, that intervals will take place between "the acts".)

With the recently rebuilt Sadler's Wells having swung confidently into its own intensive dance programming, and the Coliseum and the Barbican sustaining their commitment to the art form, 2000 proved a busy year, especially for foreign visits. The most high profile were the Kirov Ballet (performing two sell-out seasons in three months), who brought over a lavish reconstruction of the 1890 staging of Petipa's Sleeping Beauty. This lasted nearly four hours, yet audiences were enchanted by the gaudy period opulence of the costumes and by the leisurely sociability that infused dance and mime scenes alike. With a cast of hundreds, it made other productions look positively meagre.

Other welcome visitors included the Paul Taylor Company, finally giving the UK premiere of Taylor's masterly comic version of The Rite of Spring; also Mark Morris, collaborating with the singers and orchestra of English National Opera for a two-week season. The focus should have been Morris's commissioned staging of the Virgil Thomson/ Gertrude Stein opera, Four Saints in Three Acts, but this proved to be an oddly reticent production.

The Barbican played host to Merce Cunningham's Biped, performed as part of Dance Umbrella 2000. Cunningham has long been a fan of new technology and in this new, spectacularly ambitious piece he incorporated computer-generated imagery into the live performance. Real and virtual bodies danced together while the stage was transformed by vaulting digital scenery to create the impression that the vast, magical dance was taking place in a futuristic cathedral.

Outside London, the Lowry in Salford also changed the map. Despite being furnished in the manner of a P&O liner, its stage is big enough to house the world's biggest dance companies, and one of the most august, Paris Opera, opened the theatre with Nureyev's opulent production of La Bayadère . This was the company's first UK season for 21 years, and reminded us that while some of its dancers may lack dramatic sparkle, they are stylistically honed to a phenomenal pitch of elegance. The Lowry has continued to deliver the goods for dance fans all year with high quality and inventive programming.

The activity south of the border took the edge off Edinburgh's role as the presenter of the biggest and best in UK dance. Though the festival persuaded New York City Ballet to venture here after an 11-year absence, the company's brief season proved to be disappointingly mixed - a fabulous repertoire performed by dancers whose youngest stars lacked personality and nerve.

Questions have also been hanging over the Royal Ballet as Anthony Dowell leads his final season as director. Speculation about his successor was rife, though the final choice of Australian Ballet's Ross Stretton was a let-down since so few had heard of him.

Dowell's 14-year tenure may have been controversial, but his farewell season has so far been magnificent. He has exhumed old treasures from the repertoire, including Ashton's Marguerite and Armand and Tudor's Lilac Garden, and in the process given two more major roles to Sylvie Guillem who, at 35, is mellowing into an artist of extraordinary subtlety and power. He has also brought in a new generation of dancers from around the world, ready to follow the footsteps of home-grown stars such as Darcey Bussell.

Modern dance has displayed more consolidation than revelation, with Richard Alston and the much junior Wayne MacGregor creating some of their best work in ages and soloists such as David Hughes and Akram Kahn continuing to promise good things. Siobhan Davies presented a major new work but with it signalled her intention to retire for 18 months while she finds a permanent base for her company. It remains a national scandal that this gifted, grown-up artist is still scrabbling around for places to work. Adventures in Motion Pictures announced an end to their own nomadic existence after gratefully accepting the Old Vic's invitation to become company in residence. Their latest show, The Car Man, disappointed some by not being Swan Lake but boasted fine performances from the excellent Will Kemp and newcomer Alan Vincent. The company also got a boost from featuring as the aspirational destiny of Billy Elliot in Stephen Daldry's boots-to-ballet shoes movie.

Dance also hit the headlines with two of the year's oddest shows. Peter Schaufuss's Elvis ballet, The King, had to be hastily revised due to copyright issues relating to Presley's music and life (Elvis was thus morphed into an English singer who hits the big time in Blackpool). Maurice Béjart's Ballet for Life, meanwhile, was a tribute to Freddie Mercury, and the greatest moment amid two hours of tat was when the surviving members of Queen shuffled on stage for the curtain call.
fields.bodyText: The A-Z of dance-going changed significantly in the year 2000. The changes were most pronounced in London, where the glossy new Opera House launched into its full ballet season; the Place Theatre closed down for major refurbishment; and the ROH's Linbury Studio Theatre became the glamorous new venue for small-scale modern dance. (Not that the ROH management have quite got the hang of the appropriate style, despite their resolution to appear hip and audience-friendly for the new millennium. There's something charmingly fuddy-duddy about their insistence on announcing, even before some subversive new dance show, that intervals will take place between "the acts".) With the recently rebuilt Sadler's Wells having swung confidently into its own intensive dance programming, and the Coliseum and the Barbican sustaining their commitment to the art form, 2000 proved a busy year, especially for foreign visits. The most high profile were the Kirov Ballet (performing two sell-out seasons in three months), who brought over a lavish reconstruction of the 1890 staging of Petipa's Sleeping Beauty. This lasted nearly four hours, yet audiences were enchanted by the gaudy period opulence of the costumes and by the leisurely sociability that infused dance and mime scenes alike. With a cast of hundreds, it made other productions look positively meagre. Other welcome visitors included the Paul Taylor Company, finally giving the UK premiere of Taylor's masterly comic version of The Rite of Spring; also Mark Morris, collaborating with the singers and orchestra of English National Opera for a two-week season. webTitle: A year of buildings

fields.headline: Glory days
fields.standfirst: Magnificent new buildings dominated the visual arts in 2000. And the boldest and best of them all was Tate Modern. Adrian Searle looks back on a memorable year.
fields.trailText: Magnificent new buildings dominated the visual arts in 2000. And the boldest and best of them all was Tate Modern. Adrian Searle looks back on a memorable year
fields.body:
We expected the future, but it feels like the past: as yet, I am still not sure whether I have yet seen any truly 21st-century art. I guess I was looking for something futuristic, preferably with fins, gizmos and telepathic auras. Instead, I think it was a patch of light on a glass in a Chardin painting and a film of Steve McQueen playing with his nipple that really got to me.

The year 2000 was a year of buildings: the opening of the small but perfectly formed New Art Gallery in Walsall, refurbishments for the National Portrait Gallery, Dulwich Picture Gallery and the British Museum, and the opening, in May, of Tate Modern. This last, surely, was the most significant art event in Britain in 2000.

One snooty American commentator - Jed Perl - decried what he saw as the confusion of Tate Modern, and how hard it was for the public to actually find their way beyond the Turbine Hall into the galleries themselves. Well, upwards of 3m people have made it to the Claude Monet-meets-Richard Long moment, around the Fluxus fun-zone and into the minimalist hardware area, though some might find it odd that all that industrially fabricated metal is in the portion of the Tate devoted to the body. Yet a glance at the walls themselves, the heel scuffs and bum-marks, provide proof that lots of sweaty, grubby bodies have indeed been here.

Tate Modern has several problems, not the least being the sheer numbers that pass through it every day. It is always showtime. Behind the scenes, we hear of curators run ragged, of too much expected of too few, disaffection and machinations in the vault. At Tate Britain, the mix-and-match hang is a disaster. Playing games with history, with genres and movements can work, but only if there's a genuine point to be made. It also needs to be done with a sensitive eye. Curatorship and scholarship in an art museum need to be allied with an acute visual sense - which involves, among other things, a sensitivity to space and placement, to visual rhymes and contrasts, and an acute appreciation of what happens when you juxtapose one thing with another, and how oppositions and alignments and changes in scale and material generate new meanings all their own. Too many curators can't deal with this, even though they like to think of themselves as working on equal terms with artists. Which is precisely why they're not.

I remain unashamed at shedding a tear outside Tate Modern on opening night last May. It wasn't just the drink, or the hilarity of a surreal moment when Tony Blair's bodyguards got tangled up with Yoko Ono's designer minders, and the surgically improved French artist Orlan wandered oblivious - with her budding horns implanted in her forehead - through the melee. It felt for a moment there as if the opening of Tate Modern signified the centrality of contemporary art to British culture in a way it that had never been acknowledged before. London felt like a big important European city, and one with high cultural ambitions. That night felt like a vindication. But maybe it was only the drink after all; buildings and parties are one thing, looking at art another.

Some of the best shows I have seen in 2000 aren't tractable to the oversimplifications of the explanatory wall panel or a neat little curatorial theme. Close to Tate Modern, in the Delfina project space, Turner prize-winner Steve McQueen showed an alarming film that focused entirely on the artist's fingers and thumb tweaking and pulling at his tit, which filled the screen. Why was this so compelling, such an extraordinary work? I wrote about it, at some length, at the time, but still its meaning - in part undeniably erotic, but certainly not only so - remains elusive. It is a work which refuses to be contained, or killed, by its interpreters. It was a work that didn't illustrate anything, didn't have a message, but that had all sorts of unexpected resonances.

The same can be said of the Royal Academy's Chardin exhibition. For all that focus on dead game, and still lifes of objects which have little intrinsic interest in themselves, Chardin is still elusive, breathtaking, disquieting and moving. It isn't even a matter of his undeniable skill and perspicacity as a painter, so much as it is that sense of unerring focus, an almost fixated contemplation of the world revealed by light, of degrees of opacity and transparency, which his paintings declare. And when he painted people - including himself - they were invariably people in that same state of hesitancy, contemplation, of a kind of irreducible being, that the painter evinced through the act of painting. What complex paintings he made, and without recourse to steamy subject matter, flashiness, appeal to fashion or this or that issue, gridlocked by theory.

Every year, the Turner prize manages to garland itself with just the above qualities, yet the feeling was that the show was a trifle dull this year. The new Euro-Turner - the Vincent, held in Maastricht - was a much more intelligent, if low-key exhibition. The only British-based artist, Oladele Ajiboye Bamgboye, was the youngest in the shortlist, yet there was a genuine sense that the line-up (which also included Luc Tuymans, Karsten Holler, Miroslaw Balka, Eija-Liisa Ahtila and Pedro Cabrita Reis) had all achieved a level of artistic maturity and individuality which made the question of who should win irrelevant. It was a serious show of serious art. Maybe it wasn't sexy enough.

At least this year's Turner, with three foreign contenders, acknowledged the fact that art is intellectually - as well as commercially - international. I hate the bolstering of Britishness, however good some British artists are, even though we've all got to come from somewhere. Good for Wolfgang Tillmans, too, for delivering the only elegant speech I have ever heard from a Turner winner. The context, however, is bigger than these islands, and the continuing vitality of current Britart depends on its dialogues with elsewhere, even if - like Richard Billingham, whose work couldn't be closer to home - one's subject is determinedly local.

As a dialogue with elsewhere, and with history, Rachel Whiteread's Holocaust Memorial, finally unveiled last month after five and a half years of wrangling and Austrian intrigues, demonstrated that art does have a place in the moral consciousness, and that modern art, like the art of the past, has a place in the world. And that it can have dignity, reserve, and a kind of endurance. Like Lutyens' Cenotaph, it is a kind of locus for feelings and beliefs, even if we aren't always sure what those feelings are, what beliefs we ought to have.

webTitle: Diary

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: We left the Diary Awards lunch at the Savoy with Barbara Roche and Taki-George just back from St Thomas's hospital after their contretemps with Boris the Jackal Johnson.
fields.body:
We left the Diary Awards lunch at the Savoy with Barbara Roche and Taki-George just back from St Thomas's hospital after their contretemps with Boris the Jackal Johnson. Once they had settled down, we considered the matter of Press Release of the Year.

The Rev Steve Chalke was quick to declare an interest and withdraw, pointing out that one entry - "Why Jesus would have gone to Anthea and Grant's wedding by the Baptist minister who married them" - concerned himself. In the event, Steve came third behind Hampshire county council, which reported a survey revealing that 80% of visitors to Hampshire libraries go there to borrow books.

However, the Most Amusing Press Release came from Maxima Group plc. "In just two years, Maxima has investigated corporate frauds for an impressive list of clients worldwide," the document explained, "and has helped recover assets totalling $1bn (made up figure - could we conjure up a more authentic one? Journalists are impressed by such nonsense)."

 The Woodrow Wyatt Golden Cigar Cutter for Dinner Party Discretion went to Roger Liddle. Paul Johnson recalled the BBC dinner party at which Mr Tony's adviser on European policy announced that the government had no European policy at all. Later, when asked about rumours of tension between Mr T and Gordon Brown, Roger snorted and said they loathed each other like poison. The rest of the panel agreed with my sane and rational friend, so hats off Roger!

 The panel was split over Letter of the Year. Rizla Rosie Boycott, giggling alarmingly and sending Taki-George out for a family size bar of Whole Nut, proposed Michael Henderson for his "capacious arse" letter to me.

Although Paul Johnson agreed, Hendo settled for second place again (he was runner up in the soothsaying category) when Rev Steve and Liam Fox supported Barbara Roche's nomination. Peter Hain wins for the letter to the editor savaging our claim that he had "blocked" a humanitarian flight to Iraq on the grounds that he had in fact "placed it on hold".

 There was no dispute over the Andrew Ridgeley Silver Shuttlecock for Motoring. This went to the Diary for its stewardship of Corniche Convertible RR1. Within 30 minutes of getting the £250,000 car in Crewe, I had broken the cassette player. An hour later, I drove it into the wall of a Leeds car park.

Returning to London on the M1, finally, I put the engine into reverse at 90. By way of revenge, the RR press office limited itself to dobbing me to the police when the speeding ticket reached Crewe (the second ticket of the year following an earlier effort in a BMW).

 When Taki-George bought a bunch of red grapes to the table, Dr Liam Fox was reminded of a joke: a man with terrible piles is told by his friend to pack tea leaves around his bottom, but when this fails he goes to the doctor (a man Liam portrayed as having a Peter Sellers comedy Indian accent). The doctor examines him very closely and does some tutting. "I'm very sorry I can't do anything for your piles," he tells him, "but you're going on a long journey."

 It was at this stage that matters moved out of hand again. The Rev Steve Chalke, an Anglo-Indian who runs a large charity on the sub-continent, took offence at this gag and lapsed into some startlingly unChristian language. Another break was enforced before Dr Fox made his customary apology and we reconvened to decide the remaining awards, news of which will be here tomorrow.

webTitle: Comment: Rightly foxed by the threat to ban

fields.headline: Rightly foxed by the threat to ban
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Maybe it is all that bouncing about on the backs of horses. Or maybe it's just a feature of any fight to the death. But how can one explain the hypocrisy, chop logic and outright lying now being mustered daily in defence of hunting with hounds?
fields.body:
Maybe it is all that bouncing about on the backs of horses. Or maybe it's just a feature of any fight to the death. But how can one explain the hypocrisy, chop logic and outright lying now being mustered daily in defence of hunting with hounds?

Though the Telegraph, with its huntsman editor, is usually worst, a ripe example occurred in yesterday's Times, where Richard D North saluted "wonderful news": a Channel 4 poll had found a majority in favour of saving hunting. True, 46.6% still back an outright ban - but 46.7% support leaving things as they are.

But this was not a real poll. It was based on that lowest form of public opinion exercise, the survey based on a self-selecting sample. People who make a meal of such evidence when there's better around are invariably up to no good. If you want a true account, an NOP poll before Christmas told a different story: 48% want to see the "sport" stopped; a mere 14%, despite all those acres of newspaper propaganda, want to save it.

The remainder favour action short of an outright ban - the kind of so far vaguely defined solution put up by the Third Way group of MPs and endorsed by Jack Straw. But specifically repudiated, note, by that voice of the hunting fraternity, the Daily Telegraph as an unacceptable compromise, because it seems to admit, which they won't, that present practice is cruel.

Let us move to the realms of philosophy, where we might if we're lucky come across the pink-jacketed person of Roger Scruton. "Hunting with hounds," he wrote in last week's New Statesman, "raises the fox from vermin to quarry. It accords him a respect that is never shown to his fellow pest, the rat." And maybe that's right. Maybe, even as the hounds sink their fatal teeth into its neck, the dying fox consoles itself with the thought that in the very moment of death it has somehow attained a higher existence.

"At least I am no longer vermin," it tells itself as the life blood ebbs. "I'm a step ahead of the rat. And more than that: only the chase could have brought me into contact with so elevated a soul as Professor Scruton." But it's hard to square that defence with another now doing the rounds. This is that the hunt only does to the fox what the fox - that unprincipled dealer of death to defenceless chickens and lambs - routinely does every day.

Far from elevating the fox to a higher status, this reduces human status to that of the fox. Which may be why there is now emerging a curious variant of this defence, which says that it isn't really people who do the hunting, only the hounds and the horses, with the people in pink as observers, attendants, advisers, guarantors of fair play, and so on.

The hunt is defended too in broader sociological terms as a sort of glue that binds the country together. This is a favourite claim of the playwright John Mortimer, always a welcome contributor to pro-hunting newspapers who then cite him as proof that the case for saving the hunt is understood even by socialists (a group to which they think he belongs). It is also the raison d'etre of that spurious organisation, the Countryside Alliance, which, aware that simply defending hunting was a lost cause, sought to bind it together with other more genuine grievances prevalent in the countryside.

But this too is bogus. It cannot be hunting that binds countryside communities together, since great tracts of the British Isles have no hunt at all. Yet a further conclusion then gets built on this rackety basis. The assault on hunting, it's said, is really part of a wider attack on rural values by an essentially urban government.

That assumes that while townies, in their ignorance, favour a ban, country people, knowing better, resolve that hunting must stay. Yet all the genuine polling evidence, as distinct from the phoney kind, shows that opposition to hunting far outstrips support for it in the countryside, as well as in towns. One can, I think, see lurking within this contention the proud old Tory belief that governments of the left are somehow illegitimate, not what the British want: the product of electoral aberration in a country that, when in its senses, will always pick a government of the right.

Let us be wary too of some of these new-found champions of civil liberty, such as Sam Butler, chairman of the Campaign for Hunting, who on Boxing Day promised the biggest civil rights demonstration ever seen in Britain or even in Europe. How many of those attending will ever have raised a finger for any civil rights cause except this one? They may preach civil rights, but for many the only right that counts is the right to pursue an ugly pastime that they fear an elected parliament may soon snatch away from them.

Which may be why there is now emerging a curious variant of this defence, which says that it isn't really people who do the hunting, only the hounds and the horses, with the people in pink as observers, attendants, advisers, guarantors of fair play, and so on. The hunt is defended too in broader sociological terms as a sort of glue that binds the country together. This is a favourite claim of the playwright John Mortimer, always a welcome contributor to pro-hunting newspapers who then cite him as proof that the case for saving the hunt is understood even by socialists (a group to which they think he belongs). It is also the raison d'etre of that spurious organisation, the Countryside Alliance, which, aware that simply defending hunting was a lost cause, sought to bind it together with other more genuine grievances prevalent in the countryside. But this too is bogus. It cannot be hunting that binds countryside communities together, since great tracts of the British Isles have no hunt at all. Yet a further conclusion then gets built on this rackety basis. The assault on hunting, it's said, is really part of a wider attack on rural values by an essentially urban government. That assumes that while townies, in their ignorance, favour a ban, country people, knowing better, resolve that hunting must stay. Yet all the genuine polling evidence, as distinct from the phoney kind, shows that opposition to hunting far outstrips support for it in the countryside, as well as in towns. One can, I think, see lurking within this contention the proud old Tory belief that governments of the left are somehow illegitimate, not what the British want: the product of electoral aberration in a country that, when in its senses, will always pick a government of the right. Let us be wary too of some of these new-found champions of civil liberty, such as Sam Butler, chairman of the Campaign for Hunting, who on Boxing Day promised the biggest civil rights demonstration ever seen in Britain or even in Europe. How many of those attending will ever have raised a finger for any civil rights cause except this one? They may preach civil rights, but for many the only right that counts is the right to pursue an ugly pastime that they fear an elected parliament may soon snatch away from them. david.mckie@theguardian.com

webTitle: Japan's stagnating economy

fields.headline: Japan's secret shame
fields.standfirst: The world sees Japan as a rich, successful country. But the economy is stagnating, big companies are going bust, and workers are facing the unthinkable - the end of jobs for life. Jon Snow on an unreported disaster.
fields.trailText: The world sees Japan as a rich, successful country. But the economy is stagnating, big companies are going bust, and workers are facing the unthinkable - the end of jobs for life.  Jon Snow on an unreported disaster
fields.body:
The blade caught the morning sun. Despite the gloom beneath the bridge, I'd seen enough to know that it was at least the size of a carving knife. This man meant business. Even though we were on the other side of the river talking with other homeless men, he had clearly decided he was going to see to us. With a roar he grabbed his old bicycle, charged up the embankment and headed straight for us.

There was a block of flats a few hundred yards away. Our film crew of four split up, and headed for different stairwells. Four floors up Mayu, a Japanese journalist working with us, was hammering on doors begging to be let in. The crazed knife wielder was closing in.

As suddenly as he had come after us, he disappeared. We sneaked down the hallways and out on to the street again. In seconds he was back - but this time he had the police with him. An amazing sight, here was a dishevelled vagrant, ordering first two, then three, then five, and finally eight policemen to arrest us. And arrest us they did. Two squad cars, and even the superintendent's limo attended the scene.

Our first night in Kyoto was spent in the cells. In the chaos of our arrest, Mayu had become separated, so that only the three white men of our team found themselves behind bars. The complainant arrived, still on his bicycle, but with no knife, about 10 minutes after our arrest.

Our lingually-challenged confinement and eventual release lasted three and a half hours, and occupied the attention of all eight of the arresting officers. There is little crime in Kyoto, but there is much homelessness. Yet even the homeless have powers when foreigners come to call. They may have no social security, but they can still make a citizen's arrest.

Somehow, you don't expect this rich, successful, country to sport rows of cardboard box homes with desolate hungry men and women beneath every span in town. Ten bridges in Kyoto, 10-20 beneath each - I suppose we met at least 200 homeless people, and there were clearly many more that that. It is a new phenomenon that has hit a society that has almost no provision for coping. For pride is the Japanese watchword and nothing assaults pride so much as the loss of everything else, hence the ire and fury that accompanied the threatening blade beneath the city's most westerly road bridge over the Kamog river.

Japan is in unreported trouble. Sure, the statistics reveal little more than 0% growth for the past 10 years, a massaged 1.5% this past six months that has already dribbled to nothing. But they tell you nothing of the precipice this country is hurtling toward.

Back under the next bridge, Hajime Tanaka, slurped tea. He had run a small business, lost it, lost his wife and his three children, and now he had lost his home. His pride, like his dirty white gloves, was still just about intact as he scoured the river banks for cans. He can make £7 a day selling them in a country where the average wage is £500 a week.

Takashi Matsuta is only a fraction luckier. A kimono weaver, his breathtakingly fine woven wasteband lies on the table in front of his loom in the upstairs room of a sweatshop. He earns no money, but is kept by the factory owner, a distant cousin. The bottom has fallen out of the Kimono industry.

We were travelling the Tokaido Way - the old 400-mile imperial route that led from the former capital to Tokyo. Travelling in a G7 economic powerhouse, an industrial miracle maker - the birthplace of my hi-fi, my microwave, my television, even the Walkman on my belt - yet now an undiscussed disaster on its knees. Even so, we don't know it, and many of them don't either. We had been sent here to find out if the recession was over, if Japan was coming back.

The dense elongated concrete coastal sprawl that spawned Japan's success still feels prosperous, the trains run, the neon flashes and the cranes sprout above the skyline. But, like the white gloves of the homeless scavenger, appearances in Japan are deceptive. Beyond the convenience stores, the gambling halls and the noodle bars, there is an event taking place that dwarfs any postwar recession Britain has experienced.

You can hear the factory in Hamatsu where Yamaha makes grand pianos long before you enter it. Infernal robotic fingers drum the keyboards for hours on end to see if they fall apart. It is strange to see so singular a thing as a concert grand in unfurnished rows of twenty. Four hundred people work here, four hundred jobs for life. Like all old Japanese businesses, Yamaha looks after its workforce from the cradle to the grave. Except that suddenly it can't. It has already laid off more than 1,000. The world's appetite for grand pianos is sated. Mayu sat at a £7,700 grand and played sumptuous Schubert. Tears welled in the manager's eye. He knows there's a problem; I don't think the workforce does.

Further along the Tokaido, as we arrived in Toyota, they announced the closure of its biggest superstore, Sogo, and another 20 elsewhere in Japan. Sogo is the heart of Toyota. The next day the country's second biggest life assurance company went belly up with debts of £25bn.

Have we hit a particularly unfortunate week in Japanese history, or is this business as usual?

The Japanese bubble, when times were good, saw the Toyota car company so pressed for labour that Japanese migrants who had gone a century earlier to Brazil were encouraged to come home.

Past the doomed Sogo store and up the hill we could hear the Saturday night partying as soon as we opened the car door. Inside there were entirely Japanese-looking people cavorting around doing the samba and the bossanova. Many of these "returnees" speak not a word of Japanese. The quiet, introverted, indigenous Japanese resent the bizarre bangs, crashes and whoops that accompany a good time for these people. The conflict has turned so tense that a police unit has been formed to bring the two communities together.

Japan is ageing so fast that the UN estimates that 600,000 immigrant workers will be needed over the next couple of years to keep the place going even in a recession. Yet as the tension in Toyota shows, even their own forebears have a rough time. Traditional Japanese xenophobia is unlikely to take any more kindly to the Indians, Chinese and Vietnamese knocking at the country's door.

The piledrivers, barge cranes and construction boats dominate the Takonome skyline. Out at sea they are building yet another multi million pound airport. Nobody needs it - the new, offshore Kyoto airport is just down the road. But the mayor, Seikoh Ishibiashi, has secured the deal as a means of boosting the local economy. The construction companies have already been prosecuted for paying wads of yens to local officials, who have got away with suspended sentences. The whole project is adding to the 700 trillion yen (£4.3 trillion) national debt which leaves Japan the most indebted industrialised country in the world.

So who's worried? Certainly not the upper political echelons; for them it's business as usual. Certainly not the managing dirctor of the telecom offshoot NTT DoCoMo. Keiji Tachikawa told me: "Leave us alone for another 10 years and we'll fix it." Other, younger Japanese men and women are not so sanguine. Junichi Izumi is a young internet entrepreneur. Japanese does not fit well with the internet revolution and he is toiling against the stream. But he is convinced the old guard who run Japan don't even understand what it is. "In the summer," he told me "prime minister Mori kept calling the IT revolution the it revolution."

The day we left Tokyo the minister of economic planning, Taichi Sakaiya, announced a £64bn economic renewal programme. "It's focused on IT," he told me. Closer inspection revealed still more construction projects. Sure, the new Tokyo sewerage system does have an IT element, sophiticated computer sensors for checking sewage levels. Japanese politicians, alas, appear to be subject to no such monitoring system.

So why don't people talk about Japan's perilous economic state? Is it just too big to worry about, too far away, too impenetrable, too threatening to the global financial structures?

As I was leaving the minister's office, another vast life assurance company, Kyoei, had just announced that it too was going bust with debts of £30bn.

webTitle: Pass notes: Kirsty Gallacher

fields.headline: No: 1788 Kirsty Gallacher
fields.trailText: Looks like a classy bird: That's none other than Miss Kirsty Gallacher, top television sports presenter.
fields.body:
Looks like a classy bird: That's none other than Miss Kirsty Gallacher, top television sports presenter.

And where can I find this TV temptress? Well, on Skysports.com TV on Sky Digital, for starters. And frolicking around in her scanties on the glossy, wipe-clean pages of this month's edition of the quality men's magazine Maxim.

Schwwinnng! Surely you mean "swing"?

I am sure Kirsty is not that kind of girl. No, I am talking about her abilities on the green. Her father is none other than golfing legend and Ryder Cup captain, Bernard Gallacher. He reckons young Kirsty could have made it as a pro.

So she's got good ball control and a strong wrist action? If you want to put it like that.

Believe me, I do. So what's the problem? Well, it seems all Kirsty wants is to be taken seriously as a sports journalist.

Don't we all? Absolutely. But only this October, Kirsty claimed: "I want people to respect me and I don't want to be photographed everywhere, appearing in the press with nothing on."

Oops! Oops, indeed.

How can we explain this little moral confusion? A certain naked ambition, perhaps?

Really? Oh, yes. Kirsty, who began her working life as a tea girl, admits she now has an eye on making her big-screen debut. She dreams of being a kickboxing Bond girl.

So it's Hollywood or bust? It would seem so.

And how old is this buxom lovely? Twenty-three.

Barely a slip of a thing. Quite. Although it does seem rather inappropriate attire for December.

Perhaps she's naturally hot- blooded? It would appear so.

Do say: Your father must have been a thief, because he stole the stars out of the Sky and placed them in your eyes.

Don't say: Your father must have been a pirate because you've got a lovely chest.

webTitle: Museum reunites fragments of a war-torn masterpiece

fields.headline: Artistic act of bravery pieced together
fields.standfirst: Museum reunites fragments of a war-torn masterpiece
fields.trailText: Museum reunites fragments of a war-torn masterpiece.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
An exhibition at Leicester city museum is reassembling the fragments of an artist's life and work shattered by the rise of Nazism. The name of Johannes Matthaeus Koelz is scarcely remembered now, but in the 1920s he was regarded as one of the most brilliant German artists of his generation.

Koelz, who won the Iron Cross for his courage in the first world war, was forced to flee Germany after refusing to paint Hitler's portrait in 1937. He was given 48 hours warning of his impending arrest, and before he fled he cut his greatest work, a monumental anti-war triptych, into 25 pieces.

Most pieces were entrusted to family and friends to hide, but he carried some in his rucksack when he escaped the country by wading across a border river, and somehow kept them safely through the tumultuous years that followed.

His daughter Ava Farrington presented four fragments inherited from her father, one from a former neighbour, to the Leicester museum in 1998.

Since then two more have been traced in Germany. One is owned by the sister of the sawmill owner who helped Koelz cut the work. Another is owned by a retired dentist, who appears in the picture as a baby. Both regard their pictures as so precious, emblems of their own survival through the war and its aftermath in Germany, that they cannot bear to lend them, though photographic replicas are being created. "The fact that these pieces survived has given us great hope that most of the other pieces also survive," said Simon Lake, curator of the exhibition. "We have until March before the exhibition opens, it will run for six months, and we are still optimistic that more fragments may surface, as word spreads.

"It is the most extraordinary story, of a life marked by astonishing luck, both bad and good. There is no doubt that he was a major artist, who would be numbered among the greats if his life had gone otherwise. We hope to put his name and his work back where people can see them for the first time."

The entire painting - entitled Thou Shalt Not Kill - of kneeling figures including German soldiers surrounding a crucified soldier in a gas mask, was known from photographs taken in 1933. Koelz had also published anti-war poems, under the guise of Johannes Matthaeus, and as news of his triptych spread, he was beginning to be regarded as a highly suspicious character.

However, as a Catholic who had been officially declared Aryan, and a decorated hero who had rescued several soldiers by digging them out of a crater, his work was still accepted by the establishment, and was bought by major museums. In 1937 he was invited to paint a portrait of Hitler. He refused the commission and realised his hour had come.

A sympathetic police chief warned that he would keep the consequent arrest warrant in his desk for 48 hours, and two days later Koelz had cut up and hidden the painting and fled the country with his wife, son and daughter.

When the family reached England, three years later, he was interned as an enemy alien, and shipped to Australia in atrocious conditions. After the war he worked as an art teacher, and lived in England and Ireland, and died in 1971 in Stoke on Trent. Although he continued to work, he never produced a painting on the scale of the lost triptych.

His daughter, who lives in Leicestershire, traced her father's life through papers, letters and journals.

Leicester museum itself has been through troubled times. It suffered the dubious distinction of being the most heavily cut museum service in the country last year, with its budgets slashed by more than 50%. A further round of threatened cuts in the next financial year has apparently been averted after the Guardian publicised its plight this year.

Research for this exhibition has been done on a shoestring. Leicester's last major exhibition, on Victorian childhood, cost £25,000 to mount.

A Life Divided is being done for under £10,000, which is still over a third of the annual exhibition budget for the entire museum service."The exhibition is a tribute to the resilience and ingenuity of our staff," said its director, Sarah Levitt.

webTitle: Leader: The time has come for a TV experiment

fields.headline: Cases in camera
fields.standfirst:
The time has come for a TV experiment

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Lawyers were adopting a St Augustine of Hippo ("make me chaste, but not yet") approach to reform yesterday: our front page report on moves by Labour to allow television cameras into court was met with considerable caution by the legal establishment - even though it coincided with an appeal from the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, to make the legal system more approachable. The chairman of the Law Society's criminal law committee conceded that changes that bring the law closer to the public were to be welcomed, but warned that "individual citizens appearing in courts, whether they be witnesses or defendants, have to have proper safeguards". An MSP and lawyer, Gordon Jackson, was more critical, suggesting the Scottish experiment with televising courts had shown it "distorts and trivialises, puts pressure on witnesses and changes the dynamics of the court".
fields.body:
Lawyers were adopting a St Augustine of Hippo ("make me chaste, but not yet") approach to reform yesterday: our front page report on moves by Labour to allow television cameras into court was met with considerable caution by the legal establishment - even though it coincided with an appeal from the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, to make the legal system more approachable. The chairman of the Law Society's criminal law committee conceded that changes that bring the law closer to the public were to be welcomed, but warned that "individual citizens appearing in courts, whether they be witnesses or defendants, have to have proper safeguards". An MSP and lawyer, Gordon Jackson, was more critical, suggesting the Scottish experiment with televising courts had shown it "distorts and trivialises, puts pressure on witnesses and changes the dynamics of the court".

Both failed to understand the new proposal. Neither jury trials nor magistrates' cases would be open to cameras. The aim is to open up hearings confined to lawyers and judges - appeal court cases, judicial reviews and law lords' hearings. This is quite different from Scotland, which in 1992 allowed cameras access to civil and criminal hearings, subject to strict regulation: all parties due to be filmed - judges, prosecution, defence, witnesses - have to agree, and there can be no live transmission. The result was a six-part BBC documentary looking at different trials and their background shown in 1994 and repeated in 1996.

The proposal for England and Wales would not see a rush of TV producers or a clamour from television viewers. Most cases involved in the proposed hearings would be extremely boring for the average viewer - involving abstruse arguments, abstract philosophical assertions, and highly detailed references back to earlier legal rulings. webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: China widens its corruption net
fields.body:
China widens its corruption net

The vice-mayor of Hangzhou in eastern China has been arrested for taking "large amounts of money and gifts" in what President Jiang Zemin called the latest move in the "long-term and arduous struggle" for clean government, it emerged yesterday.

Ye Defan was detained with 20 other government officials. The move came as the prime minister, Zhu Rongji, promised "serious punishment" of those responsible for the shopping centre fire in Luoyang at the weekend which killed 309. Reuters, Beijing

Estrada court calls minister

The senate impeachment court trying the Philippine president, Joseph Estrada, for bribery, corruption and betrayal of public trust has summoned the defence minister and three senior bank executives, court officials said yesterday.

The development heaps more pressure on Mr Estrada, who was badly damaged last week by evidence that he had signed an agreement to invest $10m (£6.7m), 14 times his declared assets, through a local bank. Reuters, Manila

Border patrol for African troops

West African defence ministers and army chiefs met in the Nigerian capital Abuja yesterday to finalise plans to deploy troops along the borders of Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone to prevent the region sliding into instability.

The members of the Economic Community of West African States, including these three countries, were due to decide the size of the force and number of troops each country will contribute to their effort to quell the unrest which has displaced tens of thousands of refugees and local residents. AP, Abuja

Toxic waste inquiry closed

A Spanish judge ended an inquiry into Spain's worst environmental disaster yesterday, finding that the 25 people under investigation had no criminal responsibility.

Nearly 7m cubic metres of toxic material from a mine near Seville owned by their company, Boliden Apirsa, contaminated a river, damaging surrounding farmland and killing thousands of fish and other wildlife. Reuters, Madrid

webTitle: LA homeless sleep in the shadow of wealth

fields.headline: LA homeless sleep in the shadow of wealth
fields.standfirst:
Special report: debt relief
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: There may be no more greater contrast between wealth and poverty in the United States than in central Los Angeles, where streets of corporate headquarters and shining skyscrapers suddenly give way to skid row, the resort of some of the roughest and toughest of America's homeless.
fields.body:
There may be no more greater contrast between wealth and poverty in the United States than in central Los Angeles, where streets of corporate headquarters and shining skyscrapers suddenly give way to skid row, the resort of some of the roughest and toughest of America's homeless.

Attempts are under way to eliminate vagrancy as property developers spot the potential for profitable housing blocks for employees of e-commerce companies and the entertainment industry.

"There are people from all over here," said Robin, a middle-aged black man from Chicago who has been on the streets for 10 years.

"Some come to LA for the weather and then they get stuck. It's OK, but now they have this zero tolerance thing ."

He means the policy of not tolerating street-sleepers, adopted by the police department as pressure on city hall to revive the city centre intensifies.

Jack, a 60-year-old white man from Arkansas with a stutter and white hair tied back in a ponytail, said: "It has changed. There are more people - and more police."

Every US city has its skid row, but none is bigger than the one in LA, covering 50 blocks in the toy and garment districts. Its residents are mostly male and about half of them are black. Whites, native Americans and Latinos make up the other half.

Many have mental, drug or alcohol problems, and while most find rooms in the cheap hotels and rooming houses, about 1,000 bed down on the pavements each night in cardboard boxes.

The bacteria level on these pavements is three times that of raw sewage. The streets are slicked with dried urine, and sometimes blood.

To revive the central core, which has been in decline for 50 years, the police were asked to crack down on crime.

They did so by swamping the area with foot-patrols who enforced an aggressive policy of arresting the homeless for jaywalking and obstructing the pavement.

This provoked a storm of controversy in the city. Charities working with the homeless and the American Civil Liberties Union went to court on their behalf, and the courts ordered the police to stop checking the IDs of the homeless and throwing away their belongings. A further hearing is due on Monday

Alice Callaghan, of Las Familias del Pueblo, which looks after garmentworkers' children and acts on behalf of the homeless, has been working in the area for nearly 20 years.

On a tour of skid row, punctuated by cries of "How ya doin', Alice?" at every corner, she points out where attempts have been made to clear people from the street and where they still sleep in cardboard from the toy boxes imported from China and Taiwan.

"They want to make this a mini-Manhattan with bars and restaurants," she says.

Developers want to benefit from the cheap property without taking responsibility for the reason the property is cheap - the homeless who frequent the area, she adds.

"This has always been skid row. There's been an unstated truce here, and it's been the housing of last resort."

Criticism of the zero tolerance policy is exacerbated by the fact that after eight years of decline the murder rate has risen by 25%, and violent crime by 9%, but arrests are are down by 25%.

The figures are blamed on the police reluctance to intervene, for fear of being accused of brutality or dishonesty after recent trials of fellow officers for corruption. But with serious crime on the increase, charities are asking why the street-sleepers are being arrested for jaywalking.

On this sunny December afternoon, as homeless people queue for a meal ticket at the Midnight Mission, a crew are shooting a feature film that few on the street will see.

"I asked the director if he was looking for a grey-haired old drunk," says a homeless man.

"He said: 'No'. There goes my chance for Hollywood."
