webTitle: Debt: 2000 deadline brought sense of urgency

fields.headline: 2000 deadline brought sense of urgency
fields.standfirst:
Special report: debt relief
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: Jubilee 2000, whose task is the cancellation of the unpayable debt of the world's poorest countries by the year 2000, has proved to be one of the biggest global campaigns ever; it is compared to the anti-apartheid movement of the 1980s and its reach has far outstretched campaigns for nuclear disarmament. It trounced all the traditional sceptics, revealing an enthusiasm for activism which many thought had been killed off by compassion fatigue.
fields.body:
Jubilee 2000, whose task is the cancellation of the unpayable debt of the world's poorest countries by the year 2000, has proved to be one of the biggest global campaigns ever; it is compared to the anti-apartheid movement of the 1980s and its reach has far outstretched campaigns for nuclear disarmament. It trounced all the traditional sceptics, revealing an enthusiasm for activism which many thought had been killed off by compassion fatigue.

All of this was done by a tiny staff of 15 at its London headquarters and an expenditure over four years of just £3m. In that time, 24m signatures of support were gathered and nearly 100 countries set up Jubilee coalitions. Its phenomenal success has sent shock waves through much of the non-governmental organisation (NGO) sector, as many campaign strategists ponder how Jubilee 2000 pulled off what many regarded as impossible.

The success is widely attributed to two ingredients. First, the campaign had a deadline which attracted a huge constituency of churchgoers inspired by the Biblical concept of jubilee, a time to offer dramatic redress for injustice.

"The deadline also offered a unique organisational model for a campaign," Ed Mayo, one of Jubilee 2000's founders, said. "It was based on an idea by a radical Australian economist, Shann Turnbull, that all organisations should have a limited life, otherwise they develop ways of slowing down."

The idea is that the energy should go into achieving the goal of debt relief rather than in maintaining the organisation. The effect of the deadline, Jubilee 2000's director, Ann Pettifor, acknowledged, was to give activists a real sense of urgency.

Second it was an extraordinary coalition of groups ranging from aid agencies and churches to the British Medical Association, the music industry and the Mothers' Union. This formula was replicated in each country, forming an enormous civil network which commanded considerable respect at the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

Tony Burdon, an Oxfam policy adviser, said: "It gave the organisation a powerful mandate." Without such a coalition, he added, entertainers such as the musician Bono would not have associated themselves with it so strongly. Ms Pettifor is well aware, however, that the goal of debt relief for the poorest countries was not entirely achieved.

Effective debt relief, she said, could not be achieved under the current system because it was so stacked against the debtor.

"The northern countries are engaged in a debt-creation system to promote their own exports. What we need to do is change the system. In September Kofi Annan, the UN secretary general, proposed an independent panel of experts to mediate between creditors and debtors - that's what is needed to get the IMF thrown out of its pivotal role."

But the tight deadline and the coalition structure have also proved to be weaknesses; dedicated supporters are furious that the campaign is closing when the job has not been completed. In an attempt to provide some continuity, Drop the Debt, a campaign conceived in the same spirit as Jubilee 2000, will work towards lobbying the G7 meeting in Genoa next year.

The hope had been that while the campaign would come to an end, the coalition could be kept intact. But some members, including some of the biggest aid agencies, are adamant that the coalition must end. They have become anxious that the success of the campaign weakens their profile among supporters and fundraising.

Jubilee 2000 has given a big jolt to many of the assumptions of the NGO sector.

Ms Pettifor believes the campaign's success presents NGOs with a challenge. "The charity work of digging wells in developing countries is pointless. Its days are over. People who are concerned about development have got to concentrate on advocacy at a global level. The colonialist approach to development has got to come to an end and we have to focus on the structural injustices in the global economic system which make people poor."

Mr Mayo argues that many aid charities started campaigning because they lost confidence in their projects.

Their campaigns were half-hearted and amateurish, he says. Reports "fell off the trees like apples", and were merely aimed at getting a few paragraphs in the newspapers.

webTitle: Mersey beat gets stronger as arts profile is raised

fields.headline: Mersey beat gets stronger as arts profile is raised
fields.trailText: As Liverpool emerges from the economic doldrums, the city is undergoing a renaissance in preparation for its bid to become European capital of culture in 2008.
fields.body:
As Liverpool emerges from the economic doldrums, the city is undergoing a renaissance in preparation for its bid to become European capital of culture in 2008.

Museums and galleries are expanding, public buildings are being spruced up after years of neglect, a theatre has come back into the limelight after three dark years, and the city's symphony orchestra is looking forward to a stable financial future under a new conductor.

Much of the effort is concentrated in the heart of the city. Last week the Heritage Lottery Fund announced a £10m grant towards a £15m project to restore St George's Hall, one of the grandest public buildings in Britain.

A week earlier, the Playhouse, the oldest continuously running rep theatre in Britain until it collapsed in debt in 1997, reopened with a critically acclaimed production of A Christmas Carol after a £1.5m clean-up.

The Liverpool Museum, Walker art gallery and Museum of Liverpool Life are being expanded and improved in a scheme costing almost £34m and aided by a £24m lottery grant, the second largest so far awarded to a museum project.

The Philharmonic Hall has been refurbished and the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Hall has received most of the £5.8m it was promised under the Arts Council's stabilisation programme and is emerging from years of battling with debts.

Gerard Schwarz, at present chief conductor of the Seattle Symphony, arrives as music director in September with plans for building audiences.

In the area known as the Ropewalks, new media industries snuggle up against new private art galleries.

"All this should ensure that we are able to mount a full range of cultural activities if we are successful in our bid to become European capital of culture in 2008," said Peter Toyne, former vice chancellor of John Moores University and chair of the bid committee. "Within one week, there has been good news about two of the city's greatest architectural and cultural assets. That shows how determined we are that our bid should win."

Until last week, Professor Toyne also chaired the trust working for the restoration of St George's Hall, hailed by Nikolaus Pevsner in his guide to the buildings of England as "the finest neo-Grecian building in England and one of the finest in the world". It was designed by 27-year-old Harvey Lonsdale Elmes, who died seven years before it was completed in 1854.

"The hall is one of the jewels in Liverpool's crown," said Prof Toyne. "But it has been tarnished of late and now we are going to polish it up." The 740-seat Liverpool Playhouse, built in 1866 as the Star Music Hall and converted to repertory theatre in 1912, will now operate in partnership with the 400-seat Everyman in Hope Street.

Neither will have a full-time resident company and there will be no more than six home-grown productions in the first year. But theatregoers hope the troubled period for a city that nurtured Willy Russell, Alan Bleasdale, Bill Morrison and Chris Bond could now be over.

"We are making a real commitment," said Jo Beddoe, former general manager of the Playhouse, who has been wooed back to run a trust that operates both theatres.

webTitle: Osmond is back in his shell

fields.headline: Osmond is back in his shell
fields.standfirst:
E-xentric's value slides from £70m to £1 as entrepreneurs quit dot.com venture

More net news
fields.trailText: One of the dot.com boom's highest-profile bubble stocks imploded yesterday when internet consultancy E-xentric sold its business back to its former owners for just £1. Less than a year ago E-xentric was valued at £70m.
fields.body:
One of the dot.com boom's highest-profile bubble stocks imploded yesterday when internet consultancy E-xentric sold its business back to its former owners for just £1. Less than a year ago E-xentric was valued at £70m.

The company, a technology investment vehicle for Punch Taverns boss Hugh Osmond and a number of other well-known entrepreneurs, said it had scrapped plans to become an internet services group and was returning to its previous status of a cash shell.

The announcement represents an about-turn for Mr Osmond and his partners in the venture, who included fellow PizzaExpress founder Luke Johnson, internet entrepreneur Charles Nasser and Edward Spencer-Churchill, son of the Duke of Marlborough.

At the start of the year they announced a radical plan to cash in on booming demand for internet shares by transforming the stock market shell that once housed the Blakes Clothing menswear chain into a hi-tech investment company.

Thousands of private investors made a frenzied dash for the shares as bulletin board postings talked of big deals ahead and the tiny firm's share price leapt in value by 18 times in a single day.

However, as a more cautious approach towards investing in internet stocks developed over the year, E-xentric shares have fallen back from a high of 225p to around 12p.

Mr Osmond and his partners are returning to the drawing board. A spokeswoman said: "They have seen how conditions have changed and decided to cut their losses.

"A number of options with the objective of maximising shareholder value are now being considered," a statement added. E-xentric shares closed up at 13p.

Under the terms of a complex deal, MCA Holdings, which was bought by E-xentric for £12m in March, will be sold back to former owners Ian and Linda McAllister and Segun Ogunsheye for £1.

The three will return 15m of the 17m E-xentric shares they were given as part of the transaction but will retain an interest in E-xentric through various loans.

E-xentric will be left with cash reserves of £39m, which values the company at around 17p per share, the spokeswoman said. Most of the cash is left over from a £40m fundraising in March.

Mr Osmond is likely to use the shell to give another privately owned business a route on to the stock market.

Early trading in E-xentric shares was reminiscent of the initial rush to buy into Knutsford, the bid vehicle for former Asda boss Archie Norman which a few months earlier had seen its shares jump from 9.5p to 150p in a day.

It later abandoned ambitious plans to buy a retailer and instead purchased an online investor relations service.

webTitle: Lawyers hail TV cameras in courts

fields.headline: Lawyers hail TV cameras in courts
fields.trailText: Senior lawyers yesterday welcomed plans to allow television cameras into English and Welsh courts for the first time, saying the opening up of court proceedings would play an important role in building public confidence in the legal system.
fields.body:
Senior lawyers yesterday welcomed plans to allow television cameras into English and Welsh courts for the first time, saying the opening up of court proceedings would play an important role in building public confidence in the legal system.

Malcolm Fowler, chairman of the Law Society's criminal law committee, said: "Anything which brings the workings of the law closer to the public is to be welcomed."

Roy Amlot, the chairman of the Bar Council, said: "We are in favour of the view that there should be televising of proceedings."

Their remarks came after the Guardian reported yesterday that ministers were discussing plans to allow filming in court with the exception of jury trials and magistrates' hearings. The proposals, due to be unveiled after the election, would allow the televising of appeal court hearings, judicial reviews and House of Lords hearings.

A senior minister, who told the Guardian that a ministerial review group was being chaired by the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine of Lairg, said the ground-breaking initiative was designed to bring the legal system closer to people.

However, the Lord Chancellor's department last night denied that the government planned to open up courts in England and Wales to TV cameras. A spokesman said: "The Lord Chancellor is not chairing any ministerial review group looking into [it]." The spokesman confirmed, however, that Lord Irvine has had regular discussions with other ministers about court reforms. The lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, has completed a review of the civil courts, while the appeal court judge, Lord Justice Auld, is due to publish a review of the criminal courts.

Their proposals will be studied closely by the government, including Lord Williams of Mostyn, the attorney general, as well as Lord Irvine, and the home secretary.

Cameras would not be allowed to film jury trials and magistrates' hearings. Televised highlights of a jury trial could prejudice jurors, and witnesses should not have to be filmed, the minister said.

A member of the Scottish parliament was alarmed by the prospect of England and Wales following the example of Scotland where TV has been allowed in to court since 1992, provided all sides agree. This has included jury trials.

Gordon Jackson, a lawyer, voiced fears that such a move would turn the justice system into a "media circus".

Mr Jackson told the BBC's Today programme: "We did it in Scotland as a documentary but having tried it as live coverage, I don't think I would be keen on that any more. The main problem is that television distorts and trivialises, and puts pressure on witnesses and changes all of the dynamics of the court. The whole thing becomes a sort of media circus, which I don't think really helps."

webTitle: Tories plan school assault

fields.headline: Tories plan school assault
fields.standfirst:
Woodhead may play key role
Special report: Tories in opposition
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government is bracing itself for an all-out pre-election attack on its education policies and the exposure of strained relations between Downing Street and the Department for Education by Chris Woodhead, the former chief inspector of schools.
fields.body:
The government is bracing itself for an all-out pre-election attack on its education policies and the exposure of strained relations between Downing Street and the Department for Education by Chris Woodhead, the former chief inspector of schools.

Mr Woodhead will be released from his contractual requirement to remain silent about his views and experiences at Ofsted next month, after his early departure from the job.

He has indicated to friends that he plans to expose financial waste in education and Labour's resistance to the abolition of local education authorities.

William Hague has been so keen to enlist the services of Mr Woodhead that his advisors have been pressing the Conservative leader to sack his shadow education secretary, Theresa May, and appoint Mr Woodhead in her place. That would depend on Mr Woodhead accepting a peerage, which Conservative Central Office is known to be keen on.

The New Year's honours list is to be announced on Saturday, although the number of new peers may be curtailed by the government's plan that at least eight should be appointed following nominations from the public.

Under the Tory plan, Mrs May would stay as education spokeswoman in the Commons, but Mr Woodhead would become the Tories' chief spokesman on education.

Central Office believes the Conservatives are still failing to achieve a breakthrough on education and regards Mr Woodhead as the one man capable of quickly turning round the polls in Labour's strongest policy area.

The education secretary, David Blunkett, has been praised for raising literacy and numeracy standards, but Mr Woodhead has told friends Mr Blunkett is excessively dependent on departmental advisors and is only implementing policy started by the Conservatives.

Disagreements between Downing Street and the Department for Education which Mr Woodhead may expose centre on the role of the private sector in city academies and the tolerance given to Mr Woodhead to stray from his school inspections brief.

Mr Woodhead has always insisted he is not a Tory, but in a recent interview backed Mr Hague's key education policies, including his ideas of "free schools" and the reduction of waste through abolition of local education authorities. He supports the Conservative proposal that local schools rather than a central bureaucracy should determine performance related pay.

Mr Woodhead said: "It is clear to everyone that successful headteachers want the freedom to manage their own destiny. Tory plans for more autonomous schools do chime with many in the profession. So does the strong line William Hague has taken on discipline and exclusions."

Mr Hague has warmly responded by praising Mr Woodhead for "doing more than anyone else in Britain to drive up standards".

Between the announcement of his resignation on November 3 and departure on November 30, Mr Woodhead praised the dramatic improvement in classroom practice, but withheld handing any political credit to Labour. From February 28 he will be able to speak out in public.

Mr Woodhead has already undermined the government's record by backing claims that A level standards have been diluted. He has called for a new investigation into "grade inflation" in GCSE and A-levels.

He is also known to be frustrated by Labour's failure to abolish local education authorities. Mr Woodhead found that nearly half LEAS inspected by Ofsted were failing in their duties.

He is also expected to criticise education action zones and the Fresh Start initiative for schools as gimmicks.

Some ministers regard the unleashing of the unpredictable and abrasive Woodhead as one of the single biggest political management issues between now and the election.

They hope that if the former chief inspector over-reaches himself there may be a popular backlash against him.

webTitle: BMW dowry puts brake on Rover's profit hopes

fields.headline: BMW dowry puts brake on Rover's profit hopes
fields.standfirst: Special report: Rover in crisis
fields.trailText: German carmaker BMW yesterday confirmed that it expected MG Rover to repay a £500m "dowry" once it started to make profits, writes Nicholas Bannister .
fields.body:
German carmaker BMW yesterday confirmed that it expected MG Rover to repay a £500m "dowry" once it started to make profits, writes Nicholas Bannister .

MG Rover has said it aims to be in profit by 2002 and the assumption was that it would plough any surplus back into the business.

But BMW said yesterday that the £500m dowry it provided when it sold the British car company to the Phoenix consortium this year for a nominal £10 was repayable.

A BMW spokeswoman said the group's chief executive, Joachim Milberg, had made clear that the money was an interest-free loan which would be repaid out of future profits.

Neither company has revealed how much profit MG Rover must be making to trigger the repayments.

John Towers, the former Rover chief executive who headed the Phoenix consortium, is seeking to restore the British firm's fortunes, essentially by building 200,000 Rover or MG cars at the Longbridge plant in Birmingham.

He intends to revive the MG marque by adding a range of sports saloons to the existing MGF sports car. A new sports car made of modern composite materials is also on the cards.

Many industry experts have queried the 200,000 vehicles a year strategy, saying that it makes MG Rover too big to be a niche player but too small to be a volume manufacturer.

Final details of the Rover sale have yet to be wrapped up.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Five amateur divers from Plymouth hope to buy a decommissioned Royal Navy frigate to create an artificial reef by sinking it off Whitsand Bay, Cornwall.
fields.body:
Warship may become reef

Five amateur divers from Plymouth hope to buy a decommissioned Royal Navy frigate to create an artificial reef by sinking it off Whitsand Bay, Cornwall. The Artificial Reef Consortium's £400,000 scheme - the first of its kind in British waters - has been offered help from Australian divers planning a similar marine life refuge.

Artist's little wonder

Artist RB Kitaj has created the world's most valuable Post-It note - confirmed by Guinness World Records - after a tiny sketch fetched £640. His pastel and charcoal work - After Rembrandt - on one of the yellow memos was auctioned on the internet to raise cash for charity.

Cold Feet charity sale

Fans of the TV series Cold Feet, which ended this week, can buy Adam and Rachel's wedding outfits in a charity auction with other items from the comedy-drama for sale on the ebay.co.uk internet site. Proceeds will go to charities.

Mir's new year show

The Russian space station Mir will be visible with the naked eye from parts of southern England from New Year's Eve as it orbits 300km above the earth.

webTitle: Tap on car window saves man buried in snow for 16 days

fields.headline: Tap on car window saves man buried in snow for 16 days
fields.trailText: A 29-year-old US air force deserter was rescued after spending 16 days buried in his snow-covered sports car in a remote forest.
fields.body:
A 29-year-old US air force deserter was rescued after spending 16 days buried in his snow-covered sports car in a remote forest.

"Here is this poor little guy sitting with his hand frosted up like a little claw, wearing nothing but a T-shirt," said June Bloom, who dug Thomas Wade Truett out of the snow in the Deschutes forest in central Oregon. "He was so thin and grey in the face."

Mr Truett was discovered by chance in the middle of a weather system that has paralysed large parts of America. Mrs Bloom's husband, Chuck, saw a frozen black backpack, which had been uncovered by a snowmobile, as the couple negotiated a little-used road.

They stopped to throw the bag aside, the impact dislodging flakes to reveal a car window. "All of a sudden this little claw hand comes up and taps twice," said Mrs Bloom. "It just scared us to death. We thought, 'Oh my God, there's somebody in there.'

"We gave some guy his life and we didn't even set out to do anything remarkable that day. I'm not real religious but somebody was directing all of us up there. We never go up there, which is the amazing thing. We never saw one solitary soul the whole day."

Mr Truett was said to be in fair condition in hospital yesterday, suffering from advanced hypothermia. He lost 20lb during the ordeal, fuelled only by orange juice, a quart of water and a packet of almond M&M sweets.

After his car had become stuck in the snow, Mr Truett had spent four days in the woods, using a cigarette lighter to set small fires. When the lighter ran out, he tried to hike out of the forest but was too weak and returned to his car, where he wrote a farewell note to his parents.

Nine days later, Mr Truett had just enough strength to throw the backpack, a notebook and some clothes out of one of the car windows as a signal to passersby.

Mr Truett is expected to be fit to leave hospital within a week, but military police will take him back the 800 miles to Ellsworth air force base in South Dakota to answer charges that he deserted his job as an air force fuel manager.

Mr Truett's was only the most striking of the human dramas driven by the weather, with the effects most widespread across the south. Parts of the Texas panhandle were under 20in of snow, much of neighbouring Arkansas had half an inch of ice, with Oklahoma and Louisiana also affected.

Snow and ice brought down power lines in much of the region and 500,000 people were without electricity.

webTitle: Snow sweeping across Britain

fields.headline: Snow sweeping across Britain
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Northerners who enjoyed a rare white Christmas can expect further snowfalls as the first big freeze of the winter continues.
fields.body:
Northerners who enjoyed a rare white Christmas can expect further snowfalls as the first big freeze of the winter continues.

Southerners will see flurries too, as a band of sleet and snow sweeps across the country. In Scotland, temperatures are unlikely to rise above zero before the weekend. Elsewhere, they will remain below 5C (41F).

"We are looking at several days of really very cold weather with temperatures staying well below freezing," warned Peter Stewart, national forecaster for the Meteorological Office.

"Northern Ireland and southern Scotland will probably see a significant fall of snow with drifting and strong winds. We'll see outbreaks of snow across England and Wales but also some sunshine and we will see the pattern repeating itself over the next two or three days."

He also predicted that the north-east of England and Scotland could see strong to gale force winds tonight.

Looking on the bright side, he added: "It's the first really cold patch we've had, but you don't have spring to look forward to without a proper winter.

"There could be good sledging in the Cotswolds. If you're going on holiday you could get in a couple of practice runs on your skis there."

But the weather was bad news for other sportsmen and women. Traditional Boxing Day football matches were cancelled in Scotland and a race meeting at Wetherby had to be scrapped yesterday.

Motoring organisations last night warned drivers of icy conditions and urged them to stick to A roads and motorways. An RAC spokeswoman said: "In view of the snow warning, anyone travelling home should drive with extra caution. Even a smattering of snow can be lethal.

"Drivers should just do the usual common sense stuff. They should take their mobile phones."

A spokeswoman for AA Scotland said its breakdown service was struggling to cope with the increased demand caused by severe weather.

She said: "The demand for the service is four or five times higher than normal and we are calling staff in from days off and pulling out all the stops to meet that demand."

webTitle: Cordiant spends $88m on expertise

fields.headline: Cordiant spends $88m on expertise
fields.trailText: Cordiant Communications yesterday continued its acquisition spree by paying up to $88m (£63m) on US e-business consultancy MicroArts Corp.
fields.body:
Cordiant Communications, the marketing group that owns the Bates advertising network, yesterday continued its acquisition spree by paying up to $88m (£63m) on US e-business consultancy MicroArts Corp.

The takeover of the online branding and marketing specialist is part of Cordiant's strategy to build a one-stop shop for all its clients' marketing and promotional needs.

It also fits with the group's ambition of growing its business across the Atlantic and follows August's £392m takeover of US public relations and design consultancy firm Lighthouse Global Network.

Cordiant is one of the few remaining independent advertising groups but has persistently been touted as a possible takeover target since demerging from Saatchi & Saatchi in 1997.

Chief executive Michael Bungey has so far chosen to ignore the noises of potential suitors and plough on alone, however.

MicroArts helps clients including Xerox and Hasbro Interactive to combine both their on- and offline marketing campaigns and brand development.

Mr Bungey has agreed to pay an initial $47.4m in new shares and, if certain financial targets are met in the run up to December 2003, a further $41m.

In the year ending December 31 1999, MicroArts recorded revenues of $5.2m and a pre-tax profit of $0.5m. Revenues for the same period this year are expected to rise to $13.1m. Cordiant shares edged up 1p at 281.5p.

webTitle: P&O sells half its bulk ships

fields.headline: P&O sells half its bulk ships
fields.trailText: P&O has been forced to sell only half of its Associated Bulk Carriers shipping subsidiary to interests controlled by the Monaco-based Ofer family for £68m.
fields.body:
P&O has been forced to sell only half of its Associated Bulk Carriers shipping subsidiary to interests controlled by the Monaco-based Ofer family for £68m.

The UK shipping group, which was forced to drop an earlier stock market flotation for ABC, had hoped to dispose of all 22 vessels in the dry cargo fleet.

It was reportedly asking potential buyers for £140m.

Now 50% will go to Eurotower Holdings, part of the Samama group, while commercial and technical management of the entire ABC group will be transferred to London-based Zodiac Maritime Agencies.

Shipowner Sammy Ofer controls Samama and Zodiac.

A P&O spokeswoman shrugged off the company's disappointment at the part sell-off, saying it was a "good cash offer" which would allow P&O to gradually unwind its remaining ABC interests.

"ABC will no longer be a management distraction for us. It will just be a cash flow business and there is still an option for them (Ofer) to buy the remaining 50%," she added.

Ofer may also buy some of the remaining ships individually.

But city analysts said P&O was under pressure to sign a deal as uncertainty loomed about the future of the dry bulk market after 18 months of good freight rates.

A range of top notch shipowners, such as Bocimar of Belgium and Coeclerici of Italy, have also been in talks with P&O. They are said to have been put off by the high price.

P&O's managing director, Sir Bruce MacPhail, said the sale to the Ofer companies allowed the company to focus on its core ferry, port and container shipping interests.

"We are delighted to be working with the Samama group and Zodiac. Their significant interests and long experience in dry bulk shipping combined with ABC will make a real force in the market."

ABC made an operating profit of £3.5m for the six months to June 30 but lost £20.2m over the last twelve months upto December 3.

P&O, which was hived off from its cruise shipping interests two months ago, will now concentrate on selling off the rump of its property holdings and settling the future of its joint venture container shipping arm.

The P&O Nedlloyd liner company will probably be reversed into the Amsterdam stock market listing of Royal Dutch Nedlloyd, which holds a 50% stake.

But this could be complicated by the Dutch group's involvement in non-shipping activities, such as its Martinair cargo airline.

The ports and ferry businesses have been performing relatively strongly and are actively looking for expansion.

P&O recently unveiled plans for a huge new port complex to be built on the river Thames on an old Shell oil refinery.

webTitle: Prescott demands rail fare rise answers

fields.headline: Prescott demands rail fare rise answers
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: John Prescott last night attempted to quell anger over a new wave of rail fare increases and demanded that train companies justify their decision to put up ticket prices as passengers face severe disruption.
fields.body:
John Prescott last night attempted to quell anger over a new wave of rail fare increases and demanded that train companies justify their decision to put up ticket prices as passengers face severe disruption.

Passenger groups were furious at the above-inflation rises of up to 4.9% which come in on January 7, given that travellers have endured the worst disruption in the history of the British network.

During a tour of Leeds station - where a £165m regeneration programme is seriously affecting services - the deputy prime minister said he had asked the strategic rail authority for a report into the increases.

He also asked for a report into why more than 600 passengers were stranded at Stansted airport on Tuesday night because rail services ended at 7pm and there were no seats on coaches.

Mr Prescott, who arrived at Leeds station by car, passed queues of passengers waiting for buses because many trains were not stopping at Leeds from today until January 1.

Signalling work at the station meant passengers on lines to Wakefield, Huddersfield, Sheffield, Pontefract and the Calder Valley had to get buses to other stations.

He said: "It's certainly not integrated and it's not a good example if we want people to use an integrated transport system," he said.

But he stressed: "The regulated fares have had a reduction in prices. Many companies are able to offer cheap fares which are unregulated. Some have decided to freeze them, others have decided to increase them.

"I have asked the rail authority to give me a full report on it. I know it has caused a great deal of concern."

The Capital Transport Campaign group said that under the fare-capping system every train operating company could increase commuter fares in 2001, even when their performance had become dramatically worse.

The group is particularly incensed that the Silverlink company, which operates to north London and the Midlands out of Euston station, London, has put up prices by 4.3% despite finishing bottom in a recent customer satisfaction poll.

First Great Eastern, which operates out of Liverpool Street station, London, to Essex and East Anglia, is raising some fares by 3.3%.

"This is a particularly insensitive time to impose a large price rise," said Brian Cooke, chairman of the rail passenger council's Great Eastern sub-committee. "For passengers to pay an above-inflation rise at this time seems like a complete smack in the teeth. It is appalling."

Rises at other companies include a 4.9% increase on some off-peak fares on South West Trains, a 3.3% increase on Connex peak fares, and 3.3% increases on Central Trains' off-peak tickets.

Fares have been frozen by east coast operator GNER and by Virgin on its west coast main line and CrossCountry services. All these routes have been particularly badly hit by speed restrictions imposed after the Hatfield crash in October, in which four people died.

The Liberal Democrats' transport spokesman, Don Foster, said the increases were "the last straw" and demanded government action against the rail companies.

News of the fares hike came as airport officials launched an investigation after more than 600 Boxing Day travellers were stranded at London Stansted for several hours. An airport spokeswoman said rail services into London ended at 7pm and it was thought that coach firms would be able to handle passengers flying in after that time. By 9.30pm managers realised there was a major problem and organised extra coaches out of the airport.

The coaches carried more than 600 people into central London, with the last one leaving at 1.30am.

The spokeswoman said train operator West Anglia Great Northern had advertised the fact that Boxing Day services would end at 7pm well in advance.

It is believed that around eight flights arrived at Stansted after 7pm from destinations including Glasgow, Rome and Stockholm.

A spokeswoman for West Anglia Great Northern said information about the ending of the Stansted Express service at 7pm on Boxing Day had been put on the Internet, on posters, and the airlines and airport had been told.

She added: "The message didn't get through and we will be looking at that."

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Ahmed picks up handset trend
fields.body:
Ahmed picks up handset trend

Shami Ahmed, the Joe Bloggs entrepreneur who made a fortune out of restyling jeans, plans to cash in on the fashion for mobile phone accessories.

Mr Ahmed's Legendary Investments venture capital firm yesterday bought a 10% stake in The Accessory People, a distributor of mobile phone-related gadgets, valued at £10m.

The Accessory People made a pre-tax profit of £364,638 in the year to January 31, 2000 and plans to seek an AIM listing within the next 12 months.

Mr Ahmed said established fashion and lifestyle brands were looking to put their names and insignia on mobile phone earpieces, handsets, cases and other accessories as they became increasingly popular with young people.

Legendary also reported maiden interim results, showing an operating loss of £323,723 for the six months to September 30 and net assets of £7m. The company has yet to generate any revenue but says that will come from the sale of investment stakes.

Legendary shares climbed p to 3p.

Software firms' shares slide

Tech market turbulence continued yesterday when shares in two leading software firms plunged following profit warnings.

Wealth Management Software shares fell to a record low - down 60p to 115p as the firm warned full-year results would miss market expectations.

Six months after flotation, the company said it had failed to clinch an expected contract from a major finance house. "Negotiations surrounding the contract have been suspended and it is now anticipated that the licence element of this contract, which is expected to be worth over £1.5m, will be secured during 2001," a statement said.

Network Associates, a leading US computer security company, saw its paper value dive 67% after announcing a substantial profits warning and management changes.

The company, best known for its McAfee anti-virus software, blamed the revenue and profits shortfall on inventory build-up and said its president and chief financial officer were to resign. It forecast a $130m-$140m loss for the December quarter.

CGNU offloads Canadian units

CGNU, Britain's largest insurance group, yesterday held a £133m Christmas sale by offloading two of its Canadian businesses. Norwich Union Holdings (Canada) was sold to a subsidiary of American International Group for £71m and Commercial Union Life Holdings Canada went to Manulife Financial for £62m.

CGNU, created from the merger of CGU and Norwich Union in May, will focus on its general insurance interests, CGU Canada and Pilot Insurance, which combined rank number one in the market with a 12% stake.

CGNU said in June that it planned to dispose of its Canadian life interests and build up its top five positions in chosen markets. Its shares rose 20p to 1,097p.

Rio Tinto buys Australian pits

Rio Tinto, the world's second largest mining group, yesterday took control of a quarter of Australia's coal output when it bought five mines for $455m (£306m) from Peabody group.

Rio said the mines in New South Wales and Queensland would be integrated with those of its 71%-owned subsidiary, Coal & Allied Industries.

Combining the two should allow Rio to cut costs at a time when the price of coal is forecast to rise. This year Rio has increased its Australian holdings in aluminium, iron ore and diamonds as well as coal.

webTitle: Building on success

fields.headline: Building on success
fields.standfirst: B&Q planning to create 4,000 jobs in 25 such outlets over the next 12 months,  writes Julia Finch.
fields.trailText: B&Q to planning to create 4,000 jobs in 25 such outlets over the next 12 months, writes Julia Finch.
fields.body:
The boost to jobs, which will range from management positions to part-time shopfloor workers, was given extra momentum just before Christmas, when Sainsbury's finally sold its Homebase operation.

The main Homebase business went to venture capital group Schroder Ventures, but as part of the deal B&Q picked up 28 development sites on which Sainsbury had planned Homebase Depot stores.

Schroder Ventures intends to refocus Homebase to concentrate more on soft furnishings, lighting and garden centre produce. New Homebase chairman John Lovering says he has no intention of challenging B&Q in the "builders' yard" market.

Of the planned 25 new B&Q Warehouse outlets, eight will be on the former Homebase sites. Of the other sites, half have full planning permission and half have only outline planning permission.

If B&Q gets the go-ahead to expand on every Homebase site, they should all be open for business within four years. Should B&Q fails to get full permission on any of the sites, it can claim a refund from the £219m paid to Sainsbury.

A spokeswoman said the calculation that it will be hiring 4,000 staff was "a very conservative one".

Each B&Q Warehouse employs about 250 staff but B&Q believes it will need to hire an average of only 160 for each new store to take account of staff being redeployed from smaller outlets, which will close.

Dan Bernard, the B&Q stores director, said: "B&Q continues to be the most successful D-I-Y operator in the UK. The big-format stores - B&Q Warehouses - are becoming increasingly important and contribute more than 40% of sales."

webTitle: Oil shares get a warm glow

fields.headline: Oil shares get a warm glow
fields.trailText: Oil companies felt a warm glow yesterday on hopes of record demand for heating, as outdoor temperatures plunged to freezing levels on both sides of the Atlantic.
fields.body:
Oil companies felt a warm glow yesterday on hopes of record demand for heating, as outdoor temperatures plunged to freezing levels on both sides of the Atlantic. BP Amoco was among the big gainers, up 17.5p to 541.5p, with Shell bubbling up 15p to 550p.

Enthusiasm about the industry was warmed by a rise in crude oil prices, and by talk of leading producers curbing output - which could be bad news for motorists.

Forecasts of further arctic conditions encouraged talk of an upturn in demand. The weather, though hardly a sophisticated bellwether for stock-picking, was about as technical as it got yesterday. Private investors dominated, as most fund managers took an extended Christmas break.

A rally in telecom stocks helped push the FTSE 100 up a hefty 120.7 points to 6218.2, leaving behind Friday's seven-month closing low.

Vodafone was the busiest stock amid thin volumes, rising 5.25p to 237.25p after a report that it could be planning a £6.5bn bid for Cable & Wireless's offshoot Optus, which is Australia's second largest mobile phones carrier. C&W is keen to sell the business, as it concentrates on data communications, and any prospect of further global domination cheers Vodafone's followers.

British Telecom rallied 2p to 579p as the market digested news of an investigation by the government's red tape basher, Lord Haskins. The Labour peer was giving few hints as to whether he is moving towards a relaxation of the regulatory environment, or imposition of fresh measures to create fair play in the industry.

Few were prepared to extend seasonal goodwill to hi-tech stocks. Some traders muttered that the current phase of the internet sell-off could be reaching an end but there was little relief for the big players yesterday. Autonomy fell 26p to a new low of £18.74, Bookham dropped 10p to 970p and Freeserve slipped 0.75p to 97.25p.

Optimists suggested that private investors would be snapping up a few hi-tech bargains before the end of the year and there was a rare rally for software company Misys, up 46.5p to 661.5p.

On the retail front, cautious optimism prevailed about seasonal till receipts, helped by a statement from Asda, which announced a 20% rise in sales in the week before Christmas. Tesco edged up 6.75p to 282.75p and Sainsbury increased 0.25p to 399.5p. Even Marks & Spencer was in positive territory, up 3.5p to 192.5p despite unconfirmed reports of a further dive in takings.

A clearer picture on the retail front is expected in the new year, as stores issue their crucial like-for-like trading figures.

Bank of Scotland took a battering, down 5p to 707.5p with a relatively high volume of shares traded, as doubts surfaced about plans to merge with Abbey National. The banks are awaiting news from the Office of Fair Trading on their proposals, and one report yesterday suggested that Barclays could re-open talks with the Scottish bank should the deal fail.

Amid sparse corporate activity, Retail Decisions concluded a deal to help BT Cellnet avoid credit card fraud. It will provide services to scrutinise orders for top-up cards on pre-paid phones. Retail Decisions jumped 9.5p to 127p.

Meanwhile, Israeli technology firm Zen Research leapt 14p to 112.5p after saying it had signed a licensing agreement with a "global manufacturer of electronic products". Zen has a method of boosting the speed at which computers can read CD-Roms and DVDs.

In the drugs sector, Glaxo SmithKline had a quiet opening, up 29p to £18.77 on the first day of trading following the completion of its merger. Powderject Pharmaceuticals was more excited about the deal, up 51p to 561p on its hopes that the new industry leader would be interested in its needle-free method of administering vaccines.

webTitle: Micra jobs in the balance

fields.headline: Micra jobs in the balance
fields.standfirst: Nissan to rule next month on fate of Sunderland plant
fields.trailText: The fate of hundreds of jobs at Nissan's car plant at Sunderland will be sealed next month when the Japanese car maker decides where to make the replacement for its Micra model in Europe.
fields.body:
The fate of hundreds of jobs at Nissan's car plant at Sunderland will be sealed next month when the Japanese car maker decides where to make the replacement for its Micra model in Europe.

The decision on the new small car had been expected by the end of December, but company officials said it had been delayed for a month because of the complexity of the issues involved.

Nissan employs about 1,300 people to make the Micra at Sunderland. If the plant failed to win the contract to make its replacement, the bulk of the jobs would be lost. However some employees would be switched to making the Almera and Primera models as production levels for these models are ramped up at Sunderland.

The Micra decision is critical for the Sunderland plant's long-term future. Failure to win the contract - despite an anticipated £40m of state aid - would damage its chances of making new models in the future. The Micra replacement will be the first to share a common platform with a Renault model, the replacement for the Clio.

Renault rescued Nissan in 1999 by buying a 37% stake for £3.3bn, and the two companies are seeking to cut costs by developing common platforms. The platform - virtually everything other than bodywork and interior trim - can account for up to 70% of the cost of a vehicle.

Industry sources believe that the Micra and Clio replacements will be built at a Renault plant at Flins, near Paris. Modern production techniques would allow the different models to be built on the same lines, enabling the manufacturers to meet demand for either model.

The highly efficient Sunderland plant is being crippled by the strong pound. Company sources said it would have to cut its cost base by 30% to off set the currency advantage enjoyed by a plant in mainland Europe.

It is already seeking to cut costs by reducing its heavy dependence upon British-made components. The plant traditionally sourced up to 85% of its components in the UK.

Analysts said that Nissan, as it struggles to recover under the guidance of former Renault executive Carlos Ghosn, will base the Micra replacement decision solely on which plant will be the most profitable.

If Flins is deemed to be more profitable than Sunderland, the English plant's chances of winning new model contracts in the future would be slight.

However some employees would be switched to making the Almera and Primera models as production levels for these models are ramped up at Sunderland. The Micra decision is critical for the Sunderland plant's long-term future. Failure to win the contract - despite an anticipated £40m of state aid - would damage its chances of making new models in the future. The Micra replacement will be the first to share a common platform with a Renault model, the replacement for the Clio. Renault rescued Nissan in 1999 by buying a 37% stake for £3.3bn, and the two companies are seeking to cut costs by developing common platforms. The platform - virtually everything other than bodywork and interior trim - can account for up to 70% of the cost of a vehicle. Industry sources believe that the Micra and Clio replacements will be built at a Renault plant at Flins, near Paris. Modern production techniques would allow the different models to be built on the same lines, enabling the manufacturers to meet demand for either model. The highly efficient Sunderland plant is being crippled by the strong pound. Company sources said it would have to cut its cost base by 30% to off set the currency advantage enjoyed by a plant in mainland Europe. It is already seeking to cut costs by reducing its heavy dependence upon British-made components. The plant traditionally sourced up to 85% of its components in the UK. Analysts said that Nissan, as it struggles to recover under the guidance of former Renault executive Carlos Ghosn, will base the Micra replacement decision solely on which plant will be the most profitable. If Flins is deemed to be more profitable than Sunderland, the English plant's chances of winning new model contracts in the future would be slight.

webTitle: Tragedy hits music pact

fields.headline: Tragedy hits music pact
fields.trailText: EMI's hopes of an imminent tie-up with German media group Bertelsmann were dealt a tragic blow over Christmas with the sudden death of Rudi Gassner, who was due to take over as chief executive of Bertelsmann's music arm.
fields.body:
EMI's hopes of an imminent tie-up with German media group Bertelsmann were dealt a tragic blow over Christmas with the sudden death of Rudi Gassner, who was due to take over as chief executive of Bertelsmann's music arm.

The two firms have been discussing a combination of their music businesses, and recent reports suggested Mr Gassner would be joint boss, alongside EMI's Ken Berry.

News that Mr Gassner had died of a heart attack on Saturday sent EMI's shares down 7p to 557.5p, despite EMI sources' insistence that the 58-year-old was keeping his distance from discussions.

EMI has indicated that the talks are unlikely to be resolved before the end of January as competition issues are hammered out. In the meantime, the British firm is reported to be considering a listing in New York, where it feels music companies are more appreciated.

webTitle: At this price?  GlaxoSmithKline

fields.headline: At this price?  GlaxoSmithKline
fields.trailText: The champagne was kept on ice and the fireworks remained in their box as GlaxoSmithKline made a low-key debut on the stock market yesterday, with the shares edging up 29p to £18.77.
fields.body:
The champagne was kept on ice and the fireworks remained in their box as GlaxoSmithKline made a low-key debut on the stock market yesterday, with the shares edging up 29p to £18.77.

The few staff on duty at the drugs company arrived at work to receive a congratulatory email, signed jointly by chairman Sir Richard Sykes and chief executive Jean-Pierre Garnier.

The message made much of the growth prospects for the newly merged firm. But, as far as the City is concerned, the jury is still out. The brokerage Credit Suisse First Boston has set a price target of £21, but few others have pinned their colours to the mast yet.

GlaxoSmithKline is, by a slim margin, the world's leading drugs company with a market share of 7%. However, it is likely to lose this tag imminently to Pfizer which, after its recent merger with Warner-Lambert, is growing more quickly.

A series of setbacks on significant products has dogged the British company's shares over the past month. Most significantly, Glaxo's treatment for irritable bowel syndrome, Lotronex, was withdrawn on the orders of US regulators.

Critics of the new company make much of these regulatory knocks. But in pure financial terms they are relatively minor: Lotronex sales were expected to reach about $500m in 2005, by which time GlaxoSmithKline's overall sales will be close to $25bn.

More significant will be the progress of existing growth drivers such as SmithKline's diabetes treatment Avandia, and the rate at which Mr Garnier can extract savings from the corporation - redundancies and closures could yield as much as £1bn a year.

GlaxoSmithKline's late-stage pipeline does look thin; the company will need to trawl the biotechnology industry in search of promising drug candidates. As the biggest player around, the firm should be able to exploit its claim to be the "partner of choice" for smaller companies.

A research and development day next month, together with full-year results from the two pre-merger businesses, should crystallise opinion about the new company. In the meantime, sheer size makes it a refuge for investors taking fright at bad news from the e-commerce world. Hold.

webTitle: Net losses and gross gains

fields.headline: Net losses and gross gains
fields.standfirst: 2000 was the year of Stelios and Martha, Bob the Builder and Boo - and all the dot.bombs
fields.trailText: In the black
fields.body:
In the black

Ginger whinger Chris Evans was quids in after selling Ginger Media Group to Scottish Media Group. He got £75m when Ginger was sold for £225m - and SMG became the proud owner of shows that sounded good but bombed - like Red Alert and Lock, Stock and ...

Thirty three-year-old Stelios Haji-Ioannou turned the easyJet airline he started with a £5m loan from his dad into an £850m public company. Stelios still owns 32% of the company.

Ryanair's Mike O"Leary battered BA in court. He had used adverts branding the UK flag carrier as "expensive ba----ds". BA took Ryanair to court, where Mr Justice Robin Jacob described the campaign as "honest, comparative advertising".

Barclays Bank boss Matt Barrett hit the big time when it emerged he had a pay package that could deliver £30m. Barclays was simultaneously diddling its customers out of a proper counter service by closing 170-odd branches.

Freeserve and planet online founder Peter Wilkinson sold his 14-month-old Sports Internet to BSkyB for £301m just as all other valuations crashed. Wilkinson - an intensely-private, Ferrari-driving Leeds fan, who smokes roll-ups and guards his privacy jealously - is one of the UK's most successful internet entrepreneurs. He added yet more to his substantial fortune when Freeserve was sold to French rival Wanadoo - and is now doing very nicely with another venture InTechnology, a data warehousing operation.

Dr Mike Lynch had a triumphant homecoming with his Autonomy group. Two years ago the "intelligent software" group went for a listing on EASDAQ after being rejected by London as too risky. On its debut in London this year it went straight into the FTSE100 as a £5.5bn company. Despite the rout in tech stocks it is still clinging on to its FTSE premier league status, with a stock market valuation of some £2.7bn.

Bob the Builder hit No 1 and made HIT Entertainment one of the strongest performing media shares of the year. Bob, Scoop, Dizzy and Muck fixed it for the TV producer selling dumper-truck loads of merchandise worldwide. Bob is off to the US in the new year to give white rapper Eminem another kicking.

James Dyson cleaned up when he took rival Hoover to court for infringing his patent. Hoover were ordered to take every offending "Triple Vortex" appliance off the market. Mr Dyson now wants millions in damages.

Charles Allen gatecrashed the cosy little get-together planned by ITV's Carlton and United News & Media. Their merger was thwarted and he picked up UN&M's ITV franchises, winning the battle to dominate the network.

Tony Ball at BSkyB put subscriptions into overdrive after several years of zero growth, but then sent shareholders into a spin when he chose to cash in almost every share option he could get his hands on to bank nearly £6m. BSkyB explained he needed the cash because he had financial commitments and a young family.

Sir Richard Branson could have won the licence to run the national lottery, but was instead rolled over by Camelot's Dianne Thompson. The diminutive single mum eclipsed "Britain's favourite entrepreneur" in the publicity battle.

The Reichmann brothers were finally vindicated. Their Canary Wharf docklands development, which keeled over in 1992, is now the UK's biggest property company.

Michael and Yoel Zaoui, two Moroccan-born brothers, are said to have each banked £20m in this year's round of City bonuses. Yoel heads European mergers and acquisitions at Goldman Sachs. His brother does the same at rival bank Morgan Stanley.

AIM-listed Yeoman , based in the delightful surroundings of Lymington Marina and manufacturer of marine navigational wizardry, is set to be the best performing stock in the market this year. Shares in January: 62p. Shares now: 610p.

Trevor Hemmings , 64, the entrepreneur who owns Blackpool Tower, Royal Windsor racecourse and Eastbourne Pier bought back Pontins from brewer Scottish & Newcastle. He is also majority shareholder at Sportech, new owner of Littlewoods Pools. Its shares have rocketed from less than 5p twelve months ago to 27p. Last week he moved in on a more upmarket gambling business, snapping up 5% of ailing casino group London Clubs International, owner of high roller haunts like Les Ambassadeurs and the St James's club.

Carlos Ghosn, "le costcutter", has had a good year after being drafted in to turn round the struggling Nissan car company. His recovery programme is on track, but will the former Renault man let the Wearside plant build the new Micra?

Germany's finance minister Hans Eichel has enjoyed the block-busting revenues from the sale of third generation mobile phone licences while his tax reform programme is opening the door to corporate restructuring in Germany.

In the red

Durlacher Corporation took a dive in the dot.com rout. The internet financier was touted as a potential FTSE stock - but is now trading 90% off its peak value. Boss Geoffrey Chamberlain's stake has crashed in value by £300m.

Vauxhall's Luton carworkers were told they were surplus to requirements.

Alta Vista UK boss Andy Mitchell couldn't deliver unlimited internet access and his alta vista career came to an end.

The canary is extinct. It is an ex-inflation indicator. The Italians always included canary prices in the basket of goods and services used to calculate Italian inflation. Now it has been given the bird and replaced by the motorcycle helmet.

Railtrack put the country's entire rail network on go-slow after it failed to mend a broken rail and the Hatfield crash claimed four lives. Chief executive Gerald Corbett offered to resign, eventually walked and pocketed some £500,000.

Ernst Malmsten and Kajsa Leander, the photogenic founders of Boo.com, burned £80m of investors' money and then went belly up as the highest profile dot bomb. Details in their book to follow.

One million Equitable Life policyholders are facing big losses but 90,000 pensionholders now have a guaranteed annuity.

BT boss Sir Peter Bonfield has been under fire as the group's share price has plunged more than 60% this year.

The future was not bright for Orange boss Hans Snook. He lost out when Orange was bought by France Telecom.

QXL became the founder member of the UK branch of the 99% club - dot.com shares which have crashed in value by 99% this year. Once £8, they now grub along at about 8p.

Don Cruickshank, friend of government and action man regulator, has seen his reputation destroyed after a series of blunders in his new role as the chairman of the London Stock Exchange.

C&A called it a day and is going away.

Internet service provider Breathe.com expired, taking £30m of backer Martin Dawes' fortune with it.

John Hoerner, chief executive of the ailing retail group Arcadia and part-time top dog at Battersea Dog's Home, was fired. Mr Hoerner had presided over ballooning debt and an 80% share price dive in the last three years.

Jennie Page, the former Dome boss, lurched from crisis to crisis as a non-executive director of Railtrack and Equitable Life.

Bob Ayling - the man who fired Ms Page - was axed in her wake. He was then ditched as chief executive of BA.

Lord Hollick was unable to dominate ITV. His plan to merge his United News & Media group with Carlton were blocked and he was lambasted for selling the Daily Express to a porn baron.

Tony Illsley of Telewest refused to take a second fiddle role in the merger with Flextech and jumped although his fall was cushioned with £6m.

Wim Duisenberg, the head of the European Central Bank, now dubbed Dim Wim. Under his stewardship the value of the euro has been in virtual free fall for most of the year. Ill-judged - if logical - remarks about intervention did nothing to turn the tide in the forex market.

Elisabeth Murdoch conceded defeat in the succession battle at News Corp and quit the family firm.

David Elstein, who brought us X-rated terrestrial telly as the chief executive of Channel 5, was replaced by Dawn Airey.

Martha Lane Fox, the woman who epitomised the internet frenzy, went quiet. The flotation of her Lastminute.com group, founded with chum Brent Hoberman, marked the return to reality at the dot.com world of big plans and no profits. The shares hit 487p, but are now 78p.

The BBC lost the rights to Match of the Day.

Klaus Esser, the head of Mannesmann, lost Germany's biggest ever hostile bid battle. Vodafone's victory meant the dismemberment of the house that Klaus built as the UK group sold Mannesmann's traditional engineering operations as well as the Orange mobile phone operations.

The biggest stockmarket faller this year is likely to be WILink, provider of online investment products and services. It was previously known as Knutsford, the company which was once tipped to take over Marks & Spencer. It was backed by high profile property and retail businessmen Archie Norman, Nick Leslau, Nigel Wray and Julian Richer - known collectively as the "awesome foursome".

Alchemy, the venture capital firm headed by Jon Moulton, seemed certain to buy Rover from BMW until the Germans abruptly ditched their deal. Instead they sold the struggling car maker for a nominal £10 to the Phoenix consortium headed by former Rover chief executive John Towers.

webTitle: Korean police break up bank protests

fields.headline: Korean police break up bank protests
fields.trailText: About 6,000 South Korean riot police broke up a six-day protest by striking bank workers yesterday in the clearest sign yet of the government's determination to push through unpopular financial reforms.
fields.body:
About 6,000 South Korean riot police broke up a six-day protest by striking bank workers yesterday in the clearest sign yet of the government's determination to push through unpopular financial reforms.

With helicopters overhead, the police - carrying shields and batons - forced their way past bank clerks and technicians armed with steel pipes to regain control of a bank training centre in Ilsan, four miles outside Seoul.

Defying freezing conditions, 15,000 workers of Kookmin Bank and the Housing and Commercial bank had been occupying the centre since Friday in protest against a plan to merge the two institutions that is expected to lead to large scale lay-offs.

The strike has closed 90% of the 1,143 retail outlets run by the banks - the country's two biggest. Foreign investors fear that the strike will delay the financial reforms considered vital to restore South Korea to health in the wake of the Asia financial crisis two years ago.

Excluding the government, the banks' biggest shareholders are Goldman Sachs of the United States and ING Insurance International BV of the Netherlands.

Yesterday, police were able to take advantage of a weakened union presence because half of the demonstrators had returned home for Christmas. After being dispersed, those remaining were regathering at a local university, reports from Reuters news service said last night.

The South Korean president Kim Dae-Jung said the government was correct in taking a tough line. "The workers' demands cannot be justified," he said. "Whether to conclude a merger or not is a matter for management and shareholders to decide."

Government officials have declared the strike illegal and begun moves to prosecute union leaders. They have warned strikers that they face suspension and fines unless they return to work this morning.

Analysts cautioned, however, that the crackdown could backfire as workers at 20 other banks are set to vote on whether to stage a sympathy strike that would paralyse the country's financial system.

"About 70,000 unionised workers in the banking sector are likely to go on a support strike," Shin Dong-min, a spokesman for the Korean Federation of Trade Unions said. Fears of an escalating conflict drove the Korean currency to its lowest level in more than two years.

Analysts said that if the situation is not resolved by the time the stock markets re-open after new year, South Korean share prices are likely to continue the battering they have received in 2000.

This year the country's two main indices - Kospi and Kosdaq have lost more than 50% per cent of their value - making them the world's worst performers

webTitle: Sales sparkle for Goldsmiths

fields.headline: Sales sparkle for Goldsmiths
fields.trailText: Upmarket jewellery group Goldsmiths set a blistering pace for other retailers yesterday as it unveiled a surge in Christmas sales.
fields.body:
Upmarket jewellery group Goldsmiths set a blistering pace for other retailers yesterday as it unveiled a surge in Christmas sales.

The 159-strong store chain, which also trades under the name Walker & Hall, reported like-for-like sales - which exclude the impact of new space opened this year - up 11.5% in the crucial four weeks before Christmas.

The upbeat figures are likely to be in stark contrast to other retailers. Many analysts believe that overall takings have fallen short of expectations despite a good final week before the Christmas holiday.

The sector pinpointed as the most likely to disappoint is clothing and Marks & Spencer is expected to reveal particularly lacklustre figures, despite chairman Luc Vandevelde's promise of a "wonderful Christmas".

Store chains are understood to have been holding less stock in the weeks before Christmas - with the result that January discounting will be less savage than in previous years. The Goldsmiths' figures were particularly impressive as they came on top of last year's pre-millennium boost, when like-for-like sales climbed 26.3%.

Trading held up throughout the year. In the 47 weeks to Christmas eve, sales climbed by a total of 13.1% and 9.9% on a like-for-like basis.

Chairman Jurek Piasecki, who took Goldsmiths private 18 months ago after a long period of share price underperformance, said shoppers had shunned lower priced merchandise in favour of more upmarket pieces: "There has been a marked move to higher priced ranges".

fields.bodyText: Upmarket jewellery group Goldsmiths set a blistering pace for other retailers yesterday as it unveiled a surge in Christmas sales. The 159-strong store chain, which also trades under the name Walker & Hall, reported like-for-like sales - which exclude the impact of new space opened this year - up 11.5% in the crucial four weeks before Christmas. The upbeat figures are likely to be in stark contrast to other retailers. Many analysts believe that overall takings have fallen short of expectations despite a good final week before the Christmas holiday. The sector pinpointed as the most likely to disappoint is clothing and Marks & Spencer is expected to reveal particularly lacklustre figures, despite chairman Luc Vandevelde's promise of a "wonderful Christmas". webTitle: Inquest on cell deaths

fields.headline: Inquest on cell deaths
fields.trailText: In respect of the 548 deaths in police custody since 1990 (another police reform for Mr Hague to get his teeth into), we are aware of three cases in which prosecutions of police officers have occurred - those relating to the deaths of Joy Gardner, Richard O'Brien and David Ewin (Comment, December 19).
fields.body:
In respect of the 548 deaths in police custody since 1990 (another police reform for Mr Hague to get his teeth into), we are aware of three cases in which prosecutions of police officers have occurred - those relating to the deaths of Joy Gardner, Richard O'Brien and David Ewin (Comment, December 19).

The officers involved were acquitted in the first two, the jury failing to reach a verdict in the case of Ewin. There have been six further cases where inquests have reached a verdict of unlawful killing but where no prosecutions of officers have occurred.

Liberty worked closely in its research with the police, the Home Office and the police complaints authority, as well as representatives of complainants and victims of deaths in police custody. Many of the current proposals are based on that research. We recognise that the involvement of the police, both in investigations and in forms of local resolution, is an important part of any new system.

Inquest's work with bereaved families and their lawyers following deaths in custody since 1981 has drawn attention to the inadequacy of the system. Liberty and Inquest support the creation of a new organisation that will be able to independently investigate serious complaints. It is vital for public confidence and accountability for there to be truly independent and open investigation of serious cases, including deaths in custody, and effective supervision and control of the cases left in the hands of the police. The new proposed body needs proper funding, powers, resources and structure to ensure that it is able to effectively independently investigate and provide such accountability.

Mary Cunneen, Associate director, Liberty
Helen Shaw, Co-director, Inquest

I agree with Polly Toynbee in welcoming the proposal to reform the police complaints system. Ms Toynbee referred to the death of Shiji Lapite. In fact advice was sought from two different counsels by the PCA in this case. Both advised that no disciplinary proceedings could possibly be brought against the officers. The PCA made the only decision open to it - to prefer no charges. When charges are appropriate they are preferred. Following deaths in police care or custody, there have been two murder, three manslaughter and 10 misfeasance in public office criminal charges since 1994. In addition the PCA has brought almost 50 disciplinary charges.

However, we prefer a strategy of reducing such deaths. In 1991-93, before we began supervising all such investigations, there were 32 cell hangings. Last year there were two. We are now working to reduce deaths involving restraint.

Molly Meacher, Deputy chairman, PCA

webTitle: Heads sound alarm over teacher famine

fields.headline: Heads sound alarm over teacher famine
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Teachers' leaders yesterday warned of fresh evidence of a teacher vacancy crisis, claiming many schools were increasingly being forced to take on unqualified staff.
fields.body:
Teachers' leaders yesterday warned of fresh evidence of a teacher vacancy crisis, claiming many schools were increasingly being forced to take on unqualified staff.

The Secondary Heads Association published the findings, from secondary school conferences this month and in November, as a survey by the National Union of Teachers revealed that 1,400 young people who had qualified as teachers decided this year not to enter the profession.

The association said supply teacher agencies were now unable to satisfy demand. The shortages were worst in maths, science, technology and modern languages, although schools were experiencing shortages in nearly all subject areas. Selective schools, as well as those in difficult inner city areas, were having problems.

The survey by the NUT, the biggest teaching union, found a drop-out rate of 7% among newly qualified teachers against an official government figure of just 0.1%. Of 20,000 teachers who qualified during 1999-2000, some 400 resigned before their induction - the final arrangement for their entry to the profession - was complete.

Doug McAvoy, NUT general secretary, said: "The drop-out rate for newly qualified teachers is far higher than government figures imply. These findings are deeply worrying."

SHA general secretary John Dunford said: "The supply crisis is having a substantial effect on the education of thousands of pupils in secondary schools."

A spokesman for the Department for Education said of the SHA survey: "It is up to schools to assess the suitability of the people they select. Many so-called unqualified teachers are from overseas and are qualified to teach in their own countries. There is a teacher training agency programme available to convert them quickly for qualified teacher status over here."

He also disputed some of the NUT's findings.

webTitle: Upspeaking Bristolians

fields.headline: Upspeaking Bristolians
fields.trailText: Patrick Collinson, in reporting the Treasury's intention to control excessive bank charges, reveals "banks at present charge retailers up to 3% for credit card transactions ..."
fields.body:
Patrick Collinson, in reporting the Treasury's intention to control excessive bank charges, reveals "banks at present charge retailers up to 3% for credit card transactions ..." (Review 2000, Jobs and Money, December 23). In our antiques business we are charged by Lloyds TSB 4.6% - similar, I expect, for other small businesses which do not use electronic terminals.

Frank Dux, Bath

Nigel Wilcockson of the New Penguin English Dictionary pays too much attention to the US if he thinks that "upspeaking" began in California 20 years ago (Whasssuuup with this? December 27). Bristolians have been "finishing their sentences with an upward inflection, as if asking a question rather than making a statement" since time immemorial.

Ian Wilson, Thornbury, Bristol

What a cheek! The Marshfield Mummers are not from Monmouthshire, but south Gloucestershire, where the pageant has been a feature on Boxing Days for centuries (Keeping mum, December 27).

Brian Morgan, Bath

Boxing Day can never be the same again (Review, December 27). The Harry Potter reading has started a new tradition which will take its place alongside Carols from Kings and A Christmas Carol.

Anne Fennelly, Melton Mowbray

As a Guardian reader of 30 years standing and the owner of nine albums by my favourite artistes, the marvellous (and largely unknown) La Bottine Souriante, you can imagine my surprise and delight to find these two cultural icons brought together in your leader (December 27). Did this occur only in a copy of the Guardian specially targeted at me or was it available to all readers ?

Wallace McDowell, Kenilworth, Warks
