webTitle: Jason Robards obituary

fields.headline: Jason Robards obituary
fields.standfirst: Never a conventional leading man, but a stage and screen actor in the grand manner
fields.trailText: Never a conventional leading man, but a stage and screen actor in the grand manner
fields.body:
Within a few years of his New York stage debut as the rear end of a cow in Jack and the Beanstalk, Jason Robards, who has died aged 78, was voted Broadway’s most promising actor. The award by the New York drama critics had, by Robards’ own acknowledgement, been hard earned.

It was the first of many accolades during a long and distinguished career, including Oscars in consecutive years for All The President’s Men (1976) and Julia (1977). And while he never achieved star status as a conventional leading man, he notched up over 100 films and television movies, and was regarded as one of the finest stage actors of his generation, notably in the plays of Eugene O’Neill.

His passion for work may have been inspired by his father, Jason Robards Sr, who amassed well over 200 screen credits between 1921 and his death in 1963. The family acting tradition continues with Jason Robards III, a son from his first marriage, to Eleanor Pitman, and Sam Robards, a son from his third marriage, to Lauren Bacall.

Robards was born in Chicago, but found his formative years interrupted by the second world war, during which he served in the US navy, surviving the attack on Pearl Harbour. For his war service he received the Navy Cross.

After demobilisation, he studied at the American Academy of Dramatic Arts. His stage career included appearances in Gilbert and Sullivan, plus a rigorous year-long tour as the lead in Stalag 17, having understudied the part on Broadway. But it was O’Neill that established his name, first playing Hickey in The Iceman Cometh, then, during the 1956-57 Broadway season, triumphantly tackling the part of the alcoholic son Jamie in Long Day’s Journey Into Night.

He repeated the role in Sidney Lumet’s 1962 film of the marathon play. And 20 years later, Robards directed the play on Broadway while playing the tyrannical father, James Tyrone. He said that these roles were his favourites, alongside Hotspur and Macbeth.

Not surprisingly, after his east coast success, Hollywood beckoned, and he made his movie debut in the turgid The Journey (1959). Throughout the next four decades his wry, laid-back style became a fixture on television and in movies, and his expressively rasping voice and rather forbidding demeanour (like an American version of the great Trevor Howard) enhanced films as bad as Any Wednesday (1966) and Raise the Titanic (1980), and as memorable as Once Upon a Time in the West (1969) and Magnolia (1999).

Throughout a substantial early period of his career, he divided his time between stage and screen, sometimes creating roles such as the misfit in A Thousand Clowns before transferring the play to cinema (in 1965). But the attraction of lucrative screen work - especially to someone four times married, with six children - must have proved irresistible. From 1980 on, he made over 60 films and television appearances - not, it should be added, always of the highest quality.

Among his best work was a characteristically soulful Doc Holliday in Hour of the Gun (1967), and a sturdy Brutus in a lacklustre Julius Caesar (1970); in the same year he starred as the eponymous prospector in Sam Peckinpah’s elegiac The Ballad of Cable Hogue. He worked again with Peckinpah in the rather bloodier Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid (1973), playing Governor Lew Wallace, a politician better known as the author of Ben Hur.

The 1970s provided him with his best parts (before Magnolia). He was the father in Dalton Trumbo’s dark, pacifist work, Johnny Got His Gun (1971), played James Tyrone again in a television adaptation of A Moon for the Misbegotten (1975), following it with his two Oscar-winning films.

In the political thriller All the President’s Men he was memorably cast as Ben Bradlee, the Washington Post executive editor, controlling his crusading reporters during the uncovering of the Watergate scandal. He followed this pivotal role with a major television series, Washington: Behind Closed Doors, and in 1977 received his second Oscar as best supporting actor for an uncannily lifelike portrayal of the writer Dashiell Hammett, in Julia.

Robards brought authority to his characters, and inevitably became something of a specialist in factual roles. He was President Roosevelt, and twice played both Lincoln and Ulysses S Grant. For his quirky portrayal of Howard Hughes in Melvin and Howard (1980) he received a third Oscar nomination, and for both this and the title role in Sahkarov (1984) he received Golden Globe nominations as best actor.

As film historian David Thomson remarked, he was an actor in the grand manner and consequently enjoyed the part, previously acted by Orson Welles, of Will Varner in a television reworking of The Long Hot Summer (1985), and the barnstorming role of lawyer Henry Drummond in the 1988 rehash of Inherit the Wind. Here, he followed in the mighty footsteps of Spencer Tracy.

In contrast, he also relished a juicy fictional role as the neglectful father to Steve Martin in Parenthood (1989), and worked subsequently for its director Ron Howard on The Paper (1994). He was often called on to narrate prestige documentaries and television specials such as The Civil War (1990), Baseball (1994) and The Great American West (1997).

There were several notable cameo roles (uncredited) in films, including a drunk in Bright Lights, Big City (1988), an admiral in Crimson Tide (1995) and, memorably, the murdered congressman in the brutal opening to Enemy of the State (1998).

A year after that film, he took the key role of the bedridden father in the ensemble piece Magnolia. This mesmerising performance as Earl Partridge showed that he had lost none of his power or authority, and it set something of a seal on his legion of crusty characterisations.

And on occasion he was considerably harsher. He made a vengeful Capone in The St Valentine’s Day Massacre (1967), a menacing doc tor in The Trial (1993), an obsessed evangelist in Black Rainbow (1990), and was an appallingly heartless businessman, Wheeler, in Philadelphia (1993).

And who knows what he might have brought to the title role as the visionary Fitzcarraldo (1982) if he and the manic director Werner Herzog had not fallen out so dramatically. Happily, Les Blank’s record of the film and its making, Burden of Dreams, contains footage of Robards at work, revealing a dedicated and demanding professional who did not suffer fools gladly.

He is survived by his fourth wife, Lois O’Connor, and his four sons and two daughters.

webTitle: Make self-assessment less taxing

fields.headline: Make self-assessment less taxing
fields.trailText: Did you take a break from the festivities at Christmas to fill in your tax return?
fields.body:
Did you take a break from the festivities at Christmas to fill in your tax return?

This was the advice given by a number of tax experts including PricewaterhouseCoopers. "I would urge people to use this time wisely to ensure their affairs are in order to ensure penalties and surcharges are not incurred," said William Cardale, the company's head of client tax practice.

But, if you couldn't face the necessary paperwork, now is definitely the time to get organised with the deadline of 31 January looming.

Anyone who fails to meet this will have a £100 automatic fine slapped on them, even if they are just a day late.

After this, there are further penalties, as a month later you could be liable for an extra penalty of 5% of tax owed, plus interest. Even more alarming is a potential fine of up to £3,000 for failing to maintain adequate records.

This year, there are now far fewer reminders around, as the inland revenue believes most of us are aware of what needs to be done.

But thousands are likely to have forgotten, and even if you are working and taxed directly by your employer, you could still need to pay more tax.

This could be if you are self employed, are a pensioner with more than one source of income, are a company director, have received a windfall, own another property, have income from abroad or have company benefits such as a car.

It is essential to make sure your self-assessment form is properly filled in, even if you believe you have no tax to pay. Simply stating you are in employment and covered under PAYE (pay as you earn) is not enough.

Some liabilities such as owning a second home as an investment need to be declared on a supplementary form. You need to obtain these from the inland revenue, and full details are given on page two of the standard self-assessment form.

To make sure your tax return goes without a hitch, follow these guidelines:

 Get organised. Collect all information needed such as receipts or bills if you want to offset these against tax. Keep all the information until 31 January 2002, or if you run a business or receive rental income, until 2006.

 Among the documents you should have to hand are bank and building society annual statements of interest, share dividend statements, your P60 and your P11D, which outlines any taxable benefits such as company car.

 Make sure you have sufficient cash set aside, which could mean releasing money from notice accounts in banks or building societies. If not, you could face interest charges.

 Double check your form is complete. Those with omissions will be automatically rejected.

 If you include estimated figures - and experts recommend it is good to include even rough calculations - explain how you have arrived at these to pre-empt queries from the inland revenue.

 You do not need to declare tax-free nest eggs, such as TESSAs, PEPs and ISAs.

If you want help with your form, the inland revenue runs a helpline, but for those with more complex issues, you are best off using a tax adviser.

Tax calculators are also available at the Moneyextra website.

If you find filling in your form is a huge hassle, the inland revenue will do the calculations for you, but you need to meet the deadline of 30 September 2001. You can also complete your form online at the inland revenue's website. This also enables you to a £10 discount on your tax bill.

While there have been some glitches, a spokeswoman for the inland revenue promises that the site is now operating smoothly - although far more of us continue to trust snail mail for sending back returns.

The inland revenue self-assessment helpline can be contacted on 0645 000444 and the order form for supplementary forms is on 0845 900 0404.

webTitle: Billions lost in contracts failure

fields.headline: Billions lost in contracts failure
fields.standfirst:
Taxpayers miss out on windfalls after Treasury omits clawback clauses in private firms' loan deals

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Taxpayers miss out on windfalls after Treasury omits clawback clauses in private firms' loan deals.
fields.body:
The government stands to lose billions of pounds as a result of negotiating soft contracts with the private sector to build Britain's schools, hospitals and transport infrastructure.

Inquiries by the national audit office and the public accounts committee have revealed that the Treasury has failed to negotiate clawback clauses in which the taxpayer could share the extra profit if the private sector refinances loan deals.

In some cases, refinancing deals mean private sector firms, such as Group Four, are projecting to double their planned rate of return and move into profit within three years of a 25-year contract.

The oversight has led one Labour MP, Alan Williams, to describe the right to tender for private finance initiative (PFI) deals as the equivalent of Christmas.

The Treasury has now admitted to the national audit office and the public accounts committee that it had failed to negotiate clawback clauses in most of the current £17bn worth of PFI deals. Clawback clauses have not been negotiated in 69% of PFI deals, measured by their monetary value.

The Treasury financial secretary, Stephen Timms, has ruled that all future PFI deals must include a clause ensuring the private and public sector share equally in any windfall profit due to refinancing deals. He has also negotiated a clawback deal for the £100m refurbishment of the Treasury.

Private sector firms find it easy to refinance loans at cheaper interest rates and longer repayment times once the initial construction is completed to budget and the project is shown to be running smoothly. At that point the risk of the project falls sharply, making the markets more willing to lend at cheaper rates.

There is also evidence that the markets are becoming more confident about the political stability of PFI deals, so making more lenders willing to offer refinancing deals.

The national audit office has already highlighted the massively higher than expected profits which will be reaped by Group 4 and Carrilion for the first prison built and run by the private sector at Fazakerley, Liverpool.

The companies have refinanced the deal after two years, lifting their expected returns over 25 years from £17.5m to £31.6m - an 81% increase. Only £1m of the extra profit is to be paid back to the prison service.

As a result, the projected rate of return for the initial shareholders on a publicly funded project has tripled from 12.8 % to 39%.

The contractors have admitted they will be getting a 100% pay-off in two and a half years.

The public accounts committee has been told that of 105 signed PFI contracts, only 29% of them measured by value are covered by clawback arrangements. Not one of the 15 Home Office PFI contracts has clawback clauses.

Mr Williams, a senior member of the public accounts committee, said he did not object to companies making profits from PFI deals but he did object to taxpayers not getting their fair share of any unforseen windfall profits.

The Treasury says all new PFI contracts will insist on 50% clawback of excess profits.

It also claims government departments may have powers to withhold consent from refinancing, even if no clawback clause exists, if it can be shown the refinancing will alter the costs to the Treasury of early termination of the contract.

webTitle: Customers can benefit from credit card wars

fields.headline: Customers can benefit from credit card wars
fields.trailText: The cut-price credit card war shows no sign of disappearing in the new year, so unless you have iron willpower you might want to rethink any resolutions about putting less on your plastic.
fields.body:
The cut-price credit card war shows no sign of disappearing in the new year, so unless you have iron willpower you might want to rethink any resolutions about putting less on your plastic.

Egg has almost certainly stolen the show, with a new card offering 0% interest on purchases for the first six months. But, although other companies don't share Egg's enthusiasm for completely free finance, they do seem to like virtually free finance, with a myriad of providers offering introductory rates below 5%.

RBS Advanta, for example, has an introductory rate of 2.9%; Nationwide's is 3.5% and Capital One's is 3.9%. And one major provider will shortly be launching a card charging less than 2% interest for a whole year.

These rates are dramatically cheaper than most other credit cards, some of which charge as much as 25% interest. They are even cheaper than personal loans and a lot more flexible since you are not tied into the loan's repayment period. For short-term borrowing they can be ideal, as long as you have the discipline to pay back the debt rather than letting it sit on the card - after all, these super-low rates are introductory offers and usually finish after the first six months.

Although widely welcomed by consumers, the government is concerned that as a society we are taking on too much debt - in part because we take out lots of credit cards with attractive rates and then find ourselves unable to pay them off. In the event of a recession, many people may find themselves saddled with debts which they can't pay off whilst the interest racks up.

The moral of the story: by all means take out a card with headline grabbing rates, but make sure you pay off the debt before the introductory rate ends. Thereafter, try and clear your balance in full at the end of the month. Most cards have interest free periods of around 50 days from the time of purchase, so if you pay the balance each month, you will still be enjoying interest free borrowing.
